headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Southwestern Energy Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Bill Way, President and Chi
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Southwestern Energy Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Bill Way, President and Chief Executive Officer for Southwestern Energy Company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning and thank all of you for joining us today. With me today are Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Sherrick, Executive Vice President of Exploration and Business Development; Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning and thank all of you for joining us today. With me today are Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Sherrick, Executive Vice President of Exploration and Business Development; Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of our Southwest Appalachia assets; and Michael Hancock, our Director of Investor Relations. 
If you've not received a copy of last night's 2 press releases regarding our fourth quarter 2015 financial and operating results, along with our 2016 initiatives and plan, you can find a copy of those in our website at swn.com. I'd also like to point out that many of the comments during this teleconference are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties affecting outcomes, many of which are beyond our control and are discussed in more detail in the risk factors and the forward-looking statement sections of our annual and quarterly filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although we believe the expectations expressed are based on reasonable assumptions, they are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results or developments may differ materially.
Now let's begin. In the 4 years that I have the privilege of being part of this great company, our teams have accomplished a great deal. Southwestern Energy clearly has premier assets, disciplined capital investment, a low-cost operating model, a highly talented workforce and a strategy built upon our formula and inspired by our core values. I truly believe in the opportunities we have in front of us and the future success of our company. 
And although I know the company well, after moving into my current role last month, I thought it's important to take a stop and take a fresh look. And having done that, I'm confident that our strategy is an enduring one. And today I want to share with you several priorities as we move forward. I believe that credibility is derived from consistently delivering on commitments made and as such, wisely investing the cash flow from our underlying assets, which is a core part of the SWN formula will drive our decisions on investment activity when prices are high and when they are not. The industry is facing tremendous challenges, especially related to commodity prices. Inspired by our formula, we've taken clear and decisive actions to respond to these near-term challenges and strengthen the bridge to value adding growth in the future. 
To achieve this we are focused on building our strong liquidity to further strengthen the balance sheet, to invest it in cash flow, driving further operating efficiencies, enhancing margins and optimizing the portfolio. 
Starting first with liquidity, Southwestern Energy's liquidity position is strong with $1.9 billion of undrawn capacity on our $2 billion unsecured revolver at the end of 2015. Withdrawing on that liquidity to invest in wells that have margin economics in today's price environment does not make sense to us. We will continue to watch prices as we get further into the year and we can adjust accordingly. Craig will go into more detail of our liquidity and our financials in just a few minutes. 
Another foundational aspect of our company is that future cash flows generated from our currently producing wells and our Midstream assets more than exceeds our total debt obligations for the company due to our large high-quality asset base and cash flows for Midstream. Strengthening the balance sheet is a key priority for us in 2016. We did not plan to add to debt and are actively pursuing a number of options to reduce our debt levels. Additionally, we have previously disclosed we have taken decisive steps including idling our company-owned drilling rigs and frac fleets, as we're committed to invest within cash flow based on strip pricing in 2016. We are reviewing options for potential asset sales and as we make tangible progress and have decisions in this area, we will share them with you. 
We are driving further operating efficiency, we have taken further steps to improve our margin by removing costs resulting from reduced activity and lower ongoing -- lowering our ongoing cost structure. As a result of this decreased activity, in January, we announced a workforce reduction with deep personal regret that impacted 40% of our SWN team. When we look at commodity prices at our current plans, there just wasn't enough activity to support that size of employee base. 
Also announced yesterday we have recently finalized a new agreement that reduces the gathering transportation and processing rates in our Southwest Appalachia acreage. This provides 2 major benefits for us: First, it significantly lowers the gathering rates of our existing production in this important growth assets; and second, it provides a highly competitive dry gas gathering solution for the core of our West Virginia acreage, creating an additional optionality to allocate capital to wet gas or dry gas locations, including our Utica potential as commodity prices dictate. 
These 2 actions alone have reduced our ongoing annual cost structure by more than $200 million. On the top line, we are unlocking additional value from existing wells through a series of changes we are making to drilling completions and operating practices. The results are encouraging and our teams are working across the company to unlock additional value. 
Let me turn to Craig for a moment to discuss some of our financial guidelines. Followed by Paul Geiger who will discuss some of our operational highlights and our exciting first year of our ownership of our Southwest Appalachia asset.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill and good morning everyone. As Bill mentioned, Southwestern and the industry is facing challenges in this commodity price environment. While these challenges are substantial and requires action, we have taken significant amount of liquidity
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill and good morning everyone. As Bill mentioned, Southwestern and the industry is facing challenges in this commodity price environment. While these challenges are substantial and requires action, we have taken significant amount of liquidity with our $2 billion unsecured revolver that does not mature until late 2018. Southwestern and much of the industry have also experienced recent credit rating downgrades by the rating agencies and expanding credit metrics as a result of this environment. We are working to address these issues on a number of fronts. However, these actions and metrics have had no impact on our unsecured revolver or other debt instruments other than a minimal increase in our expected 2016 cash interest costs at our year end 2015 debt balances. 
And assuming those year end 2015 debt balances, total cash interest cost across all of our debt instruments will increase as a result of these downgrades by about $30 million on an annual basis beginning in 2017 and will begin to cutting again in 2018. The substantial liquidity position and active balance sheet management differentiates Southwestern from others. And when combined with our strong portfolio of assets, positions Southwestern well for a strong future. 
Additionally, and to emphasize a point that Bill made, these existing assets provide a substantial cash flow stream that at current commodity price forecast not only services our debt but pays it off over time. From a capital investment perspective in 2015, we began exhibiting our flexibility and modified our activities to align with the current environment as we move throughout the year. Importantly, we adjusted our capital investments down to $1.8 billion. This is a reduction of 30% from our original capital guidance of $2.6 billion at the beginning of the year and $50 million below our most recent public guidance. With this reduction, we're still able to deliver record production volumes of 976 Bcfe, a 27% increase over 2014, 9% of which was organic growth. And this growth reflect our significant operating achievements across the portfolio, despite depressed commodity price environment. 
I will now turn it over to Paul to discuss our first year of operations in our Southwest Appalachia business.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Craig, and good morning everyone. Our first year of operations with the assets in Southwest Appalachia was an outstanding one from an operational perspective. We had efficiently integrated the Southwest Appalachia into SWN during 2015. We lever
componenttext:
Thank you, Craig, and good morning everyone. Our first year of operations with the assets in Southwest Appalachia was an outstanding one from an operational perspective. We had efficiently integrated the Southwest Appalachia into SWN during 2015. We leveraged the many learnings and successes from our entry into Northeast Appalachia and Pennsylvania and was again demonstrated our ability to ramp quickly and produce impressive operating results in a short period of time. 
Our Southwest Appalachia asset has exceeded our expectations in every operational aspect as compared to our acquisition model. The genes hit the ground running delivering top quartile of drilling and completion efficiencies, a full 2 years ahead of expectations. Not only cost-efficient, this high quality execution resulted in an over 94% success rate of placing the drilled laterals some as low as 12,000 feet within our targeted 12-foot thick interval of the Marcellus. This exceptional performance combined with much higher sand concentration in our completions resulted in well performance that ranges from 30% to 100% better than the wells drilled by the previous operator on the same path. 
One outstanding pad development is our -- of this program is our [indiscernible] in the Central Panhandle. We were able to drill and complete 4 additional wells in this pad, placing 98% of the 43,000 feet of drilled lateral in our 12-foot target within the Marcellus interval. Initial production from the 9 total wells on this pad was over 900 cubic feet equipment per day, over half of which was liquids. 
In total, this initial year of drilling ramped production from these assets by over 65%, demonstrating the potential of this position. These factors have also increased our expectations of our core Panhandle acreage by over 50% on a per acre basis as compared to our acquisition. 
Over 200,000 of our 425,000 acres are in this core of the core from Marcellus and Utica development. Over 60% of which is held by production and over 80% of which has no obligation until 2018 or later. We accomplished a lot in our first year with this asset and we are not standing still. We are working to identify additional ways to improve returns as we continue development of this premium acreage position within a world-class producing basin. 
Across the company, 2015 included record drilling results, record well performance, material well cost savings and terrific results from our base production enhancement efforts. This performance had allowed us to build an even stronger base as we begin 2016. 
I'll now turn it back over to Bill for additional comments on 2016.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. As we close the books on 2015, I want to turn forward and look at 2016. And as I mentioned earlier, our strategy will be one that focuses on rigorous financial discipline and unlocking additional value. With our commitment to investing withi
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. As we close the books on 2015, I want to turn forward and look at 2016. And as I mentioned earlier, our strategy will be one that focuses on rigorous financial discipline and unlocking additional value. With our commitment to investing within cash flow, we issued guidance yesterday afternoon as you know that included the minimal amount of new activity. We are committed to investing only in projects that meet or exceed our 1.3 PVI hurdle and in this environment that can return the cash flow from investment in this year. We are prepared for a prolonged low price environment but we remain equipped with the flexibility and liquidity to ramp activity quickly when prices improve. With this planned activity, production is expected to decline. And while this is different from our typical E&P operational plan, we are in very different times from a commodity price perspective and we believe this is the prudent path to take for now. 
Having said this, as prices recover, we have the ability to ramp up and increase activity quickly and capture the value that is associated with those improved prices. We have the core DNA in each area of our operation that will allow us to pivot from our current activity level to evaluating growth as market fundamentals normalize. 
So I want to stop here with my remarks so we can get back to the operator who will explain the procedure for asking questions.

componenttextpreview: This is actually [indiscernible] on for Doug. So couple of questions from me. Clearly, with no activity this year, MPV has been pushed out. How does this changed the priority for asset sales? Can you talk to the depth of the asset market there? And is the
componenttext: This is actually [indiscernible] on for Doug. So couple of questions from me. Clearly, with no activity this year, MPV has been pushed out. How does this changed the priority for asset sales? Can you talk to the depth of the asset market there? And is there now an argument that SWN should pursue other opportunities, perhaps even an outright sale of the company?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about asset sales. And if this is part of, has been and is part of our overall plan. We're continuing to work on our joint venture with our exploration projects. We've had a number of different inquiries. I think we originally planned a
componenttext: Let me talk first about asset sales. And if this is part of, has been and is part of our overall plan. We're continuing to work on our joint venture with our exploration projects. We've had a number of different inquiries. I think we originally planned a large part portfolio and what we're seeing interests in individual pieces of that. So we'll continue to work on that. We looking at other candidates for sale including some of our other new ventures portfolio assets. And obviously, market conditions affect the choices on the assets that we would look at. But first we want to identify opportunities to pull value forward, that will be a priority of ours. And then what I wanted to do is discuss those when we complete them and we have a plan going forward that's more specific rather than speculating on the numbers. Your comment around selling the company. I mean that I'll just say we believe that this strategy we have is enduring. We believe that we're positioned with a very strong liquidity position and a very strong reserve base. We can manage and handle our debt in this environment and we are working right now on different opportunities to reduce that debt. And so looking to sell the company is not a priority that we're working on it.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, thank you and I have a follow-up. So year-over-year the decline is pretty large. I think 4Q to 4Q is about 25%. Can you talk about scenarios for 2017, 2018? Can you talk about perhaps CapEx to hold production flat at present levels? And CapEx need
componenttext: Got it, thank you and I have a follow-up. So year-over-year the decline is pretty large. I think 4Q to 4Q is about 25%. Can you talk about scenarios for 2017, 2018? Can you talk about perhaps CapEx to hold production flat at present levels? And CapEx needed to grow and perhaps what you believe best case scenario is in terms of returning to activity, any new gas around $3 or how are you thinking about it?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just put out our guidance around 2016. And while we can remain flexible and we have the ability to ramp up. Currently, there's a lot of conditions that can change between now and then. The simple fact that our production is declining from a compan
componenttext: Yes, we just put out our guidance around 2016. And while we can remain flexible and we have the ability to ramp up. Currently, there's a lot of conditions that can change between now and then. The simple fact that our production is declining from a company as large as ours is itself a market signal. I think when I look at 2017 and 2018, we've got various scenarios on how we might progress. But I want to see first how the rest of this year at least the early part of this year plays out. If you look at our current portfolio, every $0.25 [ph] movement in gas, adds $100 million of cash flow to our bottom line. And with our mandate to invest it in cash flow as we see prices improve, one of the opportunities for us is to get back into and restart our drilling and completions. We would certainly prioritize our work to wells that are currently drilled but not completed and then prioritize across the company in terms of the highest PVI projects. And how that exactly would work, I think what we want to do is let 2016 play a little longer. I carefully used the word idled my rigs. I didn't shut them down and take that away and get rid of them. We've had the capability to restart fairly quickly. If you look at where we would invest, certainly the economics in the Northeast tend to be the strongest economics we have. And as we have demonstrated by our well performance over the last couple of years, it takes far fewer rigs to drill and complete wells that have growing production than our original plans. So the number of rigs, the number of wells, that we are continuing the work and we'll talk more about that as we move forward.

componenttext: Michael, this is Craig Owen. Certainly, as Bill mentioned, we've got a lot of options. Our balance sheet, our liquidity position probably give us a number of options that we could look at we look at all of them. As we think about improving going forward, improving the balance sheet, certainly we are aware of where our debt trade and our potential there. But we're going to look to maintaining strong liquidity, we're going to look to maintaining a strong balance sheet and trying to address options that are most valuable today. And certainly as we look to drill, or we look to complete or we look for maybe financial options, we'll consider all of those as we move through.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's me, Charles Meade. I wanted to ask about, Bill, I think you touched on some of this already. But I wonder if you can get you to elaborate on the approach on the docks as it sits with your 1.3 PVI hurdle. It would seem to me that I recognize
componenttext: I think that's me, Charles Meade. I wanted to ask about, Bill, I think you touched on some of this already. But I wonder if you can get you to elaborate on the approach on the docks as it sits with your 1.3 PVI hurdle. It would seem to me that I recognize -- it seemed to me that the most of the money is spent on completions with these wells. But it seems to me that with the drilling already done, that you would have a lot more of those docks that would meet your 1.3 PVI hurdle and I wonder if you're limited you just working down to 20 to 30 docks this year. It's that more limitation on the PVI? Or is it more of a limitation on the overall cash flow? And are you biased to doing those docks in the back half of the year?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we would do is we're looking at it from 2 perspectives that you got both of them. It's not only the PVI and related to PVI we prioritized those highest PVI across the company that's how we allocate capital. Certainly those that we would do this
componenttext: Yes, what we would do is we're looking at it from 2 perspectives that you got both of them. It's not only the PVI and related to PVI we prioritized those highest PVI across the company that's how we allocate capital. Certainly those that we would do this year and that can return the cash flow or greater in this year are up in the Q as well. And then investing within cash flow. So the economics for the portfolio of projects that we have are quite high. The investment cash flow circuit breaker which we've imposed is that piece as well. We've already done some of them as we started the year so the benefit of that production could roll in but we'll keep monitoring that. And as we go forward, again should we see a change in price or should we elect to put that money to work in either drilling or completions or any kind of project, we'll allocate them based off of those that criteria.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just following up on the other comment you made earlier, but you talked about your wells in the Northeast. Wanted to drill down a bit on that because it was really helpful table that you guys put in your press release but it looked to me like
componenttext: Got it. And just following up on the other comment you made earlier, but you talked about your wells in the Northeast. Wanted to drill down a bit on that because it was really helpful table that you guys put in your press release but it looked to me like your best capital efficiency would actually be in Southwest Appalachia. Maybe that's part of what you meant by the Northeast. But I recognize it's not just about volumes, it's about revenue and so I wondered if that is the right conclusion that Southwest Appalachia is where you'd put that money to work? And am I right that this is about I notice a lot of assumptions about a year's worth of docks that you have?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have about 100 docks in our total inventory. And to be really clear, we don't -- we have docks that we have an inventory typically are only in the docks that are required to keep them that machine running efficiently. We don't drill wells and hold them
componenttext: We have about 100 docks in our total inventory. And to be really clear, we don't -- we have docks that we have an inventory typically are only in the docks that are required to keep them that machine running efficiently. We don't drill wells and hold them and hope for prices to recover someday in the future. This is not part of our DNA. When I mentioned Northeast I was referring to the entire Northeast. Apologies for that. That's both Northeast and Southwest. And as you look at either of those areas, you dissect further down and into the individual acreage or the individual areas of this acreage. You've also got the wet versus dry dynamic in Southwest Appalachia. And so again we don't look at averages across different plays. We go project by project, well by well, whatever it happens to be and prioritize them that way.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I wanted us kind of a high-level question and that is what's your current review regarding approvals of the pending Appalachia pipeline projects? The environmental obviously seems to be maybe some end rows, for example, the stalling of constitution
componenttext: Right. I wanted us kind of a high-level question and that is what's your current review regarding approvals of the pending Appalachia pipeline projects? The environmental obviously seems to be maybe some end rows, for example, the stalling of constitution of New York and the U.S. [indiscernible] services recent reduction in Atlantic Coast pipeline. So I was just wondering I'm sure you're watching closely just kind of wondering what your view is.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you look at the Northeast part of Pennsylvania, so that portion, we have run into challenges probably more related to the various different states than general environmentalist -- we're an environmentalist we work very hard to work in ar
componenttext: Yes, I think when you look at the Northeast part of Pennsylvania, so that portion, we have run into challenges probably more related to the various different states than general environmentalist -- we're an environmentalist we work very hard to work in areas where we operate and live within minimizing our footprint. But I think the Constitution Pipeline is really caught up in some issues related to the State of New York more than just in general because I think the State of Pennsylvania is ready to move on that. We have a portion of that pipeline in our portfolio. We've always planned to be -- our earliest plan 2, 3 years ago was far to come at the end of this year. So we basically managed around it so that we're pretty flexible. At the end of the day, when I get done, I think if the people of New York want to capitalize on the great value that natural gas brings to heating, I think we will speak up at that project to move ahead. When you look at the Southwest Appalachia area, it's a bit of different dynamic. It seems much liquid market, there's a lot more opportunities and a lot more projects moving into the area and they seem to be moving at pace. I mean we've got to listen to work together with the stakeholders but from what we understand, these projects are moving along from the perspective of getting approvals and getting all those. The certainly in the market as it unfolds going forward and pricing will also help dictate the pace of those but you've got projects that are proposed that span the next 5 or 4 years and they all seem to, at this point be lining up to be exactly where we need them to be.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful color. And if I ask one last. I think I heard you say earlier on the call that there's some new approaches to DNC that are significant. I just wondered if you could add some color on that.
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful color. And if I ask one last. I think I heard you say earlier on the call that there's some new approaches to DNC that are significant. I just wondered if you could add some color on that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you look at it and Paul could speak to this more when we get into Avenue discussion about Southwest Appalachia but we've taken a very, very hard look at how we drill wells. In fact, we spend a lot of time of redrilling wells in paper to see how
componenttext: Yes, when you look at it and Paul could speak to this more when we get into Avenue discussion about Southwest Appalachia but we've taken a very, very hard look at how we drill wells. In fact, we spend a lot of time of redrilling wells in paper to see how what I thought was going to happen happen and what it can do to change. The technology and the tools that are able to enable us to steer wells much closer to the drillbit than we ever have before, often times are used offshore technologies, enable those tools should be readily available for us in a lower commodity -- lower-cost environment on shoring shale. And so we've got the ability to steer and we've got the ability to see where we want to steer so lateral placement becomes so much more important. And as Paul said earlier, we can actually steer one of the 12,000-foot laterals. I believe we stayed in a 12-foot zone for 100% of the time with the tools that we have. If you can stay in that zone and you can get that lateral drilled then the completion techniques that we're using especially around sand loading to improve the near wellbore quality of the frac become significant. And the third thing, and Paul mentioned this as well, around the the content of liquids to gas and these pads is just like the old days of Haynesville, but for different reasons, managing the draw down on these reservoirs significantly improves or have the effects the outcome of the liquid content that is coming out of these wells. And so those techniques plus some of the work that we've done across the company and other areas around timing of beginning to flow wells in terms of debottlenecking the infrastructure that is both downhole and on the surface have really impacted performance across our company and we continue to share those techniques in each of the areas. We've made a lot of these major strides when we moved into Pennsylvania, 5 years ago, 6 years ago and the effects were significant. We took that team and moved it over to West Virginia and that team replicated that terrific [indiscernible] results in that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could discuss and on the past you all have provided some pretty good context in terms of what the inventory of locations look like in the area at different gas prices. So like at $2.50, how much do you have in inventory in Appalachi
componenttext: I was wondering if you could discuss and on the past you all have provided some pretty good context in terms of what the inventory of locations look like in the area at different gas prices. So like at $2.50, how much do you have in inventory in Appalachia say versus a [indiscernible] Shale that meet that threshold?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just say that we've got the specific inventory numbers coming out in the IR book next week so I will get those numbers. But what I can say is at $3, we still have a couple of thousand of wells in inventory that we can -- that meet our hurdle and we
componenttext: Let me just say that we've got the specific inventory numbers coming out in the IR book next week so I will get those numbers. But what I can say is at $3, we still have a couple of thousand of wells in inventory that we can -- that meet our hurdle and we can certainly go drill. And as the price comes off that, you have a full slate of wells that you can drill across the company and it gets back to that management and cash flow circuit breaker that we've imposed on ourselves to make sure that we're not going past that. Obviously, the Fayetteville Shale is more sensitive to gas prices. And as you go through so you can have $3.50, you can have 5,000 well locations and in its current prices today that number dropped significantly. In fact, I don't have economic wells to drill in this 10 seconds and what is now the third lowest March strip since we began tracking all of this. So you do have there's a lot of swing there. When you move to the Northeast, certainly the Northeast Pennsylvania is less sensitive but you still see a change drop off that you've got 1,300 wells or so in the inventory when prices get down, that number may drop down by half. Southwest Appalachia has 2 different kind of aspects to it. One is we have dry gas, we have wet gas, then the dry gas is even further subdivided into Marcellus and Utica. So as we work through the economics and certainly and the big deal is this gathering deal that you just finished with Williams, which expanded the pipe for both of us and is a win-win for both of us and is enabling our economic threshold of a big chunk of that acreage improve. So you've got that dynamic as well. We finished our first Utica well and when the first drilling goes, we don't need to or plan to complete it at this time because it's actually not in an area where our pipeline is built yet. So our rigorous attention to the margin is certainly there. But we know that, that area is far less sensitive to some of these changes in gas price and inventory means. So we've always been a low cost operator, we will drive even further to get our structural cost to change and bring it down along with these techniques that we've been talking about on improving the revenue side. In other words, the performance side of these wells and I think we'll continue to move ourselves along those curves as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that color and deifinitely look forward to an update. As my follow-up question, you did briefly mention that Utica well and that's certainly something I want to focus a little bit on. I guess your comment was we're not going to compete it at
componenttext: I appreciate that color and deifinitely look forward to an update. As my follow-up question, you did briefly mention that Utica well and that's certainly something I want to focus a little bit on. I guess your comment was we're not going to compete it at this point. But the area appears to be less sensitive on gas prices. What in your opinion is your plan at this point with the dry gas at Utica. It feels like it's an area can monetize or in fact, develop as your most economic asset if it works out. But without an infrastructure there, what's it going to take to get that within the program?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing that they've got going for us very strongly is that our Utica expands a good portion of our acreage. And as I've mentioned in my opening comments, the northern part of our acreage is where we've also captured a gathering solution with Williams t
componenttext: One thing that they've got going for us very strongly is that our Utica expands a good portion of our acreage. And as I've mentioned in my opening comments, the northern part of our acreage is where we've also captured a gathering solution with Williams to gather that gas. And so as we begin the process of looking at how we want to lay that out now that we have that agreement in place, you can build that infrastructure out fairly quickly again given the economics, driven by priority but you can build that infrastructure pretty quickly and begin to look. Our next few wells in the area of the Utica we are planning in the north and that was because the dry gas infrastructure is present around those and we can move them in. If you then take a look at the wells that are being drilled and completed all around us, those wells are proving up our position and we are delighted with the success that our colleagues and the industry are having and it just reinforces the quality of the acreage that we have. And as soon as we can in the priority of investing with the cash flow and where they fit in the priority stack, we will begin getting down that path. I would remind everyone that when we did the acquisition, our plans were to do to begin the process of drilling the Utica in 2018 and so the well that we drilled in this last year advanced that by 2 years and we still see a lot of opportunities in that area. It's just a matter of prioritization at this point. And just to make some further clarity on the completion of the well that we did drill, we were going to point that in the wet gas system, it was a test in that part of our area and wanted to do that we've got worked out an arrangement to be able to do that. But honestly when you're putting a dry gas well into wet gas system, you need to take an impairment on economics. And so will just way to compute that well. If I get if and when we get the Utica north.

And I just don't we don't have that right now that was not our plan for this year at this point.

componenttext: I apologize if I missed this when you were talking about potential divestiture candidates, and in the past you guys have been very reticent to think about monetizing it. But can you give us kind of your lastest thoughts around Boardwalk Pipeline with production volumes in the Fayetteville no longer growing actually declining? How do we think about that as a potential item for monetization and redeployment of capital?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, for clarity, we don't have any Boardwalk Pipeline so we're not going to sell it. But if your question is referring to our Midstream business in Arkansas, everything I just tell you right up front and I don't want you to read -- over read this. But we
componenttext: Yes, for clarity, we don't have any Boardwalk Pipeline so we're not going to sell it. But if your question is referring to our Midstream business in Arkansas, everything I just tell you right up front and I don't want you to read -- over read this. But we cultivated options and we cultivate them all so we take objective looks at everything we're doing. Our focus on asset divestitures right now is on continuing to work on our joint venture work with our exploration projects and looking at some of those new venture projects as an opportunity to monetize them and any other sort of asset that really doesn't have current year cash flow. I mean that our Midstream business in Arkansas is a significant contributor to our cash flow. We're focused on our cash flow at the moment and we see very strong value in having that in our company. And so right now we're focused on trying to bring future value forward and that's where our priority will lie and really of my style is want you all know we looking at these things, we're looking at them hard. But I rather talk to you about deals we have in hand or deal we might make rather than just speculate on what we might or might not do. But certainly our Midstream business, as we've discussed before is important to us and at this point is not high on my list of things to think about.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that. And then one last one relative to kind of liberating production declines. And are there any concerns as you bring those back to work that there could be service deliverability issues to kind of be able to abate production declines?

componenttext: Yes, this is Paul. We've got the ability to pull those folks from the field and from an outside service standpoint, we do see that although there's been significant reduction in that standby supply services that those do still exist in our core operating areas.

componenttext: We have a couple of examples where we recently we're doing some completions after the Northeast and the crews had to come from South Dakota or somewhere. Much further away. So commuting time to getting there and ramp-up time is a little bit longer. But we also if they were going into a resumption of activity mode, we would bring our own frac crews in and certainly you got to be efficient here as you do this just to manage the cost that we incur.

componenttext: I appreciate that. headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Our core asset areas, we don't have an issue at all. And we maintained discussions and dialogues with our chosen third-party suppliers and I'm confident that, that's not an issue for us. We have some of the best rigs that are running and we have, with
componenttext: No. Our core asset areas, we don't have an issue at all. And we maintained discussions and dialogues with our chosen third-party suppliers and I'm confident that, that's not an issue for us. We have some of the best rigs that are running and we have, with a couple of fracs fleets to go with that. So those are maintained in a ready mode. We don't -- we're not cannibalizing them, taking them apart, doing all that. And as was mentioned earlier, we have kept the core DNA in the company that has the relationships, that has the context and if and when when we need to bring those back on, we can do that fairly quickly. I think 30 to 60 days is very doable.

componenttext: Tim, we kind of put $2.35 out there as just kind of a point to $0.25 delta. So certainly the some extent we can reduce below that. We've broken out our capital into 2 lines kind of on purpose on the discretionary piece and then we'll capitalize interest expense. We can't really change that. We can flex a little bit on the discretionary and we'll continue to do so. As we mentioned earlier, no rigs running, got opportunities on our dock inventory that we continue to manage. We're working on margins, we're working on balance sheet all the way around to see what we can do to address the cash flow to the environment that we're in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you all for participating today. In closing our call, I want you to know I'm very confident that the actions we're implementing really does support our strategy, will allow us to drive through these times created by this commodity price position tha
componenttext:
Thank you all for participating today. In closing our call, I want you to know I'm very confident that the actions we're implementing really does support our strategy, will allow us to drive through these times created by this commodity price position that we're in. We're going to optimize the business and continue to drive for every dollar we can in that area and really positioned ourselves to return to evaluating growth when the environment improves. 
So before we kind of conclude, I want to emphasize especially how to deliver on these strategic priorities and to win in this environment is really beyond is unwavering that is probably the best way I can put that. I firmly believe that our strong liquidity position, our premier portfolio of assets, invested within cash flow as a mandate that is important ourselves our capital discipline of investing only in projects that exceed our 1.3 PVI hurdle, our aggressive drive on margin improvement and really probably the most important part our team of extraordinary people across the company will really enable us to execute the plan and allow us to forge ahead in these times and also create additional long-term value for our shareholders. In my experience, times like these challenging times are often when the industry delivers the brightest ideas that take us in the next level and I can tell you we plan to be a big part of that future and a big part of unlocking ideas and value from our curiosity and learning here at Southwestern. So thank you for joining the call. I look forward to meeting with you meeting new faces that are on the call and thank those that have been on the call previously for being here and you all have a great weekend.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Southwestern Energy Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Bill Way, President and Chi
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Southwestern Energy Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Bill Way, President and Chief Executive Officer for Southwestern Energy Company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and thanks to all of you for joining us today. With me today, I've got Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Sherrick, Executive Vice President of Exploration and Business Development; Paul Geiger, Senior Vice Pr
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and thanks to all of you for joining us today. With me today, I've got Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Sherrick, Executive Vice President of Exploration and Business Development; Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of our Southwest Appalachia assets; and Michael Hancock, our Director of Investor Relations. 
If you've not received a copy of last night's 2 press releases regarding our fourth quarter 2015 financial and operating results, along with our 2016 initiatives and plan, you can find a copy of those on our website at swn.com. 
I'd also like to point out that many of the comments during this teleconference are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties affecting outcomes, many of which are beyond our control and are discussed in more detail in the risk factors and the forward-looking statement section of our annual and quarterly filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although we believe the expectations expressed are based on reasonable assumptions, they are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results or developments may differ materially.
Now let's begin. In the 4 years that I had the privilege of being part of this great company, our teams have accomplished a great deal. Southwestern Energy clearly has premier assets, disciplined capital investment, a low-cost operating model, a highly talented workforce and a strategy built upon our formula and inspired by our core values. I truly believe in the opportunities we have in front of us and the future success of our company. 
And although I know the company well, after moving into my current role last month, I thought it important to take stock and take a fresh look. And having done that, I'm confident that our strategy is an enduring one. And today, I want to share with you several priorities as we move forward. I believe that credibility is derived from consistently delivering on commitments made. And as such, wisely investing the cash flow from our underlying assets, which is a core part of the SWN formula, will drive our decisions on investment activity when prices are high and when they are not. 
The industry is facing tremendous challenges, especially related to commodity prices. Inspired by our formula, we've taken clear and decisive actions to respond to these near-term challenges and strengthen the bridge to value-adding growth in the future. To achieve this, we are focused on building on -- our strong liquidity to further strengthen the balance sheet, to invest it in cash flow, driving further operating efficiencies, enhancing margins and optimizing the portfolio. 
Starting first with liquidity, Southwestern Energy's liquidity position is strong with $1.9 billion of undrawn capacity on our $2 billion unsecured revolver at the end of 2015. Withdrawing on that liquidity to invest in wells that have marginal economics in today's price environment does not make sense to us. We will continue to watch prices as we get further into the year and we can adjust accordingly. Craig will go into more detail of our liquidity and our financials in just a few minutes. 
Another foundational aspect of our company is that future cash flows, generated from our currently producing wells and our Midstream assets, more than exceeds our total debt obligations for the company due to our large high-quality asset base and cash flows for Midstream. Strengthening the balance sheet is a key priority for us in 2016. We do not plan to add to debt and are actively pursuing a number of options to reduce our debt levels. Additionally, we have previously disclosed we have taken decisive steps, including idling our company-owned drilling rigs and frac fleets, as we are committed to invest within cash flow based on strip pricing in 2016. We are reviewing options for potential asset sales and as we make tangible progress and have decisions in this area, we will share them with you. 
We're driving further operating efficiency, we have taken further steps to improve our margin by removing costs, resulting from reduced activity, and lower ongoing -- lowering our ongoing cost structure. As a result of this decreased activity, in January, we announced a workforce reduction with deep personal regret that impacted 40% of our SWN team. When we look at commodity prices and our current plans, there just wasn't enough activity to support that size of employee base. 
Also announced yesterday, we have recently finalized a new agreement that reduces the gathering, transportation and processing rates in our Southwest Appalachia acreage. This provides 2 major benefits for us: first, it significantly lowers the gathering rates of our existing production in this important growth asset; and second, it provides a highly competitive dry gas gathering solution for the core of our West Virginia acreage, creating an additional optionality to allocate capital to wet gas or dry gas locations, including our Utica potential as commodity prices dictate. 
These 2 actions alone have reduced our ongoing annual cost structure by more than $200 million. On the top line, we are unlocking additional value from existing wells through a series of changes we are making to drilling, completions and operating practices. The results are encouraging and our teams are working across the company to unlock additional value. 
Let me turn to Craig for a moment to discuss some of our financial highlights, followed by Paul Geiger, who will discuss some of their -- our operational highlights and the exciting first year of our ownership of our Southwest Appalachia asset.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, Southwestern and the industry are facing challenges in this commodity price environment. While these challenges are substantial and require action, we have a significant amount of liquidity with
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, Southwestern and the industry are facing challenges in this commodity price environment. While these challenges are substantial and require action, we have a significant amount of liquidity with our $2 billion unsecured revolver that does not mature until late 2018. Southwestern and much of the industry have also experienced recent credit rating downgrades by the rating agencies and expanding credit metrics as a result of this environment. We are working to address these issues on a number of fronts. However, these actions and metrics have had no impact on our unsecured revolver or other debt instruments other than a minimal increase in our expected 2016 cash interest costs at our year end 2015 debt balances. 
And assuming those year end 2015 debt balances, total cash interest cost across all of our debt instruments will increase as a result of these downgrades by about $30 million on an annual basis beginning in 2017 and will begin declining again in 2018. Our substantial liquidity position and active balance sheet management differentiates Southwestern from others. And when combined with our strong portfolio of assets, positions Southwestern well for a strong future. 
Additionally, and to emphasize a point that Bill made, these existing assets provide a substantial cash flow stream that at current commodity price forecast, not only services our debt, but pays it off over time. From a capital investment perspective, in 2015, we began exhibiting our flexibility and modified our activities to align with the current environment as we move throughout the year. Importantly, we adjusted our capital investments down to $1.8 billion. This is a reduction of 30% from our original capital guidance of $2.6 billion at the beginning of the year and $50 million below our most recent public guidance. With this reduction, we are still able to deliver record production volumes of 976 Bcfe, a 27% increase over 2014, 9% of which was organic growth. And this growth reflects our significant operating achievements across the portfolio, despite the depressed commodity price environment. 
I will now turn it over to Paul to discuss our first year of operations in our Southwest Appalachia business.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Craig, and good morning, everyone. Our first year of operations with the assets in Southwest Appalachia was an outstanding one from an operational perspective. We efficiently integrated the Southwest Appalachia asset into SWN during 2015. We le
componenttext:
Thank you, Craig, and good morning, everyone. Our first year of operations with the assets in Southwest Appalachia was an outstanding one from an operational perspective. We efficiently integrated the Southwest Appalachia asset into SWN during 2015. We leveraged the many learnings and successes from our entry into Northeast Appalachia in Pennsylvania and once again demonstrated our ability to ramp quickly and produce impressive operating results in a short period of time. 
Our Southwest Appalachia asset has exceeded our expectations in every operational aspect as compared to our acquisition model. The teams hit the ground running, delivering top quartile of drilling and completion efficiencies, a full 2 years ahead of expectations. Not only cost-efficient, this high-quality execution resulted in an over 94% success rate of placing the drilled laterals, some as long as 12,000 feet, within our targeted 12-foot thick interval of the Marcellus. This exceptional performance combined with much higher sand concentration in our completions resulted in well performance that ranges from 30% to 100% better than the wells drilled by the previous operator on the same pad. 
One outstanding pad development is our -- of this program is our [indiscernible] in the Central Panhandle. We were able to drill and complete 4 additional wells on this pad, placing 98% of the 43,000 feet of drilled lateral in our 12-foot target within the Marcellus interval. Initial production from the 9 total wells on this pad was over 100 million cubic feet equivalent per day, over half of which was liquids. 
In total, this initial year of drilling ramped production from these assets by over 65%, demonstrating the potential of this position. These factors have also increased our expectations of our core Panhandle acreage by over 50% on a per acre basis as compared to our acquisition. 
Over 200,000 of our 425,000 acres are in this core of the core for Marcellus and Utica development. Over 60% of which is held by production and over 80% of which has no obligation until 2018 or later. We accomplished a lot in our first year with this asset and we are not standing still. We are working to identify additional ways to improve returns as we continue development of this premium acreage position within a world-class producing basin. 
Across the company, 2015 included record drilling results, record well performance, material well cost savings and terrific results from our base production enhancement efforts. This performance has allowed us to build an even stronger base as we begin 2016. 
I'll now turn it back over to Bill for additional comments on 2016.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. As we close the books on 2015, I want to turn forward and look at 2016. And as I mentioned earlier, our strategy will be one that focuses on rigorous financial discipline and unlocking additional value. With our commitment to investing withi
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. As we close the books on 2015, I want to turn forward and look at 2016. And as I mentioned earlier, our strategy will be one that focuses on rigorous financial discipline and unlocking additional value. With our commitment to investing within cash flow, we issued guidance yesterday afternoon, as you know, that included a minimal amount of new activity. We are committed to investing only in projects that meet or exceed our 1.3 PVI hurdle and in this environment that can return their cash flow from divestment in this year. We are prepared for a prolonged low price environment, but we remain equipped with the flexibility and liquidity to ramp activity quickly when prices improve. With this planned activity, production is expected to decline. And while this is different from our typical E&P operational plan, we are very different -- we're in very different times from a commodity price perspective, and we believe this is the prudent path to take for now. 
Having said this, as prices recover, we have the ability to ramp up and increase activity quickly and capture the value that is associated with those improved prices. We have the core DNA in each area of our operation that will allow us to pivot from our current activity level to evaluating growth as market fundamentals normalize. 
So I want to stop here with my remarks so we can get back to the operator and -- who will explain the procedure for asking questions.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of the Doug Leggate with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of the Doug Leggate with Bank of America.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Kalei Akamine on for Doug. So couple of questions from me. Clearly, with no activity this year, NPV is being pushed out. How does this change the priority for asset sales? And can you talk to the depth of the asset market there? And is th
componenttext: This is actually Kalei Akamine on for Doug. So couple of questions from me. Clearly, with no activity this year, NPV is being pushed out. How does this change the priority for asset sales? And can you talk to the depth of the asset market there? And is there now an argument that SWN should pursue other alternatives, perhaps even an outright sale of the company?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about asset sales. And this is part of -- has been and is part of our overall plan. We're continuing to work on our joint venture with our exploration projects. We've had a number of different inquiries. I think we had originally planned
componenttext: Let me talk first about asset sales. And this is part of -- has been and is part of our overall plan. We're continuing to work on our joint venture with our exploration projects. We've had a number of different inquiries. I think we had originally planned on a large part portfolio, and what we're seeing is interest in individual pieces of that. So we'll continue to work on that. We're looking at other candidates for sale, including some of our other new venture portfolio assets. And obviously, market conditions affect the choices on the assets that we will look at, but first we want to identify opportunities to pull value forward, and that would be a priority of ours. And then we'll -- and what I want to do is really discuss those when we complete them, and we have a plan going forward that's more specific rather than speculating on the numbers. Your comment around selling the company. I mean, that's -- I'll just say we believe that the strategy we have is enduring. We believe that we're positioned with a very strong liquidity position and a very strong reserve base. We can manage and handle our debt in this environment and we are working right now on different opportunities to reduce that debt. And so looking to sell the company is not a priority, that we're working on it.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then I have a follow-up. So year-over-year, the decline is pretty large. I think 4Q to Q -- 4Q, it's about 25%. Can you talk about scenarios for 2017, 2018? Can you talk about perhaps CapEx, the whole production flat at exit levels? And CapEx
componenttext: Got it, and then I have a follow-up. So year-over-year, the decline is pretty large. I think 4Q to Q -- 4Q, it's about 25%. Can you talk about scenarios for 2017, 2018? Can you talk about perhaps CapEx, the whole production flat at exit levels? And CapEx needed to grow and perhaps would you believe the best case scenario is, in terms of returning to activity, you need gas around $3, or how are you thinking about it?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just put out our guidance on 2016, and we're -- while we can remain flexible and we have the ability to ramp up very quickly, there's a lot of conditions that can change between now and then. The simple fact that our production is declining from a
componenttext: Yes, we just put out our guidance on 2016, and we're -- while we can remain flexible and we have the ability to ramp up very quickly, there's a lot of conditions that can change between now and then. The simple fact that our production is declining from a company as large as ours is, in itself, a market signal. I think when I look at 2017 and 2018, we've got various scenarios on how we might progress, but I want to see first how the rest of this year, at least the early part of this year plays out. If you look at our current portfolio, every $0.20 -- $0.25 movement in gas, adds $200 million in cash flow to our bottom line. And with our mandate to invest within cash flow, as we see prices improve, one of the opportunities for us is to get back into and restart our drilling and completions. We would certainly prioritize our work to wells that are currently drilled but not completed, and then prioritize across the company in terms of the highest PVI projects. And how that exactly would work, I think what we want to do is let 2016 play out a little longer. I carefully used the words, "idled my rigs." I didn't shut them down and take -- or take them away and get rid of them. We have the capability to restart fairly quickly. If you look at where we would invest, certainly the economics in the Northeast tend to be the strongest economics we have. And as we have demonstrated just by our well performance over the last couple of years, it takes far fewer rigs to drill and complete wells that have growing production than our original plan. So the number of rigs, the number of wells, all of that, we are continuing the work and we'll talk more about that as we move forward.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Michael Rowe with TPH.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: I was just wondering a little bit, first question on the discretionary capital, it sounds quite low as you highlighted. But I guess, I'm curious to see if you had considered other potential uses of capital besides blowing down docks, including potentially buying back your bonds. Can you please just talk about the thought process on doing that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Craig Owen. Certainly, as Bill mentioned, we've got a lot of options. Our balance sheet, our liquidity position probably give us a number of options that we could look at, and we look at all of them. As we think about improving -- going f
componenttext: Michael, this is Craig Owen. Certainly, as Bill mentioned, we've got a lot of options. Our balance sheet, our liquidity position probably give us a number of options that we could look at, and we look at all of them. As we think about improving -- going forward, improving the balance sheet, certainly we are aware of where -- our debt trade and potential there, but we're going to look to maintaining strong liquidity, we're going to look to maintaining a strong balance sheet and trying to address options that are most valuable today. And certainly as we look to drill, or we look to complete or we look for maybe financial options, we'll consider all of those as we move through.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Okay. And then just one quick question on the asset side of things, and clearly you're very, very excited about what you're seeing in the Southwest Appalachia both from a drilling performance perspective as well as well results. So I guess, gi
componenttext: Understood. Okay. And then just one quick question on the asset side of things, and clearly you're very, very excited about what you're seeing in the Southwest Appalachia both from a drilling performance perspective as well as well results. So I guess, given what you've seen in this 35-or-so wells placed on production last year, at what point do you all think it makes sense to update the market on type curves and drilling economics out of those assets?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we get a bit more flow history -- we've got some information in some of our released information, but as we get some additional flow history in time, we will put that out. And next week, we'll issue our sort of monthly update IR book and t
componenttext: Yes, I think as we get a bit more flow history -- we've got some information in some of our released information, but as we get some additional flow history in time, we will put that out. And next week, we'll issue our sort of monthly update IR book and there'll be some information in there that would be very helpful, and we're happy to talk about it once we do that. We'll have plenty of detail in it for you.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's me, Charles Meade. I wanted to ask about -- Bill, I think you touched on some of this already, but I wonder if I could get you to elaborate on your approach to the docks as it fits with your 1.3 PVI hurdle. It would seem to me that I recogn
componenttext: I think that's me, Charles Meade. I wanted to ask about -- Bill, I think you touched on some of this already, but I wonder if I could get you to elaborate on your approach to the docks as it fits with your 1.3 PVI hurdle. It would seem to me that I recognize -- it would seem to me that -- I know most of the money is spent on completions with these wells, but it seems to me that with the drilling already done, that you'd have a lot more of those docks that would meet your 1.3 PVI hurdle. And I'm wondering if -- are you limited on -- with just working down the 20 to 30 docks this year, is that more limitation on the PVI? Or is it more a limitation on the overall cash flow? And are you biased to doing those docks in the back half of the year?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we will do is -- we're looking at it from 2 perspectives. I mean, you've got both of them. It's not only the PVI and then -- and related to the PVI, we prioritize those highest PVI across the company. That's how we allocate capital. Certainly th
componenttext: Yes, what we will do is -- we're looking at it from 2 perspectives. I mean, you've got both of them. It's not only the PVI and then -- and related to the PVI, we prioritize those highest PVI across the company. That's how we allocate capital. Certainly those in -- that we would do this year that can return our cash flow or greater in this year are up in the Q as well, and then investing within cash flow. So it's -- the economics for the portfolio of projects that we have are quite high. The investment with cash flow circuit breaker, which we've imposed, is that piece as well. We've already done some of them as we started the year. So the benefit of that production can roll in, but we'll keep monitoring that. And as we go forward, again, should we see a change in price and should we elect to put that money to work in either drilling or completions or any kind of project, we'll allocate them based off of those -- that criteria.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And this -- I'm following up on the other comment you made earlier, but you talked about your wells in the Northeast. I wanted to drill down a bit on that because it was a really helpful table that you guys put in your press release, but it looked
componenttext: Got it. And this -- I'm following up on the other comment you made earlier, but you talked about your wells in the Northeast. I wanted to drill down a bit on that because it was a really helpful table that you guys put in your press release, but it looked to me like your best capital efficiency would actually be in Southwest Appalachia, and maybe that's part of what you meant by the Northeast. But I recognize it's not just about volumes, it's about revenue. And so I wondered, is that the right conclusion that the Southwest Appalachia is where you'd put that money to work? And am I right that this is about -- I know there's a lot of sense -- about a year's worth of docks that you have?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have about 100 docks in our total inventory. And to be really clear, we don't -- we have -- docks that we have an inventory typically are only in the docks that are required to keep the sort of machine running efficiently. We don't drill wells and hold
componenttext: We have about 100 docks in our total inventory. And to be really clear, we don't -- we have -- docks that we have an inventory typically are only in the docks that are required to keep the sort of machine running efficiently. We don't drill wells and hold them, and then hope for prices to recover someday in the future. That's not part of our DNA. When I mentioned Northeast I was referring to the entire Northeast, and apologies for that. That's both Northeast and Southwest. And as you look at either of those areas, you dissect further down and into the individual acreage or the individual areas of those acreage, you also got the wet versus dry dynamic in Southwest Appalachia. And so again, we don't look at averages across different plays. We go project by project, well by well, whatever it happens to be and prioritize them that way.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify the last bit on the docks, is your current plan to have any remaining docks as you roll into 2016?
componenttext: Just to clarify the last bit on the docks, is your current plan to have any remaining docks as you roll into 2016?
