componenttextpreview: I think -- good morning. Thanks for the question. I think, initially, we are looking at these 10,000, and we have some actually that are up to 12,000 foot in length. We want to -- we successfully have been able to drill and complete them and bring them on
componenttext: I think -- good morning. Thanks for the question. I think, initially, we are looking at these 10,000, and we have some actually that are up to 12,000 foot in length. We want to -- we successfully have been able to drill and complete them and bring them online. We want to do some operating and flow testing and get some production history under our belt to make sure that from a stage contribution perspective as well as the overall well perspective that our theory that it makes sense to do those longer laterals is, in fact, true. Once we get a little production history behind us, then we can know. We've done economics back and forth to make sure that we're comparing apples-to-apples in wells. If we -- our models are all built on 7,500-foot lateral lengths. And so there's an opportunity to improve efficiency, and capital efficiency in that program should be -- actually be the length that we choose.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one last one, if I could. Obviously, you've got a great location status out there, now after the -- that acquisition and everything that you guys have. What's your thoughts looking at West Virginia, thinking about drilling some Utica
componenttext: Got it. And then just one last one, if I could. Obviously, you've got a great location status out there, now after the -- that acquisition and everything that you guys have. What's your thoughts looking at West Virginia, thinking about drilling some Utica there? Is it more just waiting on takeaway? Or I guess maybe a better way to say that is just your thoughts -- when you start to ramp up the drilling plan, and again, that's if not where or when, thoughts about getting after Marcellus versus Utica.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll let Paul talk a little bit about it in a second. But a quick couple of factors out on the table. One, when we first went into the -- to West Virginia, our initial plans were to drill Utica wells in -- beginning in 2018 and begin to ramp that pro
componenttext: Yes. I'll let Paul talk a little bit about it in a second. But a quick couple of factors out on the table. One, when we first went into the -- to West Virginia, our initial plans were to drill Utica wells in -- beginning in 2018 and begin to ramp that program at that time. You'll know that we've drilled a Utica well in a portion of our acreage. We have not completed it yet. And as we've ranked capital projects this year and prioritized them, we're keeping that one in mind on when we've actually completed. We have some additional Utica wells planned for other portions of our acreage that are set in the queue. And I think a lot of it really depends on where gas prices go, where liquids prices go and the balance between wet and dry Marcellus and Utica. And then we operate it as a portfolio, so then you go up and look in the Northeast of Pennsylvania and the dry gas Marcellus area as well. So too early to tell in specific drilling schedule, but we have advanced the process from 2018 to sooner, just on a general basis because we've already made that one well test. The other thing that we're excited about is that we have for the area where we would put down the next Utica well series. When we get to that point, we have a dry gas solution in hand and we're -- which would enable us to have that optionality to go in any of the particular areas we want to drill.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is Paul. I think that covers it. When you look at our position, the offset [ph] industry activity continues to prove that up as an extremely viable position and some premium acreage within the Utica. As we go forward into our investment op
componenttext: I think -- this is Paul. I think that covers it. When you look at our position, the offset [ph] industry activity continues to prove that up as an extremely viable position and some premium acreage within the Utica. As we go forward into our investment opportunities from a drilling complete standpoint with the direction of living within cash flow, certainly, wet Marcellus and Utica in that area are both on the table and are premium within our portfolio and will let, as we go through pricing at the time and specifically NGL pricing at the time, just make that determination of where our best returns can be had between the wet Marcellus drilling or the dry Marcellus or the dry Utica within that area.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Michael Rowe with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Michael Rowe with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on hedging. You've taken some initial steps to lock in basis at various sales points the rest of '16. I was wondering if you could just talk to the practicality of layering on additional basis hedges in Appalachia to potentially prot
componenttext: Just a quick question on hedging. You've taken some initial steps to lock in basis at various sales points the rest of '16. I was wondering if you could just talk to the practicality of layering on additional basis hedges in Appalachia to potentially protect a significant amount of your production heading into 2017. Just thinking about protecting against implications of potential pipeline buildout delays.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. This is Randy Curry. Thanks for the question. A little color in context on the basis positions that we have put on. Those have been as a result of some physical sales and physical basis positions. We do remain confident in our outlook of an
componenttext: Yes, Michael. This is Randy Curry. Thanks for the question. A little color in context on the basis positions that we have put on. Those have been as a result of some physical sales and physical basis positions. We do remain confident in our outlook of an improving basis position out there, particularly in '16. You'd look at some of the recent contraction in the M2 basis as little as November of last year. That was -- the May contract was trading at about $1.15 back. And you look at it today, and we're at about in the $0.60 to $0.70 back range. So there's some opportunities that are presenting themselves out there that we think are significant improvements over the past, and we'll continue to evaluate those.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just for my final question, you all accrued $122 million of capital spending in the first quarter, but the cash spending from the cash flow statement was $196 million. So I was just wondering, as the year progresses, should we expect that g
componenttext: Okay. And then just for my final question, you all accrued $122 million of capital spending in the first quarter, but the cash spending from the cash flow statement was $196 million. So I was just wondering, as the year progresses, should we expect that gap between cash and accrual CapEx to shrink? Or how should we be modeling that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This -- Michael, this is Craig. Thanks for the question. I think in general, certainly, we have timing impacts of swings on what it does to a GAAP cash flow statement. But in general, you'll see us at or underneath cash flow levels, to the extent we'
componenttext: Yes. This -- Michael, this is Craig. Thanks for the question. I think in general, certainly, we have timing impacts of swings on what it does to a GAAP cash flow statement. But in general, you'll see us at or underneath cash flow levels, to the extent we're thinking about strip right now, full -- as [indiscernible] our plan we laid out in February. We'll invest within cash flow and not add to the balance sheet. So all that is dictated on what price is, and we'll kind of continue evaluating that as we move forward throughout the rest of the year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could go back to one of the earlier questions but maybe from a slightly different angle. Can you -- we're looking at -- the natural gas strip for the back half of '16, I'm showing is $2.55, call it. Can you give us an idea which of your operating-s m
componenttext: If I could go back to one of the earlier questions but maybe from a slightly different angle. Can you -- we're looking at -- the natural gas strip for the back half of '16, I'm showing is $2.55, call it. Can you give us an idea which of your operating-s meets your -- which of your operating areas meet that 1.3 PVI hurdle at $2.55? And I know that you're looking for something [indiscernible] as well. But could you give us an idea where you cleared that hurdle and perhaps a ranking of what's at the top right now?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's -- first of all, there's a kind of a multiyear review that you take on well economics. So if it's $2.55 today, that's a data point. That same $2.55 today heads towards $3 in '17 and '18 or beyond and such wells are paid out over more tha
componenttext: Yes, I think it's -- first of all, there's a kind of a multiyear review that you take on well economics. So if it's $2.55 today, that's a data point. That same $2.55 today heads towards $3 in '17 and '18 or beyond and such wells are paid out over more than 1 year. Based on what I've just said, all of our areas, with the exception of Fayetteville, are economic. And it gets back to a question of investing within cash flow. And as we see that cash flow be assured, then we can increase that investment. And I think we've talked about before, our -- if you look at the highest capital-efficient wells that we have, and we -- and I'm using averages here. So we've had some stellar wells in Fayetteville that have exceeded our expectations even this year. But on average, my highest capital-efficient areas will be the Northeast, and it will depend really on the fact that we now have NGLs as a part of this. And so as you look at NGL pricing and gas pricing. But basically, West Virginia and Pennsylvania both would be in the top of that priority list. The other thing that we would do is look at our dock inventory. And we've got somewhere less than 100 of those that -- or excuse me, just over 100 of those that we would put in the front of the line because they bring cash flow back cyclically because they're already drilled so as you're looking at prioritization.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that makes sense. And then if we could drill in -- drill down a bit on the -- some of the compression or gathering optimization you've done, that looks like a big win for you guys in the quarter. I'm curious, is that -- was that all from one specifi
componenttext: Well, that makes sense. And then if we could drill in -- drill down a bit on the -- some of the compression or gathering optimization you've done, that looks like a big win for you guys in the quarter. I'm curious, is that -- was that all from one specific area? Or can you tell, was that mostly Fayetteville or was that mostly Northwest or Northeast Appalachia? Is there any breakdown there?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the highest impact area, our benefit area would have come from Northeast Pennsylvania and Susquehanna and Bradford Counties, and it's part of our ongoing agreement with our gatherers to -- as we move through time to get that work completed. And so ye
componenttext: Yes, the highest impact area, our benefit area would have come from Northeast Pennsylvania and Susquehanna and Bradford Counties, and it's part of our ongoing agreement with our gatherers to -- as we move through time to get that work completed. And so yes, it was a big win for us absolutely. The other opportunity was in Southwest Appalachia with Williams. And then we're continuously looking in the Fayetteville at optimizing our compression fleet. We have quite a bit of compression in Fayetteville across a very large gathering system but optimizing that and looking at any kind of constraints. But your specific question around where the biggest benefit was came from our Northeast operations, which is around compression would be up there. In addition, just I'll point out because we talked about this before, our renegotiations with Williams and our bright new deal we have with them contributes to that as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Subash Chandra with Guggenheim Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Subash Chandra with Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say that you have to deal with the '18 maturities before -- in any gas price environment is a -- there's a view towards more drilling?
componenttext: Is it fair to say that you have to deal with the '18 maturities before -- in any gas price environment is a -- there's a view towards more drilling?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me -- I think what I -- how I would characterize this, and again, I'm not going to go into a lot of detail on the details of what we're doing. But one of the things that I believe strongly in is you cultivate options to manage your business and
componenttext: Well, let me -- I think what I -- how I would characterize this, and again, I'm not going to go into a lot of detail on the details of what we're doing. But one of the things that I believe strongly in is you cultivate options to manage your business and manage through any kind of -- if you're connected to the commodity price environment, you manage through that. And cultivating those options, then you look at, well, when do you need to do things? I have 2018 maturities and from a calendar year perspective, it's 2 years away. From a priority perspective of managing and being proactive around it, I want to go -- I want to work on that, and it's a priority of ours to do that. So as -- the more proactive you can be, the more options you get to retain and the more you get to use. So that's really the underlying strategy of it. And it's -- we're not in a place where we have to go do one thing or another, and that's why we're continuing to work a portfolio of options but have come out very clearly that it's a priority. We're focused on it, and we're going to manage that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my second question is I think you implied that you were benefiting from the capacity release market. Any sort of sense on what sort of pricing there is and sort of generalities up there, what you can [indiscernible] for?
componenttext: Okay. And my second question is I think you implied that you were benefiting from the capacity release market. Any sort of sense on what sort of pricing there is and sort of generalities up there, what you can [indiscernible] for?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Subash. This is Randy again. Without getting to a lot of specifics, our Northeast portfolio, as Paul alluded to earlier, is made up of multiple transportation agreements to really multiple markets, down to the Gulf, to the Northeast, across to the Mi
componenttext: Yes, Subash. This is Randy again. Without getting to a lot of specifics, our Northeast portfolio, as Paul alluded to earlier, is made up of multiple transportation agreements to really multiple markets, down to the Gulf, to the Northeast, across to the Midwest, with varying transport rates and commitments. And in the first quarter, we did release about 80,000 a day, and it allowed us to generate some significant value over and above the inherent demand charges. So we can -- we could talk some more specifics, but generally speaking, about 80,000 to 90,000 a day is what we put together as a package in multiple agreements out of the area.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you -- just a couple of comments around it. There's a lot of challenges out there in the capacity world, and some people have more than they need, some people have less than they need. And our Northeast Appalachia takeaway is a great example where
componenttext: And if you -- just a couple of comments around it. There's a lot of challenges out there in the capacity world, and some people have more than they need, some people have less than they need. And our Northeast Appalachia takeaway is a great example where our portfolio of transport is really an asset to us. It's not -- I wouldn't even call it a liability. And what do I mean by that? You've seen our investor pack. We've got -- and we actually lay out the reservation charges and the rates that we pay. We have the volumes. I've got 1.3 billion a day of firm capacity out of there. And as you move through a very short period of time, we have the opportunity even today to release some of this. We have the opportunity to -- it's made up of so many tranches of capacity that we can release if we want to, we can hold on to it if we want to, we can move gas through it if we want to. It's a great optionality, and it's -- it doesn't hold us hostage or handcuffed to having to drill wells or do things that are not economic when you have so much flexibility around this. So we're pretty excited about the strategy that we have a building firm. This particular firm's at $0.32, $0.33, which is well, well into any kind of market condition. So we do view this as a strategic strength for us.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Three questions on production. With the production surprising a bit to the upside versus your guidance and really ahead of really starting to see the impact of 0 rigs, has your view of your natural decline rate changed, particularly in the Fayetteville? O
componenttext: Three questions on production. With the production surprising a bit to the upside versus your guidance and really ahead of really starting to see the impact of 0 rigs, has your view of your natural decline rate changed, particularly in the Fayetteville? Or do you view this beat more as timing or initial well productivity?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a couple of things at play here, and we're early into the year. The teams did such a terrific job last year of placing wells, of drilling wells. We've had such significant advancements in our understanding of how to place them, sand loadin
componenttext: I think there's a couple of things at play here, and we're early into the year. The teams did such a terrific job last year of placing wells, of drilling wells. We've had such significant advancements in our understanding of how to place them, sand loading, all the things we've always talked about. So it set us up well here. And then in addition to that, our guys have been working tirelessly, de-bottlenecking, looking at how we're flowing them [indiscernible] a number of aspects that Paul already talked about. So we're optimistic in what we're seeing, and it backs up some of the statements that we've made or facts that our wells are actually, at least from a performance standpoint when we bring them online, doing much better. And it's not a manipulated flow. It's just -- it's how they flow and how we've optimized that flow. I think it's probably early to tell whether we've got the number pegged exactly right on percentages. And we're going to continue to watch that, and I'll be very transparent with you when we kind of get a feel for that. When you're not adding a ton of wells in a year, it's a different flow dynamic. And so as we work -- as we watch this, if we need to change it, we'll tell you. But -- and I'd just say, I just need a little more time to look at it.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then my second question's with regards to the deleveraging effort. I know you don't want to be too specific on some of the individual items you're pursuing. But I guess, how should we think about where you want to get your net debt to EB
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then my second question's with regards to the deleveraging effort. I know you don't want to be too specific on some of the individual items you're pursuing. But I guess, how should we think about where you want to get your net debt to EBITDA? Assuming -- if we're going to assume $3 gas with what you may already have that you don't want to be specific on, can you kind of talk to where you think that leverage would be if that were all -- were to close? And then where equity issuance stands in the need to achieve your objectives?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Brian, it's Craig. I think we've got just the whole industry, and we're not immune to it. We've got such a long ways to go to get to certain debt to EBITDA or leverage target from a leverage ratio or anything else. But as we indicated in February, we
componenttext: Hey, Brian, it's Craig. I think we've got just the whole industry, and we're not immune to it. We've got such a long ways to go to get to certain debt to EBITDA or leverage target from a leverage ratio or anything else. But as we indicated in February, we're going to continue to work on the '18 maturities, maintaining liquidity and deleveraging. Certainly, in a $3 world or whatever the strip gives us, we look to improve that significantly from where we are. But I don't think we're ready to kind of state a specific target that we're driving towards in any time frame.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in my view on equity, I'm a publicly traded company. So all options, and I've talked a little bit about this before and even on the road, we've got to cultivate all options. And obviously, we've talked about asset sales and all these different things.
componenttext: And in my view on equity, I'm a publicly traded company. So all options, and I've talked a little bit about this before and even on the road, we've got to cultivate all options. And obviously, we've talked about asset sales and all these different things. But equity is an option, and it's an option for any publicly traded company. And so we analyze it in the same way we analyze the other items that we're working on. And as we work through -- I believe that as we move through this whole process and again, we're very deliberate and focused on doing it, it's made up of a number of pieces. And so as we pull it together, we'll talk about it. But your specific question, is it on the table? It sure is because I'm a publicly traded company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Abbott in -- calling in on behalf of Doug Leggate. Just want to go back to the -- I had 2 questions on your drilling location slide, your presentation, just want to go back to that. First, for your locations at $3 Henry Hub, could you provide
componenttext: This is John Abbott in -- calling in on behalf of Doug Leggate. Just want to go back to the -- I had 2 questions on your drilling location slide, your presentation, just want to go back to that. First, for your locations at $3 Henry Hub, could you provide an update as far as returns for the Fayetteville, Northeast Appalachian, Southwest Appalachian? And then second, could you provide a little bit more color on the breakout of locations to Southwest Appalachia between rich gas and more lean gas opportunities?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, John. This is Craig. I'll just kind of briefly on the locations and returns. Certainly, we look at that, and as we think about economic locations, as you know, our hurdle rate is in terms of PVI. So 1.3 PVI at a minimum at $3, and that's where -- wer
componenttext: Hey, John. This is Craig. I'll just kind of briefly on the locations and returns. Certainly, we look at that, and as we think about economic locations, as you know, our hurdle rate is in terms of PVI. So 1.3 PVI at a minimum at $3, and that's where -- were translated into those location levels. So yes, as it -- obviously as you move up, that PVI increases, generally 1.3 for a shale well is in the high teens on a return perspective. So we haven't broken out further on higher prices and what those PVIs turn into or returns, rather.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you provide a little color in terms of the breakout of locations for Southwest Appalachia between more rich gas and dry gas opportunities?
componenttext: And then can you provide a little color in terms of the breakout of locations for Southwest Appalachia between more rich gas and dry gas opportunities?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You -- in the sort of Marcellus, probably half those are wet Marcellus, half those are dry Marcellus. And then if I look at the balance between wet or between Marcellus and Utica, about half the locations are Utica and half the locations are Marcellu
componenttext: Yes. You -- in the sort of Marcellus, probably half those are wet Marcellus, half those are dry Marcellus. And then if I look at the balance between wet or between Marcellus and Utica, about half the locations are Utica and half the locations are Marcellus. So I guess backing up the math a little, you'd look at the total, half of them are Utica, 1/4 of them are wet, 1/4 of them are dry Marcellus.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about the ability of Fayetteville gas to move to Gulf Coast markets? Historically, it is largely moved to the North as I understand it, and the opportunities would seem to be pretty robust over the next 24 months to petrochemical plants and LNG facilities.

componenttext: Yes, I'll let Randy talk to you about it, may put a little color on this. But the Fayetteville gas has largely moved to the Gulf Coast and Southeast [indiscernible], and we've got significant capacity that -- available to us, and it's actually well-positioned. So I mean, let Randy talk a little bit about it.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Bob, I would just add that Bill commented on some of the optimism we've got and the signposts that are looking at some increasing demand. And a lot of that demand is manifesting itself in the Gulf Coast. And as Bill stated, our Fayetteville transport portfolio is largely oriented to the Gulf and where most of our disposition has always and we expect it to be in the future as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: My first question was Slide 13. You mentioned this company-owned assets can ramp up quickly as prices recover. Slide 18 shows $2.35 nat gas as the 2016 guidance benchmark. And today, you suggest there's some optimism for future prices. My questions are, what price range for what duration is likely required for an increase in investment? And once the investment decision's been made, how quickly can a productive effect become evident?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, for every $0.25 in gas price movement, there's $185 million of cash flow that, that generates. When I look at drilling and completing and obviously, some ducts before you do some of the other things, you've got -- a rig in West Virginia is about $100
componenttext: Yes, for every $0.25 in gas price movement, there's $185 million of cash flow that, that generates. When I look at drilling and completing and obviously, some ducts before you do some of the other things, you've got -- a rig in West Virginia is about $100 million, a rig in Northeast Pennsylvania is probably $180 million. And so for every $0.25 you can begin putting, if we chose to do that, put a rig, 1 to 2 rigs on. And if you look at strip going in, let's say we based our budget off $2.35 and you got a $0.50 improvement, you could put 2 or 3 rigs back in to work if that's what we chose to do and be within cash flow, certainly again doing ducts first, and that would have an impact on decline rates in the year and going forward.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Referring to the longer lateral commentary this morning. I just want to make sure I understood this. Do the longer laterals promise to provide or potentially promise to provide flatter initial declines than the tight curves that you provide in the appendix to the current company presentation?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeffrey, this is Paul Geiger. We believe so. It has to do with some of the conservatism you've seen in the production and the rest of that. As we -- certainly it's the most economic thing to do on paper, right? From a fixed and variable cost and benefit s
componenttext: Jeffrey, this is Paul Geiger. We believe so. It has to do with some of the conservatism you've seen in the production and the rest of that. As we -- certainly it's the most economic thing to do on paper, right? From a fixed and variable cost and benefit standpoint is to push those laterals out as long as you think you can get incremental economic returns. So that's on paper. And so what we've demonstrated a few of those operationally and been able to get out and not only drill but complete those and drill those out, bring them on to production. And so we're watching those from a decline standpoint. There's some -- there was some industry concern about are you able to effectively produce the tail end of that lateral? We believe we are through a various combination of things, including dissolvable plugs, flow-through plugs, things like that. We think we're getting good contribution there. But as you recall from our earlier comments regarding overall productive strategy, the ability to have tight landing zone control, the ability to have increased sand on completions and the ability to have managed drawdown were big factors, we believe, to outperformance this from a well standpoint. So the longer laterals, we believe, were able to produce those at a managed rate and get improved EURs. But then also in our liquids rich Marcellus area has also increased liquids recovery versus offset shorter laterals or wells with higher drawdown. And so as we do see those continue to outperform curve, yes, sir, that potentially has impact on our forward projections for those well type curves.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: You should think about it this way. That capital is front-end loaded and that makes the most sense from a number of perspectives, both in terms of the ramping down and then also getting the full benefit of the cash flow that's generated from it as quickly as you can. And you will see that taper off. And the real answer is, we will not be adding to any kind of cash flow deficit by investing, so you watch cash flow and you watch capital.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just along the same lines there. You -- at least relative to EBITDA minus CapEx, you were free cash flow positive during the quarter. What's your cash flow outlook for the remainder of the year at strip prices? Do you expect to continue to be free cash flow positive? And if so, what does that mean in terms of organic deleveraging versus some of the kind of more proactive alternatives you're evaluating?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're going to watch that, obviously. If we can put money to -- back to work and we agree that, that's something that we need to do and we talk to our board about it, then that's an option for sure. But we -- I want to take a look at where gas prices go. The important piece of it is which -- whatever decision we make with that, we're ready to implement it. One of the benefits of having the vertical integration that we have, we've kind of talked a little bit about that before, and retaining the DNA for both our drilling company and our completion company inside the business, we can get back to work very quickly.

componenttext: Yes. Paul will talk a little detail about this, but let me just tell you that we're going to look at it on a per lateral foot basis. We're going to make sure that the decision to drill a long lateral versus 2 shorts is a straight-up economic comparison. And that economics is EUR, flow rates, all of that and investment. And so, yes, they -- we analyze that very, very specifically. We actually have some benchmarks internally that we use to say that a 12,000-foot lateral has to perform at this level greater than 2 6,000-foot [ph] for it to make sense. And that's the analysis we're doing. But yes, we don't -- making it up on length is not something we would do.

componenttext: That's correct, Marshall. This is Paul. Regarding those longer laterals, we've got a few of those, so we're early in the testing stage. But to your question specifically, yes, on a EUR per foot basis, at this point, we've got 10% to 25% improvement versus offset, and so we're encouraged about that.

componenttextpreview: The trend that we had going for us when we have rigs in play was -- is we went from an early entry into West Virginia and kind of trying to find our way to pacesetter. And what I mean by that is best-in-class or at the top of the class performance on a co
componenttext: The trend that we had going for us when we have rigs in play was -- is we went from an early entry into West Virginia and kind of trying to find our way to pacesetter. And what I mean by that is best-in-class or at the top of the class performance on a cost per lateral foot. And we did that with some extraordinary drilling performance out of our company-owned drilling teams and our rigs, placing these laterals 100% or nearly 100% in zone, which helped boost the performance. And so it's driven costs down considerably.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Paul. Where we left off in the drilling program, like Bill had mentioned, we expected in the early time of West Virginia acquisition a year ago to move ourselves to top quartile drilling complete performance on a dollars per foot basis over a
componenttext: Yes, this is Paul. Where we left off in the drilling program, like Bill had mentioned, we expected in the early time of West Virginia acquisition a year ago to move ourselves to top quartile drilling complete performance on a dollars per foot basis over a couple of years. We did that by midyear last year. And as we left off at the end of the '15 program, we're driving those below $1,000 a foot. And so that we consider to be very cost competitive in the Marcellus. We don't have enough data points to give hard numbers in the Utica. You can see some of those in our expectations, and they're consistent with what the industry calls a development cost of the Utica well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thanks for all the questions and the dialogue, and we look forward to answering any that didn't get answered when we see you in person.As you've heard, we're driving forward on our plans we shared with you earlier in the year, a
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thanks for all the questions and the dialogue, and we look forward to answering any that didn't get answered when we see you in person.
As you've heard, we're driving forward on our plans we shared with you earlier in the year, and we've delivered strong results in a short period of time. And I think the release we put out yesterday bears that out. And as I said previously, I really believe that credibility comes from consistent delivering on the commitments that we've made. And I can tell you that we've got a firm resolve to build on that credibility and lay out plans, execute them, share those results with you and be as transparent as we can about that. We have no doubt that this strategic initiatives that we are pursuing this year and going forward are setting us up to generate significant value for our shareholders going forward. And whether it's the quality of the assets, the steps we're taking to strengthen the balance sheet, the improving macro indicators, the reasons to be excited about Southwestern Energy as an investment, I think, are strong and very apparent and getting even stronger as we move forward through 2016.
So we are not hunkered down. We are powering and driving through these commodity price environments. The results show it when every member of our team is out trying to drive margin improvements and are very focused on getting more out of the assets that we have. And we're excited about the future that we have in front of us and are looking forward to talking with you again about these accomplishments as we continue to generate them. And until then, we want to thank you for being here with us today, and I hope you have a great weekend.
So thanks a lot.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
