componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe just a follow-up to that or my second question. Just, Bill, for the Midstream maybe, just could you talk about just midstream takeaways as it pertains down to that Southwest area? I know again you guys have built up down there, but I'm just wondering I guess as you get a little bit further down into West Virginia, any plans to build that out? Or just if you can talk about sort of the infrastructure around that Southwest Appalachia area?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Randy can talk a little bit of detail on infrastructure but as we said before, we took on some early transportation commitments and some gathering commitments as we did the acquisition. We've added to that portfolio through fixed sales where the buye
componenttext: Yes, Randy can talk a little bit of detail on infrastructure but as we said before, we took on some early transportation commitments and some gathering commitments as we did the acquisition. We've added to that portfolio through fixed sales where the buyer has to transport or transport of our own. We can grow this asset over the next 3 years at about 35% per year and not have run into constraints associated with takeaway. Gathering the areas where we will drill have existing gathering agreements and gathering infrastructure in place. And it's really a model for what we do everywhere. The time from spud all the way to sales needs to include is there available capacity, is there available takeaway, is there available gathering processing, and we assure ourselves that we have that route all the way to the markets before we drill. But Randy's got some probably some further details on the latest activity that we've been doing.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. I think the only thing I'd add to your comments are on the gathering side, as Bill mentioned, we do feel confident in the existing service providers and their ability to add needed infrastructure where we do need it and the time we need it.
componenttext: Thanks, Bill. I think the only thing I'd add to your comments are on the gathering side, as Bill mentioned, we do feel confident in the existing service providers and their ability to add needed infrastructure where we do need it and the time we need it. And then on the export capacity, the interstate capacity out of the region, again, we don't anticipate having any constraints when we get to levels that are beyond currently contracted levels on our portfolio. We still have a good excess position forecasted right now. And just with the market where it is and the anticipated buildout of that area in '17 and '18, respectively, we feel very confident in being able to get what we need out of there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the benefits of the renegotiation of the Williams deal and we brought to the table was opportunity for them to be our gatherer for dry Utica gas in the same region, and that's provided us quite a bit of flexibility. Our gatherers do a great job, ar
componenttext: One of the benefits of the renegotiation of the Williams deal and we brought to the table was opportunity for them to be our gatherer for dry Utica gas in the same region, and that's provided us quite a bit of flexibility. Our gatherers do a great job, are confident that we contract there to enable us, for example, even the Utica well that Jack mentioned. We will be able to test that well in a wet gas system for a while just to -- because it's available and a great support we get out of our gatherers. So as we test there and then test other areas that dry gas gathering system for Utica gets built out and we just see a seamless progression from testing through production.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last if I could quickly, maybe for Craig, just that 700 you said of DNC for CapEx for '17, was that -- is that flat year-over-year? Or flat exit to exit?
componenttext: And just one last if I could quickly, maybe for Craig, just that 700 you said of DNC for CapEx for '17, was that -- is that flat year-over-year? Or flat exit to exit?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we've moved to, this is Bill again, what we've moved to is, prior to our guidance, was flat exit to exit. Now that is we believe that we will have a flat total production all in for '17 based off that number. And so as prices move around and we do ou
componenttext: What we've moved to, this is Bill again, what we've moved to is, prior to our guidance, was flat exit to exit. Now that is we believe that we will have a flat total production all in for '17 based off that number. And so as prices move around and we do our budgets, the opportunity, gas prices, $0.25, our gas price moves to cash flow $185 million. And so the opportunity to kind of evaluate that as we go forward is what we are up to now. But we won't do -- we'll do more work on our budget for '17 later this year. There's an improvement.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure it feels good for you all to get back to drilling. But I want to pick up on that last thread which falls upon your comments from the -- from your prepared remarks. Is the -- 2 questions in this, is the $700 million that you referred to, is that j
componenttext: I'm sure it feels good for you all to get back to drilling. But I want to pick up on that last thread which falls upon your comments from the -- from your prepared remarks. Is the -- 2 questions in this, is the $700 million that you referred to, is that just DNC CapEx? Or is that total CapEx? And then if you could drill in a little bit more on the comment of being flat year-over-year, the way I look at it, if you're going to be flat year-over-year, you probably have to resume growth quarter-over-quarter, sequential growth, sometime in early 2017, is that the right read on that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: The total capital number that I talk about, and we do -- internally, we look at it this way, that is all in, so that's got CI&E in it, as well as the activity capital that makes it happen. Our previous guidance was that for about that much capital, again,
componenttext: The total capital number that I talk about, and we do -- internally, we look at it this way, that is all in, so that's got CI&E in it, as well as the activity capital that makes it happen. Our previous guidance was that for about that much capital, again, all in, we could achieve a year-end '16 to year-end '17, you'd end up in the same where you started but that had a decline built into it because it's a U-shaped kind of production profile. With this -- with us reinitiating drilling and completions and remember, we're doing a number of our docks, and we're going to talk about that later, some of our docks and drilling new wells, we accelerate that progression. Or another way to look at it, you flatten out the trough of decline. So yes, you're going to have -- we have to turn it. We'll turn it early in the year probably rather than waiting until some time mid- to late year to do that. And so we wanted to kind of compare something that we put out before which was at about $700 million, instead of it being exit-to-exit is now full year-on-full year flat. And so you are correct, as we enter the second half of next year, you get on that growth ramp, assuming that we, again, assuming that's the number. We haven't done our capital budget and well, we guided on that before so we just wanted to make it -- connect the dots for you.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then if I could ask another question about what you're seeing in pricing in your local price points up in Appalachia. Depending on which price point you look at, you could make a case that there's been a Henry hub rally but there hasn't been mu
componenttext: Right. And then if I could ask another question about what you're seeing in pricing in your local price points up in Appalachia. Depending on which price point you look at, you could make a case that there's been a Henry hub rally but there hasn't been much of a rally up in Appalachia. Is -- how do you guys see that progressing in your local pricing in the back half of the year? And are there any particular sensitivities we should be thinking about with respect to that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Randy, I'll take that one. We have seen an improvement in basis. We saw it, obviously, in the first quarter with prices falling. We saw basis come in. And then we've seen actually as prices have risen, we haven't seen necessarily the same wid
componenttext: Yes, this is Randy, I'll take that one. We have seen an improvement in basis. We saw it, obviously, in the first quarter with prices falling. We saw basis come in. And then we've seen actually as prices have risen, we haven't seen necessarily the same widening. We still have a view that we'll have an improving basis over time in Southwest Appalachia have a bias that the incremental capacity that's coming on, as I mentioned earlier, particularly in '17 and '18, right now, we've got that at around 13 Bcf between the 2 years will be adequate to continue to show some improvement and differentials over that time frame.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: We've done, and what we'll do is probably talk about a couple of things. We both drilled wells on paper and we're completing wells on paper. And I'm going to have Jack talk to you about what we found in the studies. But certainly, position our landing zone frac loads all that will come into play, but let me get Jack to give you some specifics.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. We went through, during the time we've been not drilling, we've gone through and we've reviewed all the drilling wells that we have done, especially recently, we've done a lot of collaboration within our company and have shared a lot of i
componenttext: Thank you, Bill. We went through, during the time we've been not drilling, we've gone through and we've reviewed all the drilling wells that we have done, especially recently, we've done a lot of collaboration within our company and have shared a lot of ideas, things that have worked that in West Virginia last year are now being utilized in Appalachia. But one, we've come up with ideas one thing on this well we just recently drilled. We used a rotary steerable in Northeast PA which we use regularly in Southwest Appalachia last year. That's one of the reasons we were able to immediately get back on curve. Everything didn't go perfect on that well, but yet we still were right on pace with what we did in the past. And we've also looked at every one of our completions that are basically have gone to engineered completions as far as looking at how much is in the zone, completing it, completing the work that sim zone and we have spent a lot of time looking at how we could -- more sand placement. We've gone that pretty much across the way. Our flowback techniques of our wells, we've evaluated what has worked best and what is not worked so well, and we're going to implement those. But we -- that has been a focus for the last 6 months and we're already seeing results of it on our very first well with TV Winstead.

componenttext: So when I think about how you're allocating capital with a big in Northeast Marcellus emphasis, I'm trying to reconcile that with the PV 10 values or reserve for it, and it seems to rank say, Bill, the highest in Northeast Marcellus, second or third. Is it because the F&Ds are just so much better in Northeast Marcellus that you earn your PVI threshold there versus Fayetteville?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So when I think of the Fayetteville then, your leverage is in location is in the Fayetteville where as if we look at the price stack, you don't have that much leverage in terms of location in Northeast Marcellus, how do you think about -- so what are the gating factors to really ramping up in the Fayetteville? And why not? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Craig. I think the big biggest gating factor, as Bill mentioned, certainly, we're going to look at economics. Northeast, no secret to get bigger wells certainly Fayetteville continues to improve and we've got some things that we continue to test i
componenttext: This is Craig. I think the big biggest gating factor, as Bill mentioned, certainly, we're going to look at economics. Northeast, no secret to get bigger wells certainly Fayetteville continues to improve and we've got some things that we continue to test in the second half of this year. But the pricing, that's one component, the size of the well. And then just how we're driving cost through the system. And Randy mentioned earlier, one thing you didn't specifically reference, but West Virginia, as we get into the Southwest Appalachia, we have that liquids profile coming in as well that certainly helps the economics and we've seen what pricing has done this year so far as well. We're going to be improved on the NGL side.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up just on the CapEx is, so $700 million all in, including C&I for flat year-over-year, this might be an unfair question, but is there a way to sort of illustrate for every 100 million more in CapEx what kind of growth you might get?
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up just on the CapEx is, so $700 million all in, including C&I for flat year-over-year, this might be an unfair question, but is there a way to sort of illustrate for every 100 million more in CapEx what kind of growth you might get?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not yet, but what we -- as we put together our budget later this year, we'll be able to talk about that. If you look at our guidance from last time, we've got sort of indicative numbers on production per rig, making some assumptions on where they are and
componenttext: Not yet, but what we -- as we put together our budget later this year, we'll be able to talk about that. If you look at our guidance from last time, we've got sort of indicative numbers on production per rig, making some assumptions on where they are and the speed at the time and we're back to kind of that speed or better so if you look back there, you can try and Michael can get it for you, but we have that sort of benchmark data that we want to put together 2017. And I'm -- I wanted to connect the dot which was 2017, where we were 3, 6 months ago and 2017, where we are now so that you could see the benefits rolling in from the investment we're making now when a large percentage of that production happens in the '17. So it's appropriate for us to do that, but we are not far enough down the road on budget and certainly our view of gas price to set numbers for that in detail yet, but it'll be forthcoming.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: According to your PVI calculations is there a base level of fixed costs in each of your 3 core areas in which the hurdle rates, per se, adding a rigor to are temporarily lower? Or is the message that your hurdle rates to meet your PVI threshold are 2 72 t
componenttext: According to your PVI calculations is there a base level of fixed costs in each of your 3 core areas in which the hurdle rates, per se, adding a rigor to are temporarily lower? Or is the message that your hurdle rates to meet your PVI threshold are 2 72 to 2 80 gas?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try to answer that and Craig might help me. When we do our economics for our wells, for drilling wells going forward from that perspective, we put all the costs in there. If you look at completing of wells that we're doing in this sort of reinitiat
componenttext: Let me try to answer that and Craig might help me. When we do our economics for our wells, for drilling wells going forward from that perspective, we put all the costs in there. If you look at completing of wells that we're doing in this sort of reinitiation of completions, since those wells are already drilled and waiting on completions, those economics are point forward. But what we do is we take a look at the total cost in each of the 3 areas, we take a view in this case it's forward strict pricing, exclusive of any hedge benefits. And then we run the economic straight up in the 3 areas and the wells, when you're investing within cash flow and you have more projects than you can fund within cash flow, then you prioritize them from top to bottom. And with the flexibility of our vertical integration, we can move that investment around. So if you see it, some kind of a change develop, obviously, it's longer than a change in 1 day, but as you begin to see a trend, NGL prices begin to recover and stay there based on fundamentals, you shift to liquid-rich drilling, that kind of thing. But yes, it's compared to straight up, heads up, all in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, you mentioned 2 70, 2 80, that's true that turns on a large part of our portfolio doesn't turn on every last well location we had at those price levels, so I don't want to lead you down that path but obviously it depends on the production profi
componenttext: And Brian, you mentioned 2 70, 2 80, that's true that turns on a large part of our portfolio doesn't turn on every last well location we had at those price levels, so I don't want to lead you down that path but obviously it depends on the production profile of the well in those wells as you go north or just stronger in general, but across the portfolio, 2 70 to 2 80 does turn on economic locations.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. The follow-up is on the earlier question with regard to some of the paper drilling, the efficiency improvements on the completion front. Can you speak to what your expectations are for productivity gains? How much better well performance would look
componenttext: Great. The follow-up is on the earlier question with regard to some of the paper drilling, the efficiency improvements on the completion front. Can you speak to what your expectations are for productivity gains? How much better well performance would look like in each of the areas you're applying some of the enhanced completions or other targeting technologies?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try something on you from a fact-based, and then whether the projections forward apply to the whole company or not, I think we're still working on that. But if you go and look at wells that we've drilled in the last 12 months in the West Virginia o
componenttext: Let me try something on you from a fact-based, and then whether the projections forward apply to the whole company or not, I think we're still working on that. But if you go and look at wells that we've drilled in the last 12 months in the West Virginia or excuse me, Southwest Appalachia area, and expertly manage prior to us coming there, a lot of focus on good operatorship. We came in with a different concept and we drilled and completed wells, a number of them, across the acreage. We increased the sand loading substantially, we optimized where we landed the wells. In fact, we took the wells that were already drilled and drilled them on paper to figure out if you're going to redo it, how would you steer it. We used tools that weren't used on the first well. We upped the sand loading considerably. We managed the flowback on those wells to increase condensate yield and the ultimate EURs. And we drilled of those wells nearly or virtually 100% in the 15-foot targeted interval we had. So long way of saying we had a different concept and the wells are 40% or more, more productive and better EURs than the ones that were there when we got there. So much so that when we could go back to our reserves auditors and explain to them what we are doing, that was a-- we wanted to test it all the way through the system, so we are taking those learnings, applying them back into West -- to Pennsylvania and even into Fayetteville. There's no condensate yield or NGL yield in the other 2 divisions so that part doesn't apply. So hitting, putting stronger metrics in for being in zone 100% of the time changes, in our sand loading, changes in our flowback regime, elimination and debottlenecking of both the downhole equipment and the surface facilities are producing better wells and those kind of learnings are what we learn. And then we project those into our going forward estimates where we can substantiate them.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You all have a very definitely a vertically integrated on the services side and listening to slumbers day to day in the service side, there's a thought of higher pricing going forward, what are your thoughts of kind of cost per well per area like back hal
componenttext: You all have a very definitely a vertically integrated on the services side and listening to slumbers day to day in the service side, there's a thought of higher pricing going forward, what are your thoughts of kind of cost per well per area like back half of the year? And then I know the $700 million budget is just an indication, but whenever you think about that, do you have any sort of cost escalation in your concept?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jack can kind of go into a couple of percentages, let me just touch on a couple of things. As I said in my kind of prepared remarks, we're going to economically evaluate our equipment and third parties, but directionally, when I look at the drilling
componenttext: Yes, Jack can kind of go into a couple of percentages, let me just touch on a couple of things. As I said in my kind of prepared remarks, we're going to economically evaluate our equipment and third parties, but directionally, when I look at the drilling rigs for example, our drilling rigs are handbuilt by us. I mean, we -- in terms of picking all the pieces, we've got extraordinary employees that are compensated as employees that are drilling these wells and doing an incredible job. And so the likelihood of us using our own rigs to do that versus the cost of external rigs and the flexibility advantage we have by using our own, you put all that into the economics in our cost of drilling should stay right where they are continue to improve just because of our performance on the completion side. There's a part of the equation that's really huge here and it's utilization. And it is utilization in a place so that it becomes hyperefficient. And as we ramp-up, and we're are still working on this concept by the way, as we ramp up at this first initial pace, the numbers of wells, the numbers of completions to keep something, keep a team and a frac fleet, et cetera, fully utilized, lay heavily on the economic side. If you use them half-time, you got to charge yourself a little bit more. If you're not -- if you use them full time, you can compete with anyone and we have. This transitional phase we are working on it. So I don't see any changes in our drilling side costs in terms of moving them up. We worked with a lot of our suppliers and have put in place agreements for as long as 18 months to try to enable them to get back to work but enable us to save cost and keep our costs in check. Jack may have some specifics around completion that potential risk to it, but...

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, hello, David. The costs we're doing the work for, for the rest of this year is actually lower than it was when we were -- when we suspended operations at the end of last year. But comparing back to when times were busy and we all expect commodity pr
componenttext: Okay, hello, David. The costs we're doing the work for, for the rest of this year is actually lower than it was when we were -- when we suspended operations at the end of last year. But comparing back to when times were busy and we all expect commodity prices to get better, we're going to get busier. Last year, we were doing work for about 1/3 -- 33% less than what the peak was. It is considerably less right now. One of the reasons vertically integrated is, Bill said about drilling rigs, we expect to use our drilling rigs with mainly. But on a pumping services side, that is something we consider as protection against those higher prices if they come that will be utilized in hours again with utilization Bill mentioned. As that goes, our pumping services will be able to supplant if prices get out of hand. So we think that's a little bit of a hedge that we're protected.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Currently, [indiscernible] plateau slightly lower near-term through '17. So not a significant risk to us at this point.
componenttext: Currently, [indiscernible] plateau slightly lower near-term through '17. So not a significant risk to us at this point.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I wanted to ask was just having taken out $700 million of debt recently, does debt reduction take a backseat to EBITDA growth in 2017? Or is debt reduction still a significant concern in the shorter-term?
componenttext: First question I wanted to ask was just having taken out $700 million of debt recently, does debt reduction take a backseat to EBITDA growth in 2017? Or is debt reduction still a significant concern in the shorter-term?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, 2 things on that. Balance sheet is always a focus of ours and we'll continue to do so. But the second part of that is we've addressed what we wanted to address with 2018, the significant paydown, you mentioned the $700 million, there's a tender offe
componenttext: Well, 2 things on that. Balance sheet is always a focus of ours and we'll continue to do so. But the second part of that is we've addressed what we wanted to address with 2018, the significant paydown, you mentioned the $700 million, there's a tender offer takes that wall away from us so that's a significant accomplishment. Nothing that we feel like we have to do something immediately, but we will continue to look at the balance sheet, whether it's '18 or any other debt that we have for pay down potentially.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-on to that, it's part of our capital discussion and our 2017 budget discussion. We can have gas prices, we can hedge those gas prices, they can generate a  set of cash flow. The further dialogue that we want to have and will have is, out
componenttext: And then a follow-on to that, it's part of our capital discussion and our 2017 budget discussion. We can have gas prices, we can hedge those gas prices, they can generate a  set of cash flow. The further dialogue that we want to have and will have is, out of that cash flow, is that all drilling and completion, is it part drilling and completion, part debt reduction? We know where we just been, so we're going to look at the full dimension of that. And so a bit more time on the guidance for '17 beyond the comparison of the $700 million that we put out. Part of it is looking at that balance sheet and continuing to evaluate that. And once we figure that out, we'll get that out.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Unlike the approach to the questions -- some of the questions regarding the rigs in a slightly different way, but one that you've always been pretty consistent about, Slide 17 of the current corporate presentation shows that Southwest Appalachia has far m
componenttext: Unlike the approach to the questions -- some of the questions regarding the rigs in a slightly different way, but one that you've always been pretty consistent about, Slide 17 of the current corporate presentation shows that Southwest Appalachia has far more economic locations to $3 in that gas than the Fayetteville or Northeast Appalachia combined. So I was wondering what are the drivers that are putting 60% of your rigs in those place instead of ]more rigs at the Southwest Appalachia?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the key drivers, there's kind of a couple, one of the key drivers is the variability on liquids pricing and the assumptions that we make and then what we -- where we see the market. And we -- NGL pricing has been under quite a bit of pressure for t
componenttext: One of the key drivers, there's kind of a couple, one of the key drivers is the variability on liquids pricing and the assumptions that we make and then what we -- where we see the market. And we -- NGL pricing has been under quite a bit of pressure for the last many months and we are seeing fundamentals show us that there are more, an uphill trend buoyed by specific fundamentals in each of the NGLs that enable us to see the opportunities to shift even on the fly from Northeast to West Virginia to capture that is available to us. So we do have a starting point. We're seeing some of the available or the fundamentals that may shift that as we go through these drilling projects. The second part of it is our available wells to be able to be drilled in from a permit perspective. So you keep an inventory of permitting -- permitted wells in each area, you watch acreage explorations, you watch a number of things. And so those are qualitative issues around the shift in economic or the specific economics. I believe that when you look at the longer-term drilling profile and you look at the pricing that we see, et cetera, more and more of our capital will go to this West Virginia area. Again, assuming that they're superior economics, which when -- as NGL pricing returns to some more -- a more fundamentally -- a market fundamentally-based pricing regime, we expect that, that will happen. The prospecting, all of that is there, so it's just really a matter of where do we get started and how do we get started. Another piece of this, the economics are again a big piece of this. We've positioned rigs back in December, January in place much, some might even on pads. Some of the initial drilling to complement the permits and the plans that were already there are the most efficient things to do as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And the last point that you are making there late in that was Southwest Appalachia has no infrastructure constraints. It's based on the permitting and the efficiencies and all this sort of things.
componenttext: Right. And the last point that you are making there late in that was Southwest Appalachia has no infrastructure constraints. It's based on the permitting and the efficiencies and all this sort of things.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Lammers on with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Lammers on with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few on the -- on your debt backlog here. In contrast to allocation for rig adds, it looks like the Fayetteville has actually seen the biggest blowdown of docks, at least at the end of this year, just looking at the guidance for drilled wells versus
componenttext: Just a few on the -- on your debt backlog here. In contrast to allocation for rig adds, it looks like the Fayetteville has actually seen the biggest blowdown of docks, at least at the end of this year, just looking at the guidance for drilled wells versus completions. The Northeast, in comparison, looks to be building a bit potentially at least staying flat. Does that speak to your view on Northeast basis entering next year? And can you talk what would may have been other drivers for that dock blowdown allocation?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: The key driver for docks, they're all economic, is the fact that unless something changes in our view, in the Fayetteville, we're not going to put a number of rigs in Fayetteville. We're biased to the Northeast. Those are the investments we've made that w
componenttext: The key driver for docks, they're all economic, is the fact that unless something changes in our view, in the Fayetteville, we're not going to put a number of rigs in Fayetteville. We're biased to the Northeast. Those are the investments we've made that we're waiting to capture the revenue associated with them. And so bringing that inventory down as low as we can makes economic sense and it makes practical sense. In the Northeast, let me stop for a second and make 1 another comment relative to docks in general. We don't drill wells -- we don't have a dock inventory for any other reason than to be efficient. We don't drill wells and hold them and wait on price or doing that kind of stuff. So as we build this restart plan and we're looking towards the Northeast, we need a certain inventory of docks to be efficient. There was a -- the initial view was let's go Northeast, let's do work there. In West Virginia, we weren't going to do as many wells, and so we could burn off some of our dock inventory because we didn't need as many to be efficient and that is -- that variable moves around all the time. And so it's an efficiency issue, it's a straight up economic issue, but in this case, at this moment in time, with clearing up excess inventory, you'll recall we came to a very abrupt halt. And so as you work off that inventory and get it down to where it needs to be, that's why they came out the way they did. And we've got about 100 across the company and most of Fayetteville's will be done, and many more West Virginia's will be done and we'll have Fayetteville's, or excuse me, Appalachia's towards the end of the year. But we end up at 60 [ph] year, so by the end of the year. And keep in mind, from an operational perspective, calendar years are only to do budgets. Operationally, we keep the machine flowing through the year. And part of our plan of this restart had 2017 in mind. And again, a continuous efficient, hyperefficient operating regime.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And I know you guys just raised capital here for the second part of the year but thinking beyond that if commodity prices merit to even more acceleration going to next year, kind of mid next year, with that we do then to have a similarly balan
componenttext: Understood. And I know you guys just raised capital here for the second part of the year but thinking beyond that if commodity prices merit to even more acceleration going to next year, kind of mid next year, with that we do then to have a similarly balanced approach in terms of blowing down a portion of your docks but also adding rigs?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our plan next year is we get in the middle of next year, if prices recover?
componenttext: Our plan next year is we get in the middle of next year, if prices recover?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the flavor of -- a couple of things, as I try to dodge the question. One, the statement I made before, docks are an efficiency improvement tool for us more than a pile of a bunch of docks and wait for price to get better and move them off. So we'r
componenttext: I think the flavor of -- a couple of things, as I try to dodge the question. One, the statement I made before, docks are an efficiency improvement tool for us more than a pile of a bunch of docks and wait for price to get better and move them off. So we're -- this initial phase of restart related to docks is just putting the house from an abrupt start into an efficient mode again. If we're not drilling a bunch of wells in a particular area, we don't need a bunch of docks and we can monetize that cash flow coming back quickly. As we go into '17, my guess from a drilling and completions kind of overall priority will be more what I would call normal. First of all, highly constructed by economics and differentials and cash flow. We'll invest within cash flow, as I said earlier. We will prioritize where we go in how we do it based off of a reasonably smooth development plan, but one that is driven by economics and we will ashore of our confidence in that through a hedging program. And so you won't see some kind of opening, like we are starting over in '17 and doing a bunch of completions, you'll see us trend through the rest of this year. So it will ebb and flow, but not by plus and minus 30s because we'll have to clean that up by now.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll give you a few thoughts. I think it's the fundamentals continue to show improvement. If you look at year-over-year changes on the demand side, we've seen, just July year-over-year changes of plus 2.1 Bcf a day. If you look at exports, combined L
componenttext: Yes, I'll give you a few thoughts. I think it's the fundamentals continue to show improvement. If you look at year-over-year changes on the demand side, we've seen, just July year-over-year changes of plus 2.1 Bcf a day. If you look at exports, combined LNG and exports from Mexico, up roughly 1.2 Bcf a day. And we see lower dry gas production year-over-year decline of about 1.5 Bcf a day. So the macro fundamental outlook is certainly improving. We've certainly got less gas available to go into the ground. I think we'll see some very low injection numbers over the course of the next 2 to 3 weeks, the weather, at least the balance of the summer is looking like we're -- the heat is going to stay with us. So I think overall, from a macro standpoint, balance of the year into '17, it's a positive outlook.

componenttext: Sure. This is Paul. From the standpoint of the West Virginia land, while we were very pleased with that sale from a metric standpoint at the time we've got quite a bit of that inventory left. And the way we think about from an inventory standpoint is, up in the Panhandle of West Virginia. We've got very liquids-rich inventory that gives us an opportunity to access those in the case of positive NGL pricing. From a portfolio standpoint, over there on the eastern side of that position, as you get into Mary Mann type area, we've got the opportunity to develop dry Marcellus over there as the natural offset as our Northeast PA is to NGL prices. And then across the -- across both of those positions, you see that the industry is aggressively proving that up for a very strong Utica development so that's the basis of those type curves.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to say thank to all of you for all of the questions. I really appreciate it and the dialogue is good. We set out this year, as I said earlier, committed to strengthen our balance sheet, enhancing our margins, optimizing our portfolio. And as you ca
componenttext: I want to say thank to all of you for all of the questions. I really appreciate it and the dialogue is good. We set out this year, as I said earlier, committed to strengthen our balance sheet, enhancing our margins, optimizing our portfolio. And as you can see, as we have demonstrated, we delivered on those commitments. And I really believe we've accomplished a tremendous amount in the first half this year. And we're all thrilled and excited to continue to do what we do best, and that's create value plus for our shareholders. We've got a premier quality set of assets, some very, very strong operational proficiency, and we've married that with a disciplined capital approach and a focus on returns and so we were able to create tremendous value and deliver, really deliver differentiating value. We've been through a lot in the first quarter. And I'll express, to my employees and our whole team, our thanks. Because without them, building that base, we wouldn't have been able to do all the things we've been able to do. Our investors and banks and bondholders and all of the other folks supported us along the way because we were in an early spot that was difficult in a terrible commodity price environment and you let us, or supported us as we navigated forward. So I'm quite confident in going forward with you. I'm looking forward to talking with you again about the different ways we continue to find to strengthen our company and to take us forward in that value adding growth. And so I want to thank each of you again and I hope you all have a great weekend. Thanks for your time.

It is now my pleasure to introduce Michael Hancock, Director of Investor Relations for Southwestern Energy Company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron,
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron, our Senior Vice President of Operations; and Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of Corporate Development. If you have not received a copy of last night's press release regarding our second quarter 2016 update, you can find a copy on our website at swn.com. 
Also, I'd like to point out that many of the comments during this teleconference are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties affecting outcomes, many of which are beyond our control and are discussed in more detail in the risk factors and the forward-looking statement sections of our annual and quarterly filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although we believe the expectations expressed are based on reasonable assumptions, they are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results or developments may differ materially. 
I'll now turn the call over to Bill Way to discuss our recent activity and results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today and your continued interest in Southwestern Energy Company. Earlier this year, we set out on a mission and articulated a clear set of objectives committing to reinforce
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call today and your continued interest in Southwestern Energy Company. 
Earlier this year, we set out on a mission and articulated a clear set of objectives committing to reinforce our company, restore confidence and strengthen our bridge to resuming value-adding growth as commodity prices and economics improved. We have delivered on these commitments. As you've seen over the past few months, we have been keenly focused on strengthening our balance sheet, including managing near-term maturities, by pushing out a material amount of 2018 maturities to 2020 and have taken specific actions to reduce approximately $1.2 billion of debt through the sale of a portion of our long-dated undeveloped acreage and our very successful equity offering. Craig is going to discuss the details of this very successful deleveraging activity in a few minutes. 
In addition, we have continued to do what we do best, aggressively improve margin, both cost and performance, from our premier asset portfolio. We continue to drive cost out of the system and optimize our base production. The results of these efforts were evident in last night's release, where you saw our strong quarterly results, including production, beating the top end of guidance by 10 Bcf equivalent, while the cost metrics came in below guidance. These achievements position the company to capture the benefits of a strengthening commodity price that appears to be in process. Based on this strong operational performance and our high-quality assets; improved commodity prices; a stronger balance sheet, including the preservation of our strong liquidity position; and funds earmarked from our equity offering, we are reinitiating economic drilling and completion activities in each of our operating areas. These activities include completion of drilled but uncompleted wells and drilling of new wells, all meeting or exceeding our rigorous economic criteria. In fact, giving our -- given our vertically integrated business model and only after the funds were secured, we have already resumed drilling activities much faster than we anticipated. Our first well, which was spud last weekend, reached TD in less than 4 days, which is comparable to what we were doing 7 months ago when we halted drilling activities.
We plan to add one to 2 rigs per month in the -- across the company during the third quarter, demonstrating the speed and agility with which we can adjust our activity. Our well cost will also see the benefit of this vertical integration as the industry increases activity over time in response to the improved commodity prices. However, we plan to continue to evaluate and utilize both internal and external services as we ramp up activity and as economics dictate. Jack will walk through the detailed plan for Southwestern for the second half of 2016 in a moment, which will have a material beneficial impact on 2017 and beyond.
While we've not communicated our 2017 plans, early indications show that we can invest in value-adding economic projects, resulting in production volumes flat year-over-year with a capital program of just $700 million in '17, given the optimization work underway and the higher capital efficiency in our go-forward plans. Let me be clear. We will not chase uneconomic production growth. Each well we drill, each well we complete must meet our economic threshold of 1.3 PVI at current pricing before we drill. In line with our intent to invest within cash flow and drive continued improvement in the balance sheet, we will remain flexible and adjust activities accordingly as prices move.
A critical aspect of our commitment to financial discipline and an essential part of our forward investment plan is to take steps to assure our commodity price projections used in our economics for projects are realized. Consistent with our strategy to protect returns on our investment, to date, we have hedged just over 225 Bcf of our 2017 production, locking in a portion of our 2017 cash flow. 
With that, let me turn over to Craig to discuss some of our financial highlights from the second quarter.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, we had a very strong quarter and successfully delivered on our commitments. Since the beginning of the year, we have consistently noted that strengthening the balance sheet is a core focus. We t
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, we had a very strong quarter and successfully delivered on our commitments. Since the beginning of the year, we have consistently noted that strengthening the balance sheet is a core focus. We took significant steps and delivered steps in this area during the second quarter. 
The first step announced was the divestiture of a long-dated acreage in West Virginia for $450 million. This acreage was scheduled to be developed in or after 2023, providing us with the opportunity to realize a strong purchase price with no appreciable near-term production or cash flow loss. The due diligence is progressing well, and the transaction is expected to close in the third quarter. Additionally, we announced the amendment and extension of our bank agreements, which ensures significant liquidity availability through 2020. Our portfolio of premier assets and strong bank relationships made this amendment process possible despite the challenging lending environment currently facing the banks.
Combining the impacts of our bank transactions with our $1.25 billion equity offering and successful debt repurchase in July, we currently have approximately $1.5 billion in cash in addition to the undrawn $800 million from the revolving credit facilities. Pro forma for these transactions, our net debt balance was reduced to $3.2 billion, with debt maturities prior to 2020 reduced from $2 billion to $300 million. This is a very positive development for our credit and liquidity profile as it positions our balance sheet well to drive value from our outstanding assets. As we strengthen our balance sheet with these proactive steps, we are also taking steps to resume value-adding growth as we resume drilling and completion activity in the second half of 2016. We are committed to maintaining a healthy balance sheet and protecting our returns and have been actively hedging our remaining 2016 production as well as 2017. We have now hedged 93 Bcf of our remaining 2016 production at an average floor price of $2.57 per Mcf and approximately 228 Bcf of expected 2017 production at an average floor price of $3.01 per Mcf. These positions provide -- and our hedging program in general will provide protection on cash flows and include options that allow exposure to upside price movements. 
I will now turn it over to Jack to discuss some of the details of our operational results and increased capital program for the second half of the year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Craig, and good morning, everyone. As you saw in last night's release, in addition to the great financial achievements that Craig mentioned that we made in the second quarter, we also delivered excellent operational results. The quality of our acr
componenttext:
Thanks, Craig, and good morning, everyone. As you saw in last night's release, in addition to the great financial achievements that Craig mentioned that we made in the second quarter, we also delivered excellent operational results. The quality of our acreage and the strength of our well performance continue to show, as demonstrated by the second quarter production exceeding the top end of guidance by 10 Bcf while investing less than $15 million of drilling and completion capital during the quarter. With this strong portfolio performance, we are raising our 2016 production guidance by 45 Bcfe or 5% using midpoints. Almost 3 quarters of this improvement is attributable to our team's efforts to increase production from our existing wells.
Along with this impressive production performance, our aggressive assault on margin is continuing to reap benefits as our E&P costs, which include lease operating expenses, general and administrative and taxes other than income taxes, decreased to $1.17 per Mcfe in the second quarter of '16 compared to $1.24 per Mcfe in the second quarter of 2015. LOE costs for the quarter were again lower than our guidance range as the team's progress -- as the teams progress their efforts to identify efficiencies in the field. Our identified LOE cost savings for 2016 is now over $50 million, an increase of $10 million from savings that we discussed in our last call. These savings are in addition to the $35 million annual impact of the amended Williams agreement we previously discussed. The incremental $10 million was primarily driven by efficiencies implemented around saltwater disposal and contracted services. We expect to leverage this focus on margin enhancement as we reinitiate our drilling and completion activities.
As Bill mentioned earlier, we have already started our drilling and completion activities, and we anticipate 5 rigs running by the end of the third quarter: 2 in Northeast Appalachia, 2 in Southwest Appalachia and one in the Fayetteville. We expect to drill approximately 60 wells and place approximately 100 wells to sales on -- in the second half of this year, which includes our Utica well, which we drilled in late 2015. While this additional activity will impact 2016 slightly with increased production, the real benefit of this comes in 2017 as we build the momentum of the portfolio and return to value-added growth.
This concludes today's prepared comments. So we will now turn it back to the operator, who will explain the procedure for asking questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes. And Randy can talk a little bit of detail on infrastructure. But as we've said before, we took on some early transportation commitments and some gathering commitments as we did the acquisition. We've added to that portfolio through fixed sales, where
componenttext: Yes. And Randy can talk a little bit of detail on infrastructure. But as we've said before, we took on some early transportation commitments and some gathering commitments as we did the acquisition. We've added to that portfolio through fixed sales, where the buyer has to transport or transport of our own. We can grow this asset over the next 3 years at about 35% per year and not have run into constraints associated with takeaway. Gathering -- the areas where we will drill have existing gathering agreements and gathering infrastructure in place, and it's really a model for what we do everywhere. The time from spud all the way to sales needs to include is there available capacity, is there available takeaway, is there available gathering processing. And we assure ourselves that we have that route all the way to the markets before we drill. But Randy's got some -- probably some further details on the latest activity that we've been doing.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. I think the only thing I'd add to your comments are on the gathering side, as Bill mentioned, we do feel confident in the existing service providers and their ability to add needed infrastructure where we do need it and the time we need it.
componenttext: Thanks, Bill. I think the only thing I'd add to your comments are on the gathering side, as Bill mentioned, we do feel confident in the existing service providers and their ability to add needed infrastructure where we do need it and the time we need it. And then on the export capacity, the interstate capacity out of the region, again, we don't anticipate having any constraints when we get to levels that are beyond currently contracted levels on our portfolio. We still have a good excess position forecasted right now. And just with the market where it is and the anticipated buildout of that area in '17 and '18, respectively, we feel very confident in being able to get what we need out of there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of our benefits of the renegotiation of the Williams deal and -- we brought to the table was the opportunity for them to be our gatherer for dry Utica gas in the same region, and that's provided us quite a bit of flexibility. Our gatherers do a great
componenttext: One of our benefits of the renegotiation of the Williams deal and -- we brought to the table was the opportunity for them to be our gatherer for dry Utica gas in the same region, and that's provided us quite a bit of flexibility. Our gatherers do a great job, are confident that we contract there to enable us -- for example, even the Utica well that Jack mentioned. We will be able to test that well in a wet gas system for a while just to -- because it's available and a great support we get out of our gatherers. So as we test there and then test other areas, that dry gas gathering system for Utica gets built out, and we just see a seamless progression from testing through to production.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last, if I could quick, maybe for Craig. Just that $700 million you said of D&C for CapEx for '17, was that -- is that flat year-over-year or flat exit to exit?
componenttext: And just one last, if I could quick, maybe for Craig. Just that $700 million you said of D&C for CapEx for '17, was that -- is that flat year-over-year or flat exit to exit?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we'd moved to -- this is Bill again. What we moved to is, prior our guidance, was flat exit to exit. Now that is, we believe, that we will have a flat total production all in for '17 based off that number. And so as prices move around and we do our b
componenttext: What we'd moved to -- this is Bill again. What we moved to is, prior our guidance, was flat exit to exit. Now that is, we believe, that we will have a flat total production all in for '17 based off that number. And so as prices move around and we do our budgets, the opportunity -- gas prices, $0.25. Gas price moves cash flow $185 million. And so the opportunity to kind of evaluate that as we go forward is what we're up to now. But we won't do -- we'll do more work on our budget for '17 later this year. That's an improvement.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure it feels good for you all to get back to drilling. But I want to pick up on the -- that last thread, which falls upon your comments from the -- from your prepared remarks. Is -- 2 questions in this. Is the $700 million that you referred to, is th
componenttext: I'm sure it feels good for you all to get back to drilling. But I want to pick up on the -- that last thread, which falls upon your comments from the -- from your prepared remarks. Is -- 2 questions in this. Is the $700 million that you referred to, is that just D&C CapEx? Or is that total CapEx? And then if you could drill in a little bit more on the comment of being flat year-over-year. The way I look at it, if you're going to be flat year-over-year, you'd actually probably have to resume growth quarter-over-quarter, sequential growth, sometime in early 2017. Is that the right read on that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Total capital number that I talk about, and we do -- internally, we look at it this way. That is all in, so that's got C&IE in it as well as the activity capital that makes that happen. Our previous guidance was that for about that much capital, again, al
componenttext: Total capital number that I talk about, and we do -- internally, we look at it this way. That is all in, so that's got C&IE in it as well as the activity capital that makes that happen. Our previous guidance was that for about that much capital, again, all in, we could achieve a -- year-end '16 to year-end '17, you'd end up in the same -- where you started, but that had a decline built into it because it's a U-shaped kind of production profile. With this -- with us reinitiating drilling and completions -- and remember, we're doing a number of our DUCs, and we're going to talk about that later, some of our DUCs and drilling new wells, we accelerate that progression. Or another way to look at it, you flatten out the trough of decline. So yes, you're going to have -- we have to turn it. We'll turn it early in the year probably rather than waiting until sometime mid- to late year to do that. And so it's -- we wanted to kind of compare something that we'd put out before, which was at about $700 million, instead of it being exit-to-exit is now full year-on-full year flat. And so you are correct. As we enter the second half of next year, you get on that growth ramp, assuming that we -- again, assuming that's the number. We haven't done our capital budget, and -- but we guided on that before, so we just wanted to make it -- connect the dots for you.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's helpful detail, Bill. And then if I could ask another question about what you're seeing in pricing in your local price points up in Appalachia. Depending on which price point you look at, it -- you could make a case that there's been a Henry
componenttext: Right. That's helpful detail, Bill. And then if I could ask another question about what you're seeing in pricing in your local price points up in Appalachia. Depending on which price point you look at, it -- you could make a case that there's been a Henry Hub rally, but there hasn't been this much of a rally up in Appalachia. Is -- how do you guys see that progressing your local pricing in the back half of the year? And are there any particular sensitivities we should be thinking about with respect to that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Randy. I'll take that one. We have seen an improvement in basis. We saw it, obviously, in the first quarter with prices falling. We saw basis come in. And then we've seen actually -- as prices have risen, we haven't seen necessarily the same
componenttext: Yes. This is Randy. I'll take that one. We have seen an improvement in basis. We saw it, obviously, in the first quarter with prices falling. We saw basis come in. And then we've seen actually -- as prices have risen, we haven't seen necessarily the same widening. We still have a view that we'll have an improving basis over time in Southwest Appalachia, have a bias that the incremental capacity that's coming on, as I mentioned earlier, particularly in '17 and '18. Right now, we've got that at around 13 Bcf between the 2 years, will be adequate to continue to show some improvement and differentials over that time frame.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Holly Stewart with Scotia Howard Weil.

componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. Bill, I know last quarter, you mentioned drilling wells on paper. So I guess the question is, what will be done differently with this ramp in activity?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've done -- and what we'll do is probably talk about a couple of things. We both drilled wells on paper, and we're completing wells on paper. And I'm going to have Jack talk to you about what we found in the studies. But certainly, position -- or landin
componenttext: We've done -- and what we'll do is probably talk about a couple of things. We both drilled wells on paper, and we're completing wells on paper. And I'm going to have Jack talk to you about what we found in the studies. But certainly, position -- or landing zone frac loads, all that will come into play. But let me get Jack to give you some specifics.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. We went through -- during the time we've been not drilling, we've gone through and we've reviewed all the drilling wells that we have done, especially recently. We've done a lot of collaboration within our company and have shared a lot of
componenttext: Thank you, Bill. We went through -- during the time we've been not drilling, we've gone through and we've reviewed all the drilling wells that we have done, especially recently. We've done a lot of collaboration within our company and have shared a lot of ideas. Things that have worked that -- in West Virginia last year are now being utilized in Appalachia. But one -- we've come up with ideas. One thing on this well we just recently drilled, we used a rotary steerable in Northeast PA, which we used regularly in Southwest Appalachia last year. That's one of the reasons we were able to immediately get back on curve. Everything didn't go perfect on that well, but yet, we still were right on pace with what we did in the past. We've also looked at every one of our completions that have basically gone to engineered completions as far as looking at how much is in the zone, completing it, completing the work that's in-zone and have spent a lot of time looking at how we could -- more sand placement. We've gone in that pretty much across the way. Our flowback techniques of our wells. We've evaluated what has worked best and what has not worked so well, and we're going to implement those. But we've -- that has been a focus for the last 6 months, and we're already seeing results of it on our very first well with TD [indiscernible].

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my follow-up, just maybe on '17, Bill, and just the previous thought on staying kind of within cash flow or cash flow neutrality. Is that still the goal as we think about how we should be forecasting CapEx for next year?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my follow-up, just maybe on '17, Bill, and just the previous thought on staying kind of within cash flow or cash flow neutrality. Is that still the goal as we think about how we should be forecasting CapEx for next year?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when I think about how you're allocating capital with a big Northeast Marcellus emphasis, I'm trying to reconcile that with the PV-10 values or reserve report. And it seems to rank Fayetteville the highest and Northeast Marcellus, second or third. Is i
componenttext: So when I think about how you're allocating capital with a big Northeast Marcellus emphasis, I'm trying to reconcile that with the PV-10 values or reserve report. And it seems to rank Fayetteville the highest and Northeast Marcellus, second or third. Is it because the F&Ds are just so much better in Northeast Marcellus that you earn your PVI threshold there versus Fayetteville?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So when I think of the Fayetteville then, your leverage is -- in locations is in the Fayetteville, whereas if we look at the price stack, you don't have that much leverage in terms of location in Northeast Marcellus. How do you think about -- so wha
componenttext: Okay. So when I think of the Fayetteville then, your leverage is -- in locations is in the Fayetteville, whereas if we look at the price stack, you don't have that much leverage in terms of location in Northeast Marcellus. How do you think about -- so what are the gating factors to really ramping up in the Fayetteville? And why not -- and I'll leave it there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Craig. I think the big biggest gating factor, as Bill mentioned, certainly, we're going to look at economics. Northeast, no secret, get bigger wells. Certainly, Fayetteville continues to improve, and we've got some things that we will continue to
componenttext: This is Craig. I think the big biggest gating factor, as Bill mentioned, certainly, we're going to look at economics. Northeast, no secret, get bigger wells. Certainly, Fayetteville continues to improve, and we've got some things that we will continue to test there in the second half of this year. But the pricing, that's one component, the size of the well, and then just how we're driving cost through the system. And Randy mentioned earlier, one thing you didn't specifically reference, but West Virginia, as we get into the Southwest Appalachia, we had that liquids profile coming in as well that certainly helps the economics, and we've seen what pricing has done this year so far as well. We're getting improved on the NGL side.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up just on the CapEx is, so $700 million all in, including C&I for flat year-over-year, this might be an unfair question, but is there a way to sort of illustrate for every $100 million more in CapEx what kind of growth you might get?
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up just on the CapEx is, so $700 million all in, including C&I for flat year-over-year, this might be an unfair question, but is there a way to sort of illustrate for every $100 million more in CapEx what kind of growth you might get?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not yet, but what we -- as we put together our budget later this year, we'll be able to talk about that. If you look at our guidance from last time, we've got sort of indicative numbers on production per rig, making some assumptions on where they are and
componenttext: Not yet, but what we -- as we put together our budget later this year, we'll be able to talk about that. If you look at our guidance from last time, we've got sort of indicative numbers on production per rig, making some assumptions on where they are and the speed at the time, and we're back to kind of that speed or better. So if you look back there, you can find it or Michael can get it for you. But we have that sort of benchmark data that we want to put together 2017. And I'm -- I wanted to connect the dot, which was 2017, where we were 3, 6 months ago and 2017, where we are now so that you could see the benefits rolling in from the investment we're making now when a large percentage of that production happens in '17. So it is appropriate for us to do that, but we're not far enough down the road on budget and certainly, our view of gas price to set numbers for that in detail yet. But we -- it'll be forthcoming.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: According to your PVI calculations, is there a base level of fixed costs in each of your 3 core areas in which the hurdle rates for, say, adding a rigor or 2 are temporarily lower? Or is the message that your hurdle rates to meet your PVI threshold are $2
componenttext: According to your PVI calculations, is there a base level of fixed costs in each of your 3 core areas in which the hurdle rates for, say, adding a rigor or 2 are temporarily lower? Or is the message that your hurdle rates to meet your PVI threshold are $2.72 to $2.80 gas?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try to answer that. Craig, you may help me. When we do our economics for our wells -- for drilling wells going forward, that perspective, we put all the costs in there. If you look at completing of wells that we're doing in this sort of reinitiatio
componenttext: Let me try to answer that. Craig, you may help me. When we do our economics for our wells -- for drilling wells going forward, that perspective, we put all the costs in there. If you look at completing of wells that we're doing in this sort of reinitiation of completions, since those wells are already drilled and waiting on completion, those economics are pointing forward. But what we do is we take a look at the total cost in each of the 3 areas. We take a view, in this case, it's forward strip pricing, exclusive of any hedge benefits. And then we run the economic straight up in the 3 areas. And the wells, when you're investing within cash flow and you have more projects than you can fund within cash flow, then you prioritize them from top to bottom. And with the flexibility of our vertical integration, we can move that investment around. So if you see it -- some kind of a change develop, obviously, it's longer than a change in one day. But as you begin to see a trend, NGL prices begin to recover and stay there based on fundamentals, you shift to liquid-rich drilling, that kind of thing. But yes, it's -- compared straight up, heads up, all in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Brian, you mentioned $2.70, $2.80. That's true. That turns on -- a large part of our portfolio doesn't turn around every last well location we have at those price levels, so I don't want to lead you down that path. But it obviously depends on the
componenttext: Yes. And Brian, you mentioned $2.70, $2.80. That's true. That turns on -- a large part of our portfolio doesn't turn around every last well location we have at those price levels, so I don't want to lead you down that path. But it obviously depends on the production profile of the well in those wells as you go north or just stronger in general. But across the portfolio, $2.70 to $2.80 does turn on economic locations.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And the follow-up is on the earlier question with regard to some of the paper drilling and the efficiency improvements on the completion front. Can you speak to what your expectations are for productivity gains? How much better well performance wou
componenttext: Great. And the follow-up is on the earlier question with regard to some of the paper drilling and the efficiency improvements on the completion front. Can you speak to what your expectations are for productivity gains? How much better well performance would look like in each of the areas you're applying some of the enhanced completions or other targeting technologies?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try something on here from a fact base. And then whether the projections forward apply to the whole company or not, I think we're still working on that. But if you go and look at wells that we drilled in the last 12 months in the West Virginia -- o
componenttext: Let me try something on here from a fact base. And then whether the projections forward apply to the whole company or not, I think we're still working on that. But if you go and look at wells that we drilled in the last 12 months in the West Virginia -- or excuse me, Southwest Appalachia area and expertly managed prior to us coming there, a lot of focus on good operatorship, we came in with a different concept. And we drilled and completed wells, a number of them, across the acreage. We increased the sand loading substantially. We optimized where we landed the wells. In fact, we took the wells that were already drilled and drilled them on paper to figure out if you were going to redo it, how would you steer it. We used tools that weren't used on the first well. We upped the sand loading considerably. We managed the flowback on those wells to increase condensate yield and the ultimate EURs. And we drilled those wells nearly or virtually 100% in the 15-foot targeted interval we had. So long way of saying we had a different concept, and the wells are 40% or more, more productive and better EURs than the ones that were there when we got there. So much so that when we could go back to our reserves auditors and explain to them what we are doing, that was a -- we wanted to test it all the way through the system. So we are taking those learnings, applying them back into West -- to Pennsylvania and even into Fayetteville. There's no condensate yield or NGL yield in the other 2 divisions, so that part doesn't apply. But hitting -- putting stronger metrics in for being in-zone 100% of the time, changes in our sand loading, changes in our flowback regime, elimination and debottlenecking of both the downhole equipment and the surface facilities are producing better wells, and those kind of learnings are what we've learned. And then we project those into our going-forward estimates where we can substantiate them.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
