componenttext: And Fayetteville?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Craig. Fayetteville on Bill's notes or Bill's comments, Fayetteville at current prices with the high 17 certainly looks good. What we're seeing in these early results when we talked about these IPs and certainly testing Moorefield continues
componenttext: Doug, this is Craig. Fayetteville on Bill's notes or Bill's comments, Fayetteville at current prices with the high 17 certainly looks good. What we're seeing in these early results when we talked about these IPs and certainly testing Moorefield continues to push that breakeven down. But as we've kind of seen kind of layout based on historical results in our IR deck, Fayetteville at $3 flat gives you about 500-well locations. So you can may be push that a little bit lower. And certainly with new results, continue to push. that really kind of goes with all locations. As we continue to drive costs out of the system, it improves our production rates or EURs. That helps, but the numbers Bill quoted on our Appalachian assets is fair.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: [indiscernible] just one more thing on that. In the Fayetteville, we're doing some Moorefield drilling right now. We don't have -- the results are kind of early days, but those wells are coming on quite strong. So they have -- and they are economics are very solid. We're not doing anything that doesn't meet our 1.3 investment hurdles at strip pricing, and that's excluding any hedge benefits. So you can kind of see that in each of the 3 areas, there's a some depth and some good depth in terms of well locations available to pursue.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question about your completion pace for Q4. One of the things I was struck by was the uptick in completions to 52 in Q4 from 9 in Q3. can you talk about what the pattern of that, of those completions will be over the fourth quarter? Is i
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question about your completion pace for Q4. One of the things I was struck by was the uptick in completions to 52 in Q4 from 9 in Q3. can you talk about what the pattern of that, of those completions will be over the fourth quarter? Is it going to be kind of flat over -- across the months, at least the quarter? or more weighted towards the back end with the aim of capturing better local pricing? what does that mean for your -- do you have [indiscernible] you can share with us for your 16 exit rate?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll -- let me talk a little bit about the pace of what we're doing, and then [indiscernible]. Jack can. the -- There's a combination of things at work here. We've restarted the activity. We want to be as efficient as we can. And so really, most of t
componenttext: Yes, I'll -- let me talk a little bit about the pace of what we're doing, and then [indiscernible]. Jack can. the -- There's a combination of things at work here. We've restarted the activity. We want to be as efficient as we can. And so really, most of the completions in the fourth quarter will come across fairly ratably. We expect that we will do -- our objective is to complete all the DUCs or as many DUCs as we can in Fayetteville; and in each of the other 2 asset, retain a level of DUCs only for efficiency. we -- when we [indiscernible] activities at end of the year, first part of this year, we had a DUC inventory. we then restarted. that's all going fine, and we're working them all. Since we don't anticipate a large amount of drilling in Fayetteville, we don't need a large amount of inventory. so you get those [indiscernible] to kind of get the returns on those. in other 2 areas, you're going to be focused on capturing those you can get to market in an efficient and timely manner to capitalize on those rising prices, while retaining enough that we can be efficient with our plan. And so I think at the end of the day, you'll see it ratably across the year. And on volume, what was your question on volume?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- what implications that would have for exit rate on 16?
componenttext: Just -- what implications that would have for exit rate on 16?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far us the fracture, the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations.
componenttext: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far us the fracture, the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations. The only thing that impacts the it reasonably we don't have a little faster pace is water availability in Pennsylvania. And it comes and goes, but we've been getting a lot [indiscernible] right now. So we don't foresee a problem.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my follow-up question, and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your 2017. So I guess you can deflect part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, looks like by 16 in Q4. A
componenttext: Got it. And my follow-up question, and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your 2017. So I guess you can deflect part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, looks like by 16 in Q4. And then you say you will be back to -- your target of that 60% [ph] inventory that you need for efficiency in '17. So that implies you're going to work down your DUC inventory by another roughly 25 over the course of the year. What -- compared to the 52 completions you're going to have in Q4, what do you think your completion rate per quarter is going to look like in '17?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like, and we haven't done that yet. So we are doing scenario planning around that now. W
componenttext: Well you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like, and we haven't done that yet. So we are doing scenario planning around that now. We want to remain flexible between the 2 divisions up in the northeast. And so as our DUC inventory, our rate of burnoff of DUCs, our timing of wells and completions, the underlying theme will be it will be as efficient as we can to drive higher margins through lower cost and improved well performance. And it will be -- the makeup of that will be part of our capital plan --

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit, how can I guess could you just talk through how you're reviewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus I guess the slide deck is little highe
componenttext: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit, how can I guess could you just talk through how you're reviewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus I guess the slide deck is little higher in the wells turned to sales projection for the year a little bit. Well, I guess year-to-date is not right on par with the forecast. So just trying to get a good sense for how you think it's going, and maybe if the [indiscernible] expectations here as you work through the fourth quarter?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. headline is it's going terrific. Remember there's 2 components to this. First component on fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can, and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget. The second thing
componenttext: Sure, yes. headline is it's going terrific. Remember there's 2 components to this. First component on fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can, and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget. The second thing that we talked about, and this is critical, is the frac intensity or the testing that's going on these -- on some of these wells. We're ramping sand loading in a couple of cases from 1,000 to 2,000 pounds a foot, from 2,000 to 5,000 pounds a foot. And so -- that testing impacts some of these wells. And to put much more sand in that many more stages into a well takes longer to do. And so the only issue that we have right now -- and it's not really an issue. I miscalled it, It's an opportunity  -- is we're doing some testing related to higher sand loading, which will have positive effects we expect on our wells. We've already seen that in West Virginia where we've gone up about 2,000 to almost 3,000 pounds in wells already online. And that, with how we're landing and how we're flowing them and all of that, is improving their individual performance. we expect that to be the case elsewhere. and nuance to all of that statement is we're right now focused on technical limit. So we've already proved to ourselves that we can get a whole lot more sand in and then make whole lot better wells, which makes them more economic. We want to know how much more can you do. so we focus the focus on that. We will do those wells and get them online and see and we'll break them. And if we go to the place where much higher sand content and stage phasing, et cetera, becomes more of the norm after we tested, then we readjust our schedule, let you know what that looks like, and go from there. So that's the real big piece of that whole calendar issue.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay that's helpful. And maybe following up on the sand comment, you mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000-well -- or the 5,000 pound per well foot test. And then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess is that well online, is there anything to thin
componenttext: Okay, okay that's helpful. And maybe following up on the sand comment, you mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000-well -- or the 5,000 pound per well foot test. And then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess is that well online, is there anything to think through there? And was that a wet versus dry well? just trying to think through I guess historical. you said you've been at 2,000 pounds. I'm just trying to think through how that could potentially impact the results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: , this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. they'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000-pound tests we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the [indiscernib
componenttext: , this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. they'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000-pound tests we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the [indiscernible] ventures pad. So we're building on that, actually stretching again, as Bill said, the technical limits to do that. We have brought on, in northeast , some of our the pad I mentioned was one where we went to tighter cluster spacing, more stages. And that contributes to the time, but we're definitely seeing the performance there. And it's -- they're with high sand already, the 2,000 pounds we've adopted last year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: as you walk through these, we've got a couple of things going on. we've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have, they're all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000 pounds.
componenttext: as you walk through these, we've got a couple of things going on. we've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have, they're all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000 pounds. That doesn't mean we're stopping there. That's a big leap for them. In northeast assets, we already have proof that that in certain areas, that you can go up past 3,000 pounds and get materially better wells. Now we want to figure out, okay how do we step that up and in what increment? I've got engineers that would like to do a whole lot more than even the numbers we've been talking about, but we want to be prudent about it as well. And then we'll figure out where that economic threshold crosses that technical limit and optimize that point and go forward. So we'll -- we've got a lot of moving parts here. And the early indications, both from late last year and early now, with some of the work in northeastern Pennsylvania and some of this is very encouraging. And so we'll continue to pursue that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly on a relative basis, to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the
componenttext: Yes, just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly on a relative basis, to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the different twists and turns that are going on with those projects. We think that [indiscernible] project should happen, but we've known for some time that we needed to manage our overall portfolio in that area by adding additional capacity. Last year, we added some additional capacity around what we already had, anticipating you can have some scheduling [indiscernible]. I think further, probably the greatest near-term impact becomes the seasonal differential challenge. Especially as production and pricing resumes and if you get production come back online, you get a differential challenge. We're trying to manage that through basis hedging. Our overall transportation portfolio pricing is very low in that area. And so managing that to the markets we serve, managing the -- any kind of basis challenge with further hedging, we certainly are doing and we'll watch it closely. Randy may have some other comments for you, but we feel pretty good about where we sit relative to that right now.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree with everything Bill said. Probably the only thing and color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware, the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year, yesterday. And then there's the 90-day period after that. So th
componenttext: Yes, I agree with everything Bill said. Probably the only thing and color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware, the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year, yesterday. And then there's the 90-day period after that. So the project has been certainly pushed back a little bit, but as Bill said, we feel really good about our overall portfolio out of northeast PA and Southwest Virginia. And what we had was a 44k, 44,000 a day volume on Atlantic Sunrise. So...

componenttext: Yes, Rover has received their final EIS. And there's actually an expectation, I believe, by the industry in the market that they'll receive some notification here very soon at the exploration of the 90-day period. So today, I think all the feedback we're getting from the pipeline is they remain confident on that, and be able to start construction fairly soon.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: okay. my second question would be on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic in NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachian acreage to take
componenttext: okay. my second question would be on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic in NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachian acreage to take advantage of that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way we are doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do is in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to
componenttext: Yes, I think the way we are doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do is in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to the company from each of the areas, and we rank them. And as we're working through that planning process, and we see further and further signs of some clear strengthening of NGLs, you get some of the wells move around in that positioning. And so yes, it's entirely likely that as you look at where that mix falls out and fit by the time we issue guidance, that you see it move around. We are -- I'm a firm believer in leveraging every strength you have. And because we have -- we're vertically integrated. We have our own rigs, we have our flexibility to move around. We have capacity in each of the areas. We need to take advantage of that and be able to be agile in working through that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What are your wells costing by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with larger completions?
componenttext: What are your wells costing by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with larger completions?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well the -- typically in northeast PA where we're looking at still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because the service [ph] prices right now are very favorable. We now in t
componenttext: Well the -- typically in northeast PA where we're looking at still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because the service [ph] prices right now are very favorable. We now in the very large jobs we're pumping in West Virginia and Southwest Appalachia, we are adding $1 million to $2 million to our well costs. They're up to $8 million on the well costs, $8 million, $8.5 million, but we're getting a great return. I believe the work we did at the end of '15, we think on that $2 million we invested extra on those, we got 2 PVI on that $2 million. So -- the return is very healthy on the incremental sand and cluster spacing. Fayetteville is still right around $3 million on our wells. We have our own sand mine. And so the sand is very cheap there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: In West Virginia, 7 million on a 7,500 or 7,800-foot lateral in rich gas and about 6.5  on 6,000-foot lateral in those lean gas.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, 3 25 versus 3 50 gas price environment for 2017?
componenttext: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, 3 25 versus 3 50 gas price environment for 2017?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology or completion practices, fl
componenttext: Yes, as I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology or completion practices, flow back practice and drilling practices, what impact that has on the Fayetteville. I remain in the same place that I spoke about earlier that you have some targeted testing. And if that opens up new frontiers and we put that into the mix, we have some land capturing the 2 other divisions not Fayetteville. Absence of those, it may be 1 or 2 other things, then you start looking at relative economics to the northeast. A big piece of our capital productivity improvement, big piece really our overall performance improvement is allocating capital to the highest best use of that capital. And today with current technology and commercial terms and all the other things that go into that, our 2 northeast assets, by and large, have that advantage. And so in the first pileup of projects, the majority of it obviously close to the northeast. And as see you're seeing right now, we have a rig in Fayetteville that's focusing on Moorefield, it's focusing on some other testing, and we've got some other things we're working on. And then the rest of the activities and the other 2 plays. We challenge the teams all the time, and they take this challenge very well. you can see from our results, it shows through. Each group, while they're working for the whole of the company, they are driving, in their own backyard, driving margin improvements, driving productivity and well improvements and major inroads into the water management of any of these divisions. And you move the needle. So there's a lot of very exciting testing going on around water management and around different techniques. It can move the dial. So as you work through the remainder of this year and continue this, the planning for '17, all of that will be taken into account. But the headline for you is really it's all about economic value and driving economic value that what we have. So the bias, the current view of this obviously goes to capturing that value in the northeast.

componenttext: If they are, then certainly, they would compete in the investment stack and you'd go from there. I'm going to do capital allocation based off of proof. I don't know whether, at this 10 seconds, [ph] whether we'll do more and more field testing next year, or we will gain enough to be able to sort of lay that all out and put it again in the priority stack.

[indiscernible] 6 months, doing a lot of work with paper and a lot of challenge across divisions and in divisions. is kind of stepped up and we like the early results we've seen. I think that's -- we're seeing some positive things that may be changing that.

Are we accelerating EURs, are we opening up new recovery percentages, all that? so this not been on all that long. And so I would guard against adding to EUR at this time. What is clear is when they come on and flow at this rate, you're accelerating value. And that is -- that's our driver is trying to figure out how we maximize value. As soon as we get a bit more of those under our belt, we are going to kind of fund, but it's awkward time right now. We've been offline in the drilling and completions area for 6 months. We've come back with a just an aggressively strong performance -- but it's too early it, and I don't want to lead you down a path that we can't confirm.

componenttext: A couple of questions. One, I think Bill referenced ethane. Can you just talk about what type of leverage you have to that, and what that could mean as far as margin and pricing? I know I have  obviously NGL behind, but can you expand on that a little more?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Randy. We have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our capacity. so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also, ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do start impacting kind of
componenttext: Yes, this is Randy. We have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our capacity. so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also, ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do start impacting kind of the wet versus dry economics when we start seeing some significant shift in ethane think. And the longer-term outlook, given the crackers that are under construction as we speak for demand in the Mont Belvieu area, is very significant. We're looking at over 600,000 to 700,000 barrels a day of demand on top of a base that is 1.2. You couple that with export capacity. that's why you see a rather strong outlook for ethane, which we have some -- certainly have some good exposure to.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.
componenttext: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, I think what you have to think about is you look at forward crude, and depending on what that -- your view of that is. You look at our cash flow that our assets can generate. And then you look at the capital that investing within cash flow
componenttext: At this point, I think what you have to think about is you look at forward crude, and depending on what that -- your view of that is. You look at our cash flow that our assets can generate. And then you look at the capital that investing within cash flow would add up to. And that's how we intend to be thinking about setting these budgets and plans. You look at assurance of that. We have a 3-year rolling hedging program that the front year's hedged about where you see we're at for '17. And then you look at the 2 following years. And we want to have rigor and discipline around rolling those in, taking into account market forces and economics of the program and investments. But I think right now, it would be prudent for you to look at that from the standpoint of hedging within -- or not hedging, but investing within cash flow as that's what we think is prudent.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jack. the rotary steerables has helped us getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting in zone. Before, they were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance in the wells is that -- it's a combinat
componenttext: This is Jack. the rotary steerables has helped us getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting in zone. Before, they were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance in the wells is that -- it's a combination of landing in the proper zone and completion techniques. The Moore sand is definitely making better wells, but if you don't get them in zone, doesn't matter how much sand you put in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing we're looking at, and we do it all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so upsize meter run
componenttext: The other thing we're looking at, and we do it all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so upsize meter runs or upsized production facilities. And I'm not talking about massive upsizing, go from 2 to 3-inch and you got a huge benefit. Looking at tubing design in history, we've done some modified tubing design. we've got some tubing as well in different parts of the company. we're applying all of those learnings back to the assets as well. So we'll continue to see the components improve the overall performance. And as we can triangulate around well, I think sand is contributing this much and better. Different flowback regimes or different surface facilities contributed t that much. We can share that with you, but we're getting solid performance out of each component.

componenttextpreview: Yes, kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very up close to a dollar, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. acquired as much t
componenttext: Yes, kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very up close to a dollar, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. acquired as much transportation as we needed to do 2 things, one, get an early ramp in the business. And assuming pipes come in when -- [indiscernible] come in, we can ramp that thing at 35% a year for the next 3 years comfortable. we wanted to look at where the pipe gets built. So committing our right pipes in the right place to access our acreage was really important. And we stepped back. 16 Bcf a day of pipeline capacity, excluding expansion capacity, being built all in one area is a lot of capacity. And taking on long-term commitments, which end up having to drill into or whatever, didn't make any sense to us at all. And so we said we're wait. Because we do believe and, I think the industry shares this with us, that there will come an inflection point in the -- all of this expansion were the cause of those. especially when you get into any expansion type capacity, the cost of that comes down. and we will get to that at a later date as costs come down. and the terms get more rationalized. We also have the opportunity to enter firm sales capacity where we are making sales into other consuming demand-side in capacity. So we'll continue to work that. And Randy may have some additional color put on that. the high level, it's kind of our philosophy.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that and Bill touched on it as we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The outlook again is one where we think structurally over time improve's annual continue. What we have today in FT, we're very comfortable with pipes that will be coming online. And we'll continue to watch the that feel very confident about our position as it stands today.

componenttext: First thing I wanted to ask was this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&P's are [indiscernible] lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, you're also increasing lateral length in your Fayetteville and Moorefield tests as well as the 2 Appalachia areas.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We are analyzing -- we were up virtually 100% in zone and all things we talked about it. wha
componenttext: Yes, where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We are analyzing -- we were up virtually 100% in zone and all things we talked about it. what we're doing is analyzing that flowback. We have 4 of those wells I believe in 2 areas. it's some of our longest that we have. And we -- the trick is making sure that you're getting contribution out of the full lateral length and then when you -- rerun economics. It's not about flow rate or IP . it's about well economics. make sure that these extended reach laterals, you're getting the contribution out of the whole thing for the investment that you're making. And it's a risk-reward balance. But we do as we look to block up land, we are consistently -- so for example in the , started out in West Virginia a 7,500-foot type of lateral. I think some of our latest averages are like 7,800. We'll continue to block up acreage and trade and exchange, so we can get those out there while we are testing these longer reach. Moorefield laterals are longer. The Fayetteville well laterals are longer as well. So the trend is longer, but we will make sure that the value per risk foot and all of that makes sense.

componenttext: Just little higher-level question of Fayetteville close, if are looking longer term, is there an argument for high-grading or downsizing the assets for sales or acreage release, in other words, the more challenged locations? also wondering how the Fayetteville's midstream might affect your thinking on that point the.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions we do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. we are seeing the appli
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions we do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. we are seeing the application of commercial and technical and operating expertise be applied in an even greater pace that is unlocking additional opportunities. Certainly, our midstream business is integral to that. The agility that we have, the ability to move back and forth, the ability to be flexible as a corporation, again, not drilling into somebody else's midstream contracts or not drilling into firm transportation that you've overcommitted to, any of those kinds of things, it's a balance. I think we see the Fayetteville as a vast resource that continues to generate cash flow. Any of these assets are certainly assets that you look at that can great greater value, doing something different than I'm doing now, we work that routinely. Where are they on for the curve, or you take a subset of it. we did a transaction in West Virginia on some acreage we weren't even going to get to until 2023. So it wasn't that it was not economic. It's just so long dated that if we for able to accelerate that value at a good value to it. So I think we continue to look at it as the answer. We don't want to put ourselves in a place where we do a because we've done b.. We want them to be economically synchronized, and we think we get more value

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you and thank you all for being here today and taking interest in what we are doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that
componenttext:
Well, thank you and thank you all for being here today and taking interest in what we are doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that they're each set up for you can expect even more results and even better results as we go forward in time. we believe that we recaptured the company this year. We've got a clearer path to capturing and delivering value-creating growth. And we're doing all of that in a rising gas price environment. And positioning yourself to capitalize in a rising gas price environment is a big piece of that objective. Our portfolio's primed to deliver impressive well results as we learn from all of the things we've talked about today. And our firm transportation portfolio allows us the flexibility to maneuver and navigate and work through an ever-changing basis environment and ever-changing regulatory environment and ever-changing pricing environment.  So we'll continue to devise and implement innovative drilling and operating techniques and efficiencies. We will -- we are -- we have what we call around here an aggressive assault on improving margin. And so every individual in this company is driven by, incentivized by the quest to reduce costs, improve the operating results of every part of the business. So we have it on the revenue side. We have it on the cost side. And we are committed to continue to increase that margin. And finally, we will maintain the rigor, capital allocation, capital discipline, financial responsibility that we've demonstrated so far this year and is the hallmark of our company. 
So I want to thank you again for joining us on the call today, all the questions. We look forward to seeing you along the road and hope you all have a great weekend.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to Southwestern Energy Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Michael Hancock, Director of Investor Relations for Southwestern Energy Company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry, our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron, our Seni
componenttext:
Thank you, Doug. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry, our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron, our Senior Vice President of Operations; and Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of Corporate Development.
If you've not received a copy of last night's press release regarding our third quarter 2016 financial and operating results, you can find a copy on our website at swn.com.
Also I'd like to point out that many of the comments during this teleconference are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties affecting outcomes. Many of these are beyond our control and are discussed in more detail in the Risk Factors and the Forward-looking Statements sections of our annual and quarterly filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although we believe the expectations expressed are based on reasonable assumptions, they are not guarantees of future performance and actual results or developments may differ materially.
We may also refer to some non-GAAP financial measures, which help facilitate comparisons across periods and with peers. For any non-GAAP measures we use, a reconciliation to the nearest corresponding GAAP measure can be found in our earnings release available on our website.
I'll now turn the call over to Bill Way to discuss our recent activity and results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, and good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us on our call today.This year has been one of unwavering focus in SWN. And that focus is on our commitments that we laid out in February, namely to strengthen our balance sheet, agg
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael, and good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us on our call today.
This year has been one of unwavering focus in SWN. And that focus is on our commitments that we laid out in February, namely to strengthen our balance sheet, aggressively improve margin, optimize the portfolio and remain agile, enabling us to be ready to capture opportunities to add value as the commodity price environment improves. And we're delighted to be here today to talk with you about this and talk about another quarter in which we delivered on those commitments.
I'd like to start by thanking the Southwestern team for all that has been accomplished so far this year. We've tackled a number of different challenges and set the company up for significant value creation as we finish up 2016 and prepare to move on to 2017. This year's accomplishments are a direct reflection of the commitment and dedication that each employee brings to the work every day, and I commend you for all that you do and all that you've done.
When we spoke last quarter, we discussed our plans to reinitiate investment in drilling and completion activities as a result of our strengthened balance sheet, the improving commodity price environment and our ability to assure solid returns provided by our commitment to prudent hedging and disciplined risk management. We'll provide more details about this in a few minutes. However, I can tell you that the learning, planning and preparation that each of the teams focused on during the pause in drilling and completions activity resulted in an extremely successful reinitiation of our drilling and completion operations.
As expected, we now have 5 rigs running company-wide: 2 in Northeast Appalachia, 2 in Southwest Appalachia and one in Fayetteville. The drilling results have been better than expected as we've seen record performance in drilling times that are even better than when we halted activity at the end of 2015.
However, speed is only part of the story. We've also been able to stay within our targeted zone over 95% of the time, which can be as narrow as 10 feet. Steering the well fully in zone supports the completion optimization by placing the entire length of the lateral in the integral that is most favorable for fracture stimulation and initiation. These impressive results have been driven by the learnings we captured from drilling and completing wells on paper during the first half of the year and applying these learnings now as we resume activity.
Additionally, the utilization of technology such as rotary steerable tools and other technologies are now standard on many of our wells. The activity in the second half of this year primes the portfolio for a robust 2017.
Regarding 2017, while we have not approved next year's capital program, at current strip prices, we expect cash flow to be in excess of $1 billion. We've had some questions on maintenance capital for next year. So let me reconfirm that the maintenance capital required to hold 2017 annual volumes flat at 2016 levels is only $700 million, given our improved capital efficiency and the benefits of flow -- flowing from our recent restart activity of approximately 150 Bcf equivalent of incremental 2017 production from the wells that we are drilling and completing during the second half of this year. With this quarter's impressive restart of activity, we also fully expect to arrest our production decline by the end of the year, this year, 2016, after which we will be back on the growth trajectory.
Reduced overall decline and resumption of value-added growth are both the results of our work to improve the performance of our vast portfolio. This $700 million in maintenance capital is an all-in capital number, including capitalized interest and expenses.
Closing this part of the discussion, while the maintenance capital is approximately $700 million, this is well below the expected more than $1 billion in cash flow for 2017 that I mentioned earlier at current strip prices. We plan to watch the impacts of the winter weather on 2017 prices and issue public guidance in February.
Let me now move on to our marketing and commercial activities. As is historically the case, we experienced our widest differentials for the year in the third quarter. Our overall discount, inclusive of differentials and transport costs, was $1.03 per Mcf lower than average NYMEX settlement pricing compared to $1 per Mcf lower than average NYMEX settlement pricing during the third quarter of 2015. This slight widening of the 2016 quarter was influenced largely by regional storage levels being at or near capacity and the percentage of total production from our Northeast assets increasing versus guidance.
Factoring in the forecasted gains of approximately $0.03 per Mcf on basis hedges currently in place, the company anticipates its total company discount to NYMEX for the year will be at the high end of guidance range or about $0.83 per Mcf.
We do believe that the current challenges facing the Appalachia Basin are a short-term issue and that the quality and quantity of our transportation portfolio in our Appalachian Basin businesses is robust and allows us both strong access to markets and growth opportunities this year and beyond. Over the long-term, our view of -- on improving regional basis differentials has not changed. And we expect the projected capacity additions out of the greater Appalachian region to come online over the next few years. These pipeline projects have robust economics and are of high quality, and we remain confident that the capacity for these pipeline projects gets overbuilt, albeit not without some scheduling challenges on individual projects.
Lastly, we are encouraged by the strengthening of NGL pricing for 2016 and how the NGL demand picture, particularly ethane, seems to be shaping up over the next few years. Given SWN's capacity on ATEX, we are in a strong position to capitalize on rising ethane prices at Mont Belvieu as projects making up the estimated 620,000 barrels a day of new demand begin to come online between now and 2019. With our vast resource position and the optionality provided by the wet gas window of Southwest Appalachia, increased NGL prices materially enhance the margins provided from that area.
With that, let me turn over to Craig to discuss some of our financial highlights from the third quarter. And then, we'll have Jack talk a bit more about some operations.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. I thought I would start this morning by summarizing the steps we have taken to strengthen the balance sheet this year, since many of them were in progress at the end of the second quarter.In the third quarter, we co
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. I thought I would start this morning by summarizing the steps we have taken to strengthen the balance sheet this year, since many of them were in progress at the end of the second quarter.
In the third quarter, we completed the equity offering for $1.25 billion, of which a portion was used to retire $700 million in 2018 debt maturities, with $500 million earmarked for resumption of drilling and completion activities. Additionally, in the third quarter, we closed the previously announced acreage divestiture in Southwest Appalachia. As you saw in last night's release, net debt as of September 30 was $3.2 billion, down from $4.8 billion at the end of the second quarter.
And as a reminder, when we amended the bank agreement, its structure changed from our historical revolving credit facility. The new credit facility is supplemented by the fully drawn $1.2 billion secured term loan, which we expect to utilize for liquidity purposes and result in large cash balances going forward compared to our historical amounts.
We have made great strides strengthening the balance sheet this year and expect net debt-to-EBITDA for 2017 to be in the high 2s, assuming current price levels. With these actions and the improved commodity price environment, we are confident in our trajectory and, therefore, have no other asset sale plans imminent or of a material nature. In the normal course, we will continue to evaluate options and opportunities, but are confident with our portfolio and balance sheet where it stands today.
In the third quarter, we continued to add to our hedge position. We have now hedged 535 Bcfe -- Bcf, excuse me, of 2017 production, of which approximately half of these positions are collars providing upside exposure to improving prices. On these 2017 hedges, we have a weighted average strike price for the swaps and purchase puts of $3 per Mcf. We have also been actively adding financial and physical basis hedges to the portfolio where we currently have 75 Bcf protected in the fourth quarter and 196 Bcf protected in 2017. These hedging activities will help us achieve our expected returns, providing downside protection while also retaining upside potential as prices improve.
With the financial strengthening steps taken in 2016, we are now positioned to drive value generation with our premier assets.
I will now turn it over to Jack to discuss some of the details of our operational results in the third quarter.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Craig. Good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned earlier, we have successfully reinitiated our drilling and completion activities, which was a primary focus of the third quarter for operations. It's not often that you completely halt drilling and
componenttext:
Thanks, Craig. Good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned earlier, we have successfully reinitiated our drilling and completion activities, which was a primary focus of the third quarter for operations. It's not often that you completely halt drilling and completion work for 6 months and then ramp up to 5 rigs in such a short period of time as we have this year. The success of this resumption demonstrates our differentiating agility as a company.
While returning to drilling and completions, we did not lose sight of the importance of our 2016 strategic initiatives, evidenced by once again hitting the top end of our production guidance at 211 Bcfe, while continuing our focus on improving margins. In particular, we reduced our lease operating expenses on a unit of production basis for the fifth quarter in a row.
In each of our areas, we continue to push the boundaries of our completion design. We are experimenting with increased proppant volumes with tests in Southwest Appalachia reaching up to 5,000 pounds per foot. We are also challenging ourselves to find the technical limits of these solutions. With such a vast number of drilling locations in the area, determining the optimal proppant loading will significantly increase the value of this play.
Our proppant testing is not just limited to Southwest Appalachia. We are also testing this in each of our other operating areas. In Fayetteville, we are testing over 2x as much proppant as our historical averages were. We expect to have some preliminary results on our next call, but the early indications are promising.
In Southwest Appalachia, we completed 8 wells in the third quarter and plan to connect 9 wells to sales by -- prior to the end of the year. While we did not turn on any wells to sales in the third quarter, we continue to see strong well performance from our Ridgetop Land Ventures Pad in Wetzel County, which came online in the fourth quarter of 2015. As a result, we have increased our lean gas type curves for the second time this year to approximately 25 Bcfe based on 7,500 foot laterals. The wells that we have drilled and completed there continue to outperform the offset wells drilled by the previous operator by as much as 40%. As we look forward, this asset provides substantial optionality where capital could be allocated to the wet or dry gas targets depending on commodity prices.
Moving to Northeast Appalachia, we currently have 2 rigs running which were the first 2 rigs to be mobilized. As Bill mentioned, the preparation for the reinitiation of activity resulted in some exceptional accomplishments. For the quarter, we have achieved a record total drill depth time of less than 8 days from reentry to reentry, which is 5% faster than the fourth quarter of 2015. Included in these results was one well drilled over 4,700 foot of lateral in just 24 hours, a company record in the area.
On the completion size -- side, we have tested reduced cluster spacing to increase well performance. This, when coupled with the optimized flow techniques we're using, expect to materially improve the flow rates. For example, the Racine pad we brought on in Susquehanna County this quarter came online at greater than 50 million cubic feet a day from just 3 wells. We plan to continue testing these techniques in the fourth quarter, and we'll discuss further as we have more information.
Moving to Fayetteville. We hit a very big milestone there during the third quarter where we surpassed 5 trillion cubic feet of production since our inception in 2004. Even with the recent reduction in rig count, this play still produces approximately 2% of the nation's gas supply and contributed over $60 million to the company in cash flow in the third quarter.
We continued our testing efforts in Fayetteville during the quarter on the Moorefield Shale, which lies just below the Fayetteville Shale. We brought online one Moorefield well at the end of June that had an initial production rate of 6.2 million cubic feet of gas per day, a lateral length of approximately 7,300 feet and an estimated EUR of over 4 Bcf.
This continues the encouraging results we've seen since the beginning of 2015. The 7 Moorefield wells brought online since the beginning of the year in '15 averaged an additional -- initial production rate of 7.2 million cubic feet a day, a lateral length of approximately 6,950 feet and an estimated EUR of over 5 Bcfe. We will continue watching the long-term performance of these wells to determine the aerial extent of the acreage prospective for this interval. With the potential of the Moorefield and the impact of increased proppant loading in the Fayetteville that we discussed earlier, we are encouraged that these, along with other initiatives being tested in the play, could significantly lower the breakeven price for the play and help it compete with opportunities available in the Appalachian portion of the portfolio.
This concludes today's prepared comments. So we'll now turn it back to the operator, who will explain the procedure for asking questions.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

And when could that occur?

componenttext: This is Jack. As far as rig count for the $700 million of maintenance capital, that would be less rigs then we're running today, that would be right around 3 rigs, maybe 3.5 rigs for the year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Capital efficiency has gone up as we drill more and more in the Northeast, and so we are able to do more and more with fewer rigs. And our, I think, well count becomes probably the key question. As you look at our hedges, and Randy talked a little bit abo
componenttext: Capital efficiency has gone up as we drill more and more in the Northeast, and so we are able to do more and more with fewer rigs. And our, I think, well count becomes probably the key question. As you look at our hedges, and Randy talked a little bit about it, but as you look at our hedge positions -- as we look at our capital program, we feel very assured on delivering the value that we need as our capital -- as we look at gas prices and we see -- if they increase further than they are, then we will make some adjustments to our plans at that time. And our objective is to invest it in cash flow. And as that cash flow changes or rises, I guess, the option is to move forward. The rigs are -- our rigs were very flexible in terms of what we can turn on and turn off. And so we can be very agile in that view as we get closer to February.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. No. I'm not trying to front run your guidance. Maybe the better question I should ask more specific is that at the current 5 rig count, what does that imply for annualized CapEx then?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we haven't set our 2017 plan. My only reason for bringing up the $700 million, 2 points: One, just to make sure people understood that point. And there's a good amount of upside. We're returning back to flat production using that -- just main
componenttext: Well, again, we haven't set our 2017 plan. My only reason for bringing up the $700 million, 2 points: One, just to make sure people understood that point. And there's a good amount of upside. We're returning back to flat production using that -- just maintenance capital. And then, we'll analyze and look at the markets as we approve our budget and, in the end, look for opportunities to either go faster or drill more as economics and cash flow afford.

componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Randy Curry. We do believe that it's a question of when, not if. And so, right now, our differentials for '17 are at the strip levels. And the strip is also indicating out into the future, '18 and '19, some structural improvement, and that's consistent with what we're modeling.

componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at Marcellus, and I don't -- these numbers probably don't have all of the improvements in them yet. We're working on that. But Marcellus' economic wells are $2.60, $2.63 kind of range on pricing, that's a 10% kind of return. West Virginia is probably dry. It's probably $2.50. I don't have a wet one with the newer kind of outlook on gas pricing. We can get that to you, but -- I mean, not gas pricing, but ethane improvements. But the portfolio looks very positive for opportunities to invest and make the returns we need in that range. If you look at 1.3 PVI numbers, they're probably in the $2.80s to $2.90s for each of those 2 areas.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Doug, this is Craig. In Fayetteville, kind of just a follow-up on Bill's notes or Bill's comments, Fayetteville, certainly at current prices, with the high 17, certainly looks good. What we're seeing in these early results -- we talked about these IPs and certainly testing Moorefield, continues to push that breakeven down. But as we've kind of seen kind of layout based on historical results in our IR deck, Fayetteville at $3 flat gives you about 500 well locations. So you can maybe push that a little bit lower. And certainly, with new results, we can continue to push. And that really kind of goes with all locations. As we continue to drive cost out of the system and improve production rates or EURs, that helps, but the numbers Bill quoted on our Appalachian assets is fair.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
