componenttext: Another comment we have, just one more thing on that. In the Fayetteville, we're doing some Moorefield drilling right now. We don't have -- the results are kind of early days, but those wells are coming on quite strong. So they have -- their economics are very solid. We're not doing anything that doesn't meet our 1.3 PVI investment hurdle at strip pricing, and that's excluding any hedge benefits. So you can kind of see that in each of the 3 areas, there's some depth in -- and some good depth in terms of well locations available to pursue.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question about your completion pace for your Q4. One of the things I was struck by was the uptick in play completions to 52 in Q4 from 9 in Q3. Can you talk about what the pattern of that -- of those completions will be over the fourth q
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question about your completion pace for your Q4. One of the things I was struck by was the uptick in play completions to 52 in Q4 from 9 in Q3. Can you talk about what the pattern of that -- of those completions will be over the fourth quarter? Is it going to be kind of flat over -- across the months, at least the quarter? Or are you more perhaps weighted towards the back end with the aim of capturing better local pricing? And what does that mean for your -- or do you have a [indiscernible] you can share with us for your '16 exit rate?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll -- let me talk a little bit about the pace of what we're doing, and then I'll do some exit rates at the back end. The -- there's a combination of things at work here. We've restarted the activity. We want to be as efficient as we can. And so rea
componenttext:
Yes. I'll -- let me talk a little bit about the pace of what we're doing, and then I'll do some exit rates at the back end. The -- there's a combination of things at work here. We've restarted the activity. We want to be as efficient as we can. And so really most of the completions in the fourth quarter will come across fairly ratably.
We expect that we will do -- our objective is to complete all the DUCs or as many DUCs as we can out of Fayetteville and then, in each of the other 2 assets, retain a level of DUCs only for efficiency. We don't -- when we halted activities at the end of the year, first part of this year, we had a DUC inventory. We then restarted. That's all going fine and we're just working them all. Since we don't anticipate a large amount of drilling in Fayetteville, we don't need a large amount of inventory in Fayetteville. So you get those to market and we're going to get returns on those. In the other 2 areas, you're going to be focused on capturing those that you can get to market in an efficient and timely manner to capitalize on those rising prices, while retaining enough that we can be efficient with our plan. So I think, at the end of the day, you'll see it ratably across the year.
And on volume, what was your question on volume?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the -- what implications that would have for exit rate on '16?
componenttext: Just the -- what implications that would have for exit rate on '16?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far as the fracture -- the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations
componenttext: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far as the fracture -- the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations. The only thing that impacts it -- the reason we don't have a little faster pace is water availability in Pennsylvania. And it comes and goes. They've been getting a lot of rain up there right now, so we don't foresee a problem.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, my follow-up question -- and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your 2017, so I guess, if we could deflect a part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, it looks l
componenttext: Got it. And then, my follow-up question -- and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your 2017, so I guess, if we could deflect a part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, it looks like by 16 in Q4 and then you say you will be back to the -- your target of that 60% inventory that you need for efficiency in '17. So that implies you're going to work down your DUC inventory by another roughly 25 over the course of the year. What -- compared to the 52 completions you're going to have in Q4, what do you think your completion rate per quarter is going to look like in '17?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like. And we haven't done that yet. So we're doing scenario planning around that now. W
componenttext: Well, you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like. And we haven't done that yet. So we're doing scenario planning around that now. We want to remain flexible between the 2 divisions up in the Northeast. And so as -- our DUC inventory, our rate of burn off of DUCs, our timing of wells and completions, the underlying theme will be it will be as efficient as we can to drive higher margin through lower cost and improved well performance. And it will be -- the makeup of that will be part of our capital plan.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Holly Stewart with Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Holly Stewart with Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit. How -- and, I guess, could you just talk through how you're viewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus, I guess, the slide deck is a littl
componenttext: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit. How -- and, I guess, could you just talk through how you're viewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus, I guess, the slide deck is a little higher and the wells' turn to sales projection for the year is a little bit -- I guess, year-to-date is not right on par with the forecast. So just trying to get a good sense for how you think it's going and maybe if -- to see your expectations here as you work through the fourth quarter?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. The headline is it's going terrific. Remember, there's 2 components to this. First component on the fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget.The seco
componenttext:
Sure. Yes. The headline is it's going terrific. Remember, there's 2 components to this. First component on the fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget.
The second thing that we talked about, and this is critical, is the frac intensity or the testing that's going on these -- on some of these wells. We're ramping sand loading in a couple of cases from 1,000 to 2,000 pounds a foot from 2,000 to 5,000 pounds a foot. And so those -- that testing impacts some of these wells. And to put that much more sand in that many more stages into a well takes longer to do. And so the only issue that we have right now -- and it's not really an issue. I miscalled it, it's an opportunity -- is we're doing some testing related to higher sand loading, which will have positive effects, we expect, on our wells. We've already seen that in West Virginia where we've gone up about 2,000 to almost 3,000 pounds in wells that are already online. And that, combined with how we're landing them and how we're flowing them and all of that, is improving their individual performance. Well, we expect that to be the case elsewhere.
And a nuance to all of that statement is we're, right now, focused on technical limit. So we've already proved out to ourselves that we can get a whole lot more sand in and then make a whole lot better wells, which makes them more economic. We want to know how much more can you do. And so we focused the folks on that. We'll do those wells and get them online and see, and then we'll bring them. And if we go to the place where much higher sand content and stage phasing, et cetera, becomes more of the norm after we test it, then we'll readjust our schedule and let you know what that looks like and go from there. That's the real big piece of that whole calendar issue.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And then, maybe just following up on the sand comment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000 well -- or the 5,000 pound per lateral foot test, and then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess, is that well online? Is there
componenttext: Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And then, maybe just following up on the sand comment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000 well -- or the 5,000 pound per lateral foot test, and then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess, is that well online? Is there anything to think through there? And then, was that a wet versus dry well? Just trying to think through, I guess, historically, you said you've been at 2,000 pounds. I'm just trying to think through how that could potentially impact the results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Holly, this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. They'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000 pound tests that we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the Ri
componenttext:
Holly, this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. They'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000 pound tests that we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the Ridgetop Land Ventures Pad. So we're building on that. Actually, stretching again, as Bill said, the technical limits to do that.
We have brought on, in Northeast PA, some of our -- the Racine pad I mentioned was one that we went to tighter cluster spacing, more stages. And that contributes to the time, but it -- we're definitely seeing the performance there. And it's -- they're with high sand already, the 2,000 pounds that we've adopted last year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you walk through these, you've got a couple of things going on. We've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have and they are all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000
componenttext:
So as you walk through these, you've got a couple of things going on. We've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have and they are all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000 pounds, that doesn't mean we're stopping there. That's a big leap for them. In the Northeast assets, we already have proof that, that, in certain areas, that you can go up past 3,000 pounds and get materially better wells. Now, we want to figure out, okay, how do we step that up and in what increment. I've got engineers that would like to do a whole lot more than even the numbers we've been talking about, but we want to be prudent about it as well. And then, we'll figure out where that economic threshold crosses that technical limit and optimize at that point and go forward.
So we'll -- we've got a lot of moving parts here. And the early indications, both from late last year and early now with some of the Racine work in Northeast Pennsylvania and some of these, is very encouraging and we'll continue to pursue that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JP Morgan.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I was wondering if you could comment on the potential delays on Atlantic Sunrise, I think you do have some modest volumes on that project, and what that means to SWN as we think about 2017, 2018 and your -- how you're thinking about capital allocati
componenttext: Bill, I was wondering if you could comment on the potential delays on Atlantic Sunrise, I think you do have some modest volumes on that project, and what that means to SWN as we think about 2017, 2018 and your -- how you're thinking about capital allocation?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly, on a relative basis to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the
componenttext:
Yes. Just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly, on a relative basis to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the different twists and turns that are going on with those projects. We think that both those projects should happen. But we've known for some time that we needed to manage our overall portfolio in that area by adding additional capacity. Last year, we added some additional capacity around what we already had, anticipating that you could have some scheduling challenges.
I think, further, probably the greatest near-term impact becomes the seasonal differential challenge, especially as production and pricing resumes. And if you get production come back online, you get the differential challenge. We're trying to manage that through basis hedging. Our overall transportation portfolio pricing is very low in that area. And so managing that to the markets we serve, managing the -- any kind of basis challenge with further hedging we certainly are doing, and we'll watch it closely.
Randy may have some other comments for you, but we feel pretty good about where we sit relative to that right now.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I agree with everything Bill said. Obviously, the only thing and color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware that the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year yesterday, and then there's a 90-day period after that. So
componenttext: Yes. I agree with everything Bill said. Obviously, the only thing and color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware that the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year yesterday, and then there's a 90-day period after that. So the project has been certainly pushed back a little bit. But as Bill said, we feel really good about our overall portfolio out of Northeast PA and Southwest Virginia. And what we had was a 44k -- 44,000 a day volume on Atlantic Sunrise.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up on that. Can you give us an update on Rover as well where you do have more significant -- from transportation exposure?
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up on that. Can you give us an update on Rover as well where you do have more significant -- from transportation exposure?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Rover has received their final EIS. And there's actually an expectation, I believe, by the industry and the market that they will receive some notification here very soon at the expiration of the 90-day period. So today, and I think all the feedback
componenttext: Yes. Rover has received their final EIS. And there's actually an expectation, I believe, by the industry and the market that they will receive some notification here very soon at the expiration of the 90-day period. So today, and I think all the feedback that we're getting from the pipeline is they remain confident on that and will be able to start construction fairly soon.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just my second question would be just on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic on NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your Southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachia ac
componenttext: Okay. And just my second question would be just on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic on NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your Southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachia acreage to take advantage of that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the way we are doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to the
componenttext:
Yes. I think the way we are doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to the company from each of the areas, and we rank them. And as we're working through that planning process and we see further and further signs of some clear strengthening of NGLs, you get some of the wells move around in that positioning. And so yes, it's entirely likely that as you look at where that mix falls out, in fact, by the time we issue guidance that you see it move around.
We are -- I'm a firm believer in leveraging every strength you have. And because we have our -- we're vertically integrated, have our own rigs, we have our flexibility to move around, we have capacity in each of the areas, we need to take advantage of that and be able to be agile in working through that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marshall Carver from Heikkinen Energy Advisers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marshall Carver from Heikkinen Energy Advisers.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What are your wells costing by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with the larger completions?
componenttext: Yes. What are your wells costing by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with the larger completions?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- typically, in Northeast PA, we're looking at about -- still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because of the service prices right now are very favorable.We now
componenttext:
Well, the -- typically, in Northeast PA, we're looking at about -- still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because of the service prices right now are very favorable.
We now, in the very large jobs we're pumping in West Virginia and Southwest Appalachia, we are adding $1 million to $2 million generally to our well cost. They're up to $8 million on the well cost, $8 million to $8.5 million, but we're getting a great return. I believe the work we did at the end of '15, we think, on that $2 million we invested extra on those, we got 2 PVI on that $2 million. So it's -- the return is very healthy on the incremental sand and the cluster spacing.
Fayetteville is still right around $3 million on our wells. We have our own sand mine, and so sand is very cheap there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In West Virginia, $7 million on a 7,500 or 7,800 foot lateral in rich gas and about $6.5 million on a 6,000 foot lateral in those lean gas.
componenttext: In West Virginia, $7 million on a 7,500 or 7,800 foot lateral in rich gas and about $6.5 million on a 6,000 foot lateral in those lean gas.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, $3.25 versus $3.50 gas price environment for 2017?
componenttext: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, $3.25 versus $3.50 gas price environment for 2017?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly, as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology or completion practices, flow
componenttext:
Yes. I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly, as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology or completion practices, flow back practices and drilling practices, what impact that has on the Fayetteville.
I remain in the same place that I spoke about earlier though is that you have some targeted testing, and if that opens up new frontiers then we put that into the mix. You have some land capture in the 2 other divisions, not Fayetteville. Absent of those and maybe one or 2 other things, then you start looking at relative economics to the Northeast. A big piece of our capital productivity improvement, a big piece of really our overall performance improvement is allocating capital to the highest best use of that capital. And today, with current technology and current commercial terms and all the other things that go into that, our 2 Northeast assets, by and large, are -- have that advantage. And so in the first pileup of projects, the majority of it obviously goes to the Northeast. But as see you're seeing right now, we have a rig in Fayetteville. It's focusing on Moorefield. It's focusing on some other testing. And we've got some other things we're working on. And then, the rest of the activity is in the other 2 places. And we challenge the teams all the time, and they take this challenge on very well. And as you can see from our results, it shows through. Each group, while they're working for the whole of the company, they are driving in their own backyard, driving margin improvements, driving productivity and well improvements, major inroads into the water management of any of these divisions and you move the needle. So there's a lot of very exciting testing going on around water management and around different techniques. It can move the dial.
So as we work through the remainder of this year and continue this -- the planning for '17, all of that would be taken into account. But the headline for you is really it's all about economic value and driving economic value out of what we have. And so the bias, the current view at this 10 seconds obviously goes to the capturing that value in the Northeast.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on the Moorefield point that you mentioned a couple of times. Obviously, that's baseload because you're going that now with the one rig you've added. Is it also the next -- is it also on the margin? In other words, if you do want to add
componenttext: Just to follow-up on the Moorefield point that you mentioned a couple of times. Obviously, that's baseload because you're going that now with the one rig you've added. Is it also the next -- is it also on the margin? In other words, if you do want to add more activity to the Fayetteville, would you actually do more Moorefield tests first with another rig over [indiscernible]? Or would you actually go do more development drilling to the Fayetteville? I know you mentioned that, that would have to come only if the returns are better than Appalachia, but let's just say they are.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If they are, then certainly, they would compete in the investment stack and you'd go from there. I'm going to do capital allocation based off of proof. And so the guys -- the teams are working those out and, certainly, we will go from there. I don't know
componenttext: If they are, then certainly, they would compete in the investment stack and you'd go from there. I'm going to do capital allocation based off of proof. And so the guys -- the teams are working those out and, certainly, we will go from there. I don't know whether at this 10 seconds whether we'll do more Moorefield testing next year or we'll gain enough to be able to sort of lay that all out and put it again in the priority stack.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. This is Craig. I may just add, as Bill indicated, Moorefield is certainly something that we like. We like what we've seen. But all of Fayetteville continues as the teams continue to work. In the 6 months, doing a lot of work on paper and a lot
componenttext:
Yes, Brian. This is Craig. I may just add, as Bill indicated, Moorefield is certainly something that we like. We like what we've seen. But all of Fayetteville continues as the teams continue to work. In the 6 months, doing a lot of work on paper and a lot of challenge across divisions and in divisions. It is kind of stepped up and we like the early results we've seen. So it continues to compete and it continues to [indiscernible] claw back.
If you had asked us that question 9 months ago, I think, in a $3 flat environment, our bias would have been most of the economics would have been in the north. I think that we're seeing some positive things that may be changing that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We challenge the team with thousands of well locations that are sitting there on the price curve, and they rise to that occasion. So we look forward to talking more about that as we learn more.
componenttext: We challenge the team with thousands of well locations that are sitting there on the price curve, and they rise to that occasion. So we look forward to talking more about that as we learn more.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kashy Harrison with Simmons.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Racine pad with the really impressive initial results, could you give us an idea of what your expectations are for year one cumulative production on an individual well? And then, could you also give us some idea as to what extent this optimized
componenttext: So on the Racine pad with the really impressive initial results, could you give us an idea of what your expectations are for year one cumulative production on an individual well? And then, could you also give us some idea as to what extent this optimized flowback technique would be incorporated into future wells being brought online?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the headline for you -- Jack may have some comments to go with it. The headline for you is it's just too early to tell. When we -- as a matter of practice just now and going forward and in the past, when we have some very high rate performanc
componenttext:
Yes. I think the headline for you -- Jack may have some comments to go with it. The headline for you is it's just too early to tell. When we -- as a matter of practice just now and going forward and in the past, when we have some very high rate performance out of some wells, given advancing sand loading or given advancing anything, we're going to study them, understand them, are we accelerating EURs, are we opening up new recovery percentages and all that. And so these have not been on all that long. And so I would guard against adding to EUR at this time. What is clear is when they -- as they come on and they flow at this rate, you're accelerating value. And that is -- our driver is trying to figure out how we maximize value.
As soon as we get a bit more of those under our belt, we are going to kind of fund, but it's awkward time right now. We've been offline in the drilling and completions area for 6 months. We've come back with a just an aggressively strong performance -- but it's too early it, and I don't want to lead you down a path that we can't confirm.

componenttext: Yes. I don't have that yet. It depends on where you allocate those, that capital and where you allocate those rigs and how many -- how the completions go. And the divisions are all very different. So I'll ask you to stay tuned on that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And then, as a follow-up, relatively heavy use of swaps in 2017 as part of the hedging program. Just curious as to why swaps versus greater use of collars?
componenttext: Very good. And then, as a follow-up, relatively heavy use of swaps in 2017 as part of the hedging program. Just curious as to why swaps versus greater use of collars?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our program is one where we just -- we try to find the right balance. And we want to have a portfolio of both swaps and collars to give us both some floor certainty and then also some opportunity for the upside. So it's really just a balanced approach.
componenttext: Our program is one where we just -- we try to find the right balance. And we want to have a portfolio of both swaps and collars to give us both some floor certainty and then also some opportunity for the upside. So it's really just a balanced approach.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, I think Bill referenced ethane. Can you just talk about what type of leverage you have to that and what that could mean as far as margin and pricing? I know I have  obviously NGL behind, but can you expand on that a little more
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, I think Bill referenced ethane. Can you just talk about what type of leverage you have to that and what that could mean as far as margin and pricing? I know I have  obviously NGL behind, but can you expand on that a little more?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Randy?
componenttext: Sure. Randy?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Randy. Yes. The -- we have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our ATEX capacity, and so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do sta
componenttext: Yes. This is Randy. Yes. The -- we have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our ATEX capacity, and so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do start impacting kind of the wet versus dry economics when we start seeing some significant shift in ethane. And the longer-term outlook, given the frackers that are under construction as we speak for demand in the Mont Belvieu area, is fairly significant. We're looking at over 600,000 to 700,000 barrels a day of demand on top of a base that is 1.2. You couple that with some export capacity, and that's why you see a rather strong outlook for ethane, which we have some -- certainly have some good exposure to.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.
componenttext: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, as it relates to -- remind me, how should we think about '17, '18 as far as framework? What are you putting up [indiscernible] as far as debt-to-EBITDA levels, within cash flow, [indiscernible] cash flow? I mean, how should
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, as it relates to -- remind me, how should we think about '17, '18 as far as framework? What are you putting up [indiscernible] as far as debt-to-EBITDA levels, within cash flow, [indiscernible] cash flow? I mean, how should we -- we could play along on pricing, but how should we be thinking about that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. At this point, I think that what you have to think about is you look at the forward curve, and depending on what that -- your view of that is, you look at our cash flow that our assets can generate, and then you look at the capital that investing wit
componenttext: Yes. At this point, I think that what you have to think about is you look at the forward curve, and depending on what that -- your view of that is, you look at our cash flow that our assets can generate, and then you look at the capital that investing within cash flow would add up to. And that's how we intend to be thinking about setting these budgets and plans. You look at assurance of that. We have a 3-year rolling hedging program that the front year's hedged about where you see we're at for '17. And then you look at the 2 following years. And we want to have rigor and discipline around rolling those in, taking into account market forces and economics of the program and investments. But I think right now, it would be prudent for you to look at that from the standpoint of hedging within -- or not hedging, but investing within cash flow as that's what we think is prudent.

componenttext: Okay. The Moorefield Shale, can you give us -- I wasn't sure if I heard it or not. But what do those wells costs right now relative to the Fayetteville wells?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you opened up your remarks, Bill, like talking about how you've basically been 95% within the zone or your target of where you want to land these laterals. You also talked about improvements of proppant loading. Are you seeing the biggest
componenttext: Okay. And then, you opened up your remarks, Bill, like talking about how you've basically been 95% within the zone or your target of where you want to land these laterals. You also talked about improvements of proppant loading. Are you seeing the biggest step change from that lateral landing from rotary steerables? Or is the performance that you see this year more of a function of sand loading? And where were you in terms of percentage of hitting zone in 2015?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jack. We're -- the rotary steerables have helped us in getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting in zone. Before, they were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance in the wells is that -- it
componenttext: This is Jack. We're -- the rotary steerables have helped us in getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting in zone. Before, they were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance in the wells is that -- it's a combination of landing in the proper zone and completion techniques. The Moore sand is definitely making better wells, but if you don't get them in zone, doesn't matter how much sand you put in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing we're looking at, and we do it all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look at your -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so upsize m
componenttext: The other thing we're looking at, and we do it all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look at your -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so upsize meter runs or upsized production facilities. And I'm not talking about massive upsizing, go from 2 to 3-inch and you got a huge benefit. Looking at tubing design, in history, we've done some modified tubing design, we've got some tubing as well in different parts of the company, and we're applying all of those learnings back towards these assets as well. So you'll continue to see the components improve the overall performance. And as we can triangulate around well, I think sand is contributing this much and better. As different flowback regimes or different surface facilities contribute to that much, we can share that with you, but we're getting solid performance out of each component.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

So it was probably mostly related to just sequencing and timing.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to a dollar, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquir
componenttext:
Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to a dollar, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquired as much transportation as we needed to do 2 things, one, get an early ramp on the business. And assuming the pipes come in where they are -- when they're supposed to come in, we can ramp that thing at 35% a year for the next 3 years comfortably.
We then wanted to look at where the pipes get built, so committing to the right pipes at the right place to access our acreage was really important. And then, we stepped back. 16 Bcf a day of pipeline capacity, excluding expansion capacity, being built all in one area is a lot of capacity. And taking on long-term commitments, which end up having to drill into or whatever, didn't make any sense to us at all. And so we said we're wait. Because we do believe and, I think the industry shares this with us, that there will come an inflection point in the -- all of this expansion were the cause of those. especially when you get into any expansion type capacity, the cost of that comes down. and we will get to that at a later date as costs come down. and the terms get more rationalized. We also have the opportunity to enter firm sales capacity where we are making sales into other consuming demand-side in capacity. So we'll continue to work that. And Randy may have some additional color put on that. the high level, it's kind of our philosophy.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The
componenttext:
Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The outlook, again, is one that we think structurally, over time, improves, and we'll continue that.
What we have today in FT we're very comfortable with, with the commitments that we have made on some pipes that will be coming online. And so we're -- we'll continue to watch that, but feel very confident about our position as it stands today.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

There will be some Midwest exposure in some of the capacity that we have that's to be built, but we also are very oriented towards the Gulf Coast as -- really as you look at kind of the Gulf Coast and Southeast, where the demand growth expectations are, that's certainly a value to us as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First thing I want to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so you're also increasing lateral l
componenttext: First thing I want to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so you're also increasing lateral length in your Fayetteville and Moorefield tests as well as in the 2 Appalachia areas.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We are analyzing that the -- we were up virtually 100% in zone and all things we talk
componenttext: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We are analyzing that the -- we were up virtually 100% in zone and all things we talked about it. what we're doing is analyzing that flowback. We have 4 of those wells I believe in 2 areas. it's some of our longest that we have. And we -- the trick is making sure that you're getting contribution out of the full lateral length and then when you -- rerun economics. It's not about flow rate or IP . it's about well economics. make sure that these extended reach laterals, you're getting the contribution out of the whole thing for the investment that you're making. And it's a risk-reward balance. But we do as we look to block up land, we are consistently -- so for example in the , started out in West Virginia a 7,500-foot type of lateral. I think some of our latest averages are like 7,800. We'll continue to block up acreage and trade and exchange, so we can get those out there while we are testing these longer reach. Moorefield laterals are longer. The Fayetteville well laterals are longer as well. So the trend is longer, but we will make sure that the value per risk foot and all of that makes sense.

componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions we do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. we are seeing the application of commercial and technical and operating expertise be applied in an even greater pace that is unlocking additional opportunities. Certainly, our midstream business is integral to that. The agility that we have, the ability to move back and forth, the ability to be flexible as a corporation, again, not drilling into somebody else's midstream contract or not drilling into firm transportation that you've overcommitted to, any of those kinds of things. It's a balance. And I think we see that Fayetteville is a vast resource that continues to generate cash flow. Any of these assets are certainly assets that you look at that can great greater value, doing something different than I'm doing now, we work that routinely. Where are they on for the curve, or you take a subset of it. we did a transaction in West Virginia on some acreage we weren't even going to get to until 2023. So it wasn't that it was not economic. It's just so long dated that if we for able to accelerate that value at a good value to it. So I think we continue to look at it as the answer. We don't want to put ourselves in a place where we do a because we've done b.. We want them to be economically synchronized, and we think we get more value

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you and thank you all for being here today and taking interest in what we are doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that
componenttext:
Well, thank you and thank you all for being here today and taking interest in what we are doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that they're each set up for you can expect even more results and even better results as we go forward in time. we believe that we recaptured the company this year. We've got a clearer path to capturing and delivering value-creating growth. And we're doing all of that in a rising gas price environment. And positioning yourself to capitalize in a rising gas price environment is a big piece of that objective. Our portfolio's primed to deliver impressive well results as we learn from all of the things we've talked about today. And our firm transportation portfolio allows us the flexibility to maneuver and navigate and work through an ever-changing basis environment and ever-changing regulatory environment and ever-changing pricing environment.  So we'll continue to devise and implement innovative drilling and operating techniques and efficiencies. We will -- we are -- we have what we call around here an aggressive assault on improving margin. And so every individual in this company is driven by, incentivized by the quest to reduce costs, improve the operating results of every part of the business. So we have it on the revenue side. We have it on the cost side. And we are committed to continue to increase that margin. And finally, we will maintain the rigor, capital allocation, capital discipline, financial responsibility that we've demonstrated so far this year and is a hallmark of our company. 
So I want to thank you for joining us on the call today. Thanks for all the questions. We look forward to seeing you along the road and hope you all have a great weekend.
