componenttext: It's greatly influenced by the seasonal effects. I would say there's probably right now about the same as this past year -- that I'm talking about.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this quarter, Northeast PA production was down, I think, more than the prior quarter. Just curious if you had shut in any volumes and just wondering on your typical operational plan. As you said in your remarks earlier, 3Q is typically your weak
componenttext: Okay. And this quarter, Northeast PA production was down, I think, more than the prior quarter. Just curious if you had shut in any volumes and just wondering on your typical operational plan. As you said in your remarks earlier, 3Q is typically your weakest pricing quarter of the year. Do you typically try to constrain volumes when prices are low? Or is it mitigated by some other basis swaps or other measures?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't normally constrain volumes unless prices get very low, which in the quarter they were actually not that -- at that point. There was a lot of maintenance went on, on different pipelines during the quarter that did hurt our production in the Northe
componenttext: We don't normally constrain volumes unless prices get very low, which in the quarter they were actually not that -- at that point. There was a lot of maintenance went on, on different pipelines during the quarter that did hurt our production in the Northeast a little. And we've brought on -- [indiscernible] the wells came on later in the quarter, the new wells that we didn't bring on. So it was normal decline generally.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we -- the investments that we did make early in the year, the benefit of that showed up in Q2. And so then you'll go [ph] 6 months without much of activity that'll do Q3. But as I said earlier, when you get to -- when you include the activity that we
componenttext: When we -- the investments that we did make early in the year, the benefit of that showed up in Q2. And so then you'll go [ph] 6 months without much of activity that'll do Q3. But as I said earlier, when you get to -- when you include the activity that we've got going on now and the improvement of the overall business, setting aside the activity we have going on now with just the overall improvement, we arrest decline by the end of Q4, and you're actually building back volume. So it was probably mostly related to just sequencing and timing.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing that was just pointed out to me that when we started -- restarted our drilling, you usually have simultaneous operations. You have some shut-in on the pads that you do actually curtail production, but it's really from a HS&E standpoint
componenttext: And the other thing that was just pointed out to me that when we started -- restarted our drilling, you usually have simultaneous operations. You have some shut-in on the pads that you do actually curtail production, but it's really from a HS&E standpoint that we do it. And so that goes in the second quarter. We had no operations going on. Third quarter, we did have some that contributed somewhat.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have minimal volume in the dailies. Most of our volume is under contract. So you have some just minimal volume. And if we don't cover cash costs, we don't -- we won't reduce it [ph]. But it doesn't show up on the radar. It's not material.
componenttext: And we have minimal volume in the dailies. Most of our volume is under contract. So you have some just minimal volume. And if we don't cover cash costs, we don't -- we won't reduce it [ph]. But it doesn't show up on the radar. It's not material.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ray Deacon from Coker & Palmer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ray Deacon from Coker & Palmer.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I was wondering if you could talk about your attempts to lock in additional firm transportation if you were to make the decision to ramp in the Southwest at this point, looking out to 2017, and keep the current rig count in place.
componenttext: Yes. I was wondering if you could talk about your attempts to lock in additional firm transportation if you were to make the decision to ramp in the Southwest at this point, looking out to 2017, and keep the current rig count in place.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to $1, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquired as
componenttext: Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to $1, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquired as much transportation as we needed to do 2 things, one, get an early ramp on the business. And assuming the pipes come in when they're supposed to come in, we can ramp that thing at 35% a year for the next 3 years comfortably. We then wanted to look at where the pipes get built, so committing to the right pipes at the right place to access our acreage was really important. And then, we stepped back. 16 Bcf a day of pipeline capacity, excluding expansion capacity being built all in one area is a lot of capacity. And taking on long-term commitments, which end up having to drill into or whatever, didn't make any sense to us at all. And so we said we'll wait because we do believe and, I think the industry shares this with us, that there will come an inflection point in the -- all this expansion where the cost of those and especially if you get into any expansion-type capacity, the cost of that comes down. and we will leg into that at a later date as that cost does come down and the terms get more rationalized. We also have the opportunity to enter and we have into firm sales capacity where we are making sales into other consuming-side, demand-side debt capacity. And so we'll continue to work that. And Randy may have some additional color he wants to put on that, but at a high level, that's kind of our philosophy.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The
componenttext: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The outlook, again, is one that we think structurally, over time, improves, and we'll continue that. What we have today in FT we're very comfortable with, with commitments that we have made on some pipes that will be coming online. And so we're -- we'll continue to watch that but feel very confident about our position as it stands today.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess, just one more follow-up on that is it seems as though some have noticed that you have less exposure to the Midwest relative to others. And is that something you see as critical to price realizations going forward?
componenttext: Great. I guess, just one more follow-up on that is it seems as though some have noticed that you have less exposure to the Midwest relative to others. And is that something you see as critical to price realizations going forward?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We want to have exposure -- a balanced portfolio and a broad portfolio. There will be some Midwest exposure in -- with some of the capacity that we have that's to be built, but we also are very oriented towards the Gulf Coast as -- really as you look at k
componenttext: We want to have exposure -- a balanced portfolio and a broad portfolio. There will be some Midwest exposure in -- with some of the capacity that we have that's to be built, but we also are very oriented towards the Gulf Coast as -- really as you look at kind of Gulf Coast and Southeast, where the demand growth expectations are, that's certainly a value to us as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for one last question. Our last question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: We have time for one last question. Our last question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First thing I wanted to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so are you also increasing latera
componenttext: First thing I wanted to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so are you also increasing lateral length in your Fayetteville and Moorefield tests as well as in the 2 Appalachia areas?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We're analyzing that the -- and we were up virtually 100% in zone and all the things
componenttext: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We're analyzing that the -- and we were up virtually 100% in zone and all the things that we've talked about. And what we're doing is analyzing that flowback. We have 4 of those wells, I believe, in 2 different areas are some of our longest that we have. And you want -- the trick is making sure that you're getting the contribution out of the full lateral length and that when you rerun economics, so it's not about flow rate or IP or any of that. It's about well economics. You make sure that these extended-reach laterals, you're getting the contribution out of the whole thing for the investment that you're making. And it's a risk-reward balance. But we do -- as we look to block up land, we are consistently -- so for example in the range, we started out in West Virginia a 7,500 foot target lateral. I think some of our latest averages are like 7,800. We'll continue to block up acreage in trade and exchange, so that you can get those out there while we're testing these longer-reach ones. The Moorefield laterals are longer. The Fayetteville well laterals are longer as well. So the trend is longer, but we will make sure that value per risked foot and all that makes sense.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little higher-level question on that Fayetteville to close, if -- looking at it longer term, is there an argument for high-grading and downsizing the assets through sales or acreage release, in other words, the more challenged locations? And I'm al
componenttext: Just a little higher-level question on that Fayetteville to close, if -- looking at it longer term, is there an argument for high-grading and downsizing the assets through sales or acreage release, in other words, the more challenged locations? And I'm also wondering how the Fayetteville's midstream might affect any thinking on that point.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions. We do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. We're seeing the applicat
componenttext: Yes, I think you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions. We do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. We're seeing the application of commercial and technical and operating expertise be applied in an even greater pace that is unlocking additional opportunities. Certainly, our midstream business is integral to that. The agility that we have, the ability to move back and forth, the ability to be flexible as a corporation, again, not drilling into somebody else's midstream contract or not drilling into the firm transportation that you've overcommitted to, any of those kinds of things. It's a balance. And I think we see that Fayetteville is a vast resource that continues to generate cash flow. Any of these assets are certainly assets that you look, say can I get greater value doing something different than I'm doing now. And we work that routinely. Where are they on their cost curve? Or you take a subset of it. We did a transaction in West Virginia on some acreage we weren't even going to get to until 2023. So it wasn't that it was not economic. It's just so long-dated that why -- if we're able to accelerate that value at a good value then it [indiscernible] do it. So I think we continue to look at it as the answer. We don't want to put ourselves in a place where we do a because we've done b. We want them to be economically synchronized, and we think that you add more value in the long run.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and thank you all for being here today and taking an interest in what we're doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout the call this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we
componenttext:
Well, thank you, and thank you all for being here today and taking an interest in what we're doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout the call this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that they're each set up to where you can expect to have even more results and even better results as we go forward in time. With the stability that we've recaptured in the company this year, we've got a clearer path to capturing and delivering value-creating growth. And we're doing all of that in a rising gas price environment. And positioning yourself to capitalize on a rising gas price environment is a big piece of that objective. Our portfolio's primed to deliver impressive well results as we learn from all the things we've talked about today. And our firm transportation portfolio allows us the flexibility to maneuver and navigate and work through an ever-changing basis environment and ever-changing regulatory environment and an ever-changing pricing environment. So we'll continue to devise and implement innovative drilling and operating techniques and efficiencies. We will -- we are -- we have what we call around here an aggressive assault on improving margin. And so every individual in this company is driven by, incentivized by the quest to reduce cost, improve the operating results of every part of the business. So you have it on the revenue side. You have it on the cost side. And we're committed to continue to increase that margin. And finally, we will maintain the rigor, capital allocation, capital discipline, financial responsibility that we've demonstrated so far this year and is a hallmark of our company. 
So I want to thank each of you for joining us on the call today. Thanks for all the questions. We look forward to seeing you along the road and hope you all have a great weekend.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to Southwestern Energy Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce Michael Hancock, Director of Investor Rela
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to Southwestern Energy Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Michael Hancock, Director of Investor Relations for Southwestern Energy Company.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry, our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron, our Seni
componenttext:
Thank you, Doug. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Bill Way, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Craig Owen, our Chief Financial Officer; Randy Curry, our Senior Vice President of Midstream; Jack Bergeron, our Senior Vice President of Operations; and Paul Geiger, Senior Vice President of Corporate Development.
If you've not received a copy of last night's press release regarding our third quarter 2016 financial and operating results, you can find a copy on our website at swn.com.
Also I'd like to point out that many of the comments during this teleconference are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties affecting outcomes. Many of these are beyond our control and are discussed in more detail in the Risk Factors and the Forward-looking Statements sections of our annual and quarterly filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although we believe the expectations expressed are based on reasonable assumptions, they are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results or developments may differ materially.
We may also refer to some non-GAAP financial measures which help facilitate comparisons across periods and with peers. For any non-GAAP measures we use, a reconciliation to the nearest corresponding GAAP measure can be found in our earnings release available on our website.
I'll now turn the call over to Bill Way to discuss our recent activity and results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, and good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us on our call today.This year has been one of unwavering focus in SWN. And that focus is on our commitments that we laid out in February, namely to strengthen our balance sheet, agg
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael, and good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us on our call today.
This year has been one of unwavering focus in SWN. And that focus is on our commitments that we laid out in February, namely to strengthen our balance sheet, aggressively improve margin, optimize the portfolio and remain agile, enabling us to be ready to capture opportunities to add value as the commodity price environment improves. And we're delighted to be here today to talk with you about this and to talk about another quarter in which we delivered on those commitments.
I'd like to start by thanking the Southwestern team for all that has been accomplished so far this year. We've tackled a number of different challenges and set the company up for significant value creation as we finish up 2016 and prepare to move on to 2017. This year's accomplishments are a direct reflection of the commitment and dedication that each employee brings to the work every day, and I commend you for all that you do and all that you've done.
When we spoke last quarter, we discussed our plans to reinitiate investment in drilling and completion activities as a result of our strengthened balance sheet, the improving commodity price environment and our ability to assure solid returns provided by our commitment to prudent hedging and disciplined risk management. We'll provide more details about this in a few minutes, however, I can tell you that the learning, planning and preparation that each of the teams focused on during the pause in drilling and completions activity resulted in an extremely successful reinitiation of our drilling and completion operations.
As expected, we now have 5 rigs running company-wide: 2 in Northeast Appalachia, 2 in Southwest Appalachia and 1 in Fayetteville. The drilling results have been better than expected as we've seen record performance in drilling times that are even better than when we halted activity at the end of 2015.
However, speed is only part of the story. We've also been able to stay within our targeted zone over 95% of the time, which can be as narrow as 10 feet. Steering the well fully in zone supports the completion optimization by placing the entire length of the lateral in the integral that is most favorable for fracture stimulation and initiation. These impressive results have been driven by the learnings we captured from drilling and completing wells on paper during the first half of the year and applying these learnings now as we resume activity.
Additionally, the utilization of technology such as rotary steerable tools and other technologies are now standard on many of our wells. The activity in the second half of this year primes the portfolio for a robust 2017.
Regarding 2017, while we have not approved next year's capital program, at current strip prices, we expect cash flow to be in excess of $1 billion. We've had some questions on maintenance capital for next year. So let me reconfirm that the maintenance capital required to hold 2017 annual volumes flat at 2016 levels is only $700 million, given our improved capital efficiency and the benefits of flow -- flowing from our recent restart activity of approximately 150 Bcf equivalent of incremental 2017 production from the wells that we are drilling and completing during the second half of this year. With this quarter's impressive restart of activity, we also fully expect to arrest our production decline by the end of the year, this year, 2016, after which we will be back on the growth trajectory.
Reduced overall decline and resumption of value-added growth are both the results of our work to improve the performance of our vast portfolio. This $700 million in maintenance capital is an all-in capital number, including capitalized interest and expenses.
Closing this part of the discussion. While the maintenance capital is approximately $700 million, this is well below the expected more than $1 billion in cash flow for 2017 that I mentioned earlier at current strip prices. We plan to watch the impacts of the winter weather on 2017 prices and issue public guidance in February.
Let me now move on to our marketing and commercial activities. As is historically the case, we experienced our widest differentials for the year in the third quarter. Our overall discount, inclusive of differentials and transport costs, was $1.03 per Mcf lower than average NYMEX settlement pricing compared to $1 per Mcf lower than average NYMEX settlement pricing during the third quarter of 2015. This slight widening of the 2016 quarter was influenced largely by regional storage levels being at or near capacity and the percentage of total production from our Northeast assets increasing versus guidance.
Factoring in the forecasted gains of approximately $0.03 per Mcf on basis hedges currently in place, the company anticipates its total company discount to NYMEX for the year will be at the high end of guidance range or about $0.83 per Mcf.
We do believe that the current challenges facing the Appalachian Basin are a short-term issue and that the quality and quantity of our transportation portfolio in our Appalachian Basin businesses is robust and allows us both strong access to markets and growth opportunities this year and beyond. Over the long term, our view of -- on improving regional basis differentials has not changed. And we expect the projected capacity additions out of the greater Appalachian region to come online over the next few years. These pipeline projects have robust economics and are of high quality, and we remain confident that the capacity for these pipeline projects gets overbuilt, albeit not without some scheduling challenges on individual projects.
Lastly, we are encouraged by the strengthening of NGL pricing for 2016 and how the NGL demand picture, particularly ethane, seems to be shaping up over the next few years. Given SWN's capacity on ATEX, we are in a strong position to capitalize on rising ethane prices at Mont Belvieu as projects making up the estimated 620,000 barrels a day of new demand begin to come online between now and 2019. With our vast resource position and the optionality provided by the wet gas window of Southwest Appalachia, increased NGL prices materially enhanced the margins provided from that area.
With that, let me turn over to Craig to discuss some of our financial highlights from the third quarter. And then, we'll have Jack talk a bit more about some operations.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. I thought I would start this morning by summarizing the steps we have taken to strengthen the balance sheet this year, since many of them were in progress at the end of the second quarter.In the third quarter, we co
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. I thought I would start this morning by summarizing the steps we have taken to strengthen the balance sheet this year, since many of them were in progress at the end of the second quarter.
In the third quarter, we completed the equity offering for $1.25 billion, of which a portion was used to retire $700 million in 2018 debt maturities with $500 million earmarked for resumption of drilling and completion activities. Additionally in the third quarter, we closed the previously announced acreage divestiture in Southwest Appalachia. As you saw in last night's release, net debt as of September 30 was $3.2 billion, down from $4.8 billion at the end of the second quarter.
And as a reminder, when we amended the bank agreement, its structure changed from our historical revolving credit facility. The new credit facility is supplemented by the fully drawn $1.2 billion secured term loan, which we expect to utilize for liquidity purposes and results in large cash balances going forward compared to our historical amounts.
We have made great strides strengthening the balance sheet this year and expect net debt to EBITDA for 2017 to be in the high 2s, assuming current price levels. With these actions and the improved commodity price environment, we are confident in our trajectory and, therefore, have no other asset sale plans imminent or of a material nature. In the normal course, we will continue to evaluate options and opportunities but are confident with our portfolio and balance sheet where it stands today.
In third quarter, we continued to add to our hedge position. We've now hedged 535 Bcfe -- Bcf, excuse me, of 2017 production, of which approximately half of these positions are collars providing upside exposure to improving prices. On these 2017 hedges, we have a weighted average strike price for the swaps and purchase puts of $3 per Mcf. We have also been actively adding financial and physical basis hedges to the portfolio where we currently have 75 Bcf protected in the fourth quarter and 196 Bcf protected in 2017. These hedging activities will help us achieve our expected returns, providing downside protection while also retaining upside potential as prices improve.
With the financial strengthening steps taken in 2016, we are now positioned to drive value generation with our premier assets.
I will now turn it over to Jack to discuss some of the details of our operational results in the third quarter.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Craig. Good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned earlier, we've successfully reinitiated our drilling and completion activities, which was a primary focus of the third quarter for operations. It's not often that you completely halt drilling and co
componenttext:
Thanks, Craig. Good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned earlier, we've successfully reinitiated our drilling and completion activities, which was a primary focus of the third quarter for operations. It's not often that you completely halt drilling and completion work for 6 months and then ramp up to 5 rigs in such a short period of time as we have this year. The success of this resumption demonstrates our differentiating agility as a company.
While returning to drilling and completions, we did not lose sight of the importance of our 2016 strategic initiatives evidenced by once again hitting the top end of our production guidance at 211 Bcfe while continuing our focus on improving margins. In particular, we reduced our lease operating expenses on a unit of production basis for the fifth quarter in a row.
In each of our areas, we continue to push the boundaries of our completion design. We are experimenting with increased proppant volumes with tests in Southwest Appalachia reaching up to 5,000 pounds per foot. We are also challenging ourselves to find the technical limits of these solutions. With such a vast number of drilling locations in the area, determining the optimal proppant loading will significantly increase the value of this play.
Our proppant testing is not just limited to Southwest Appalachia. We are also testing this in each of our other operating areas. In Fayetteville, we are testing over 2x as much proppant as our historical averages were. We expect to have some preliminary results on our next call, but the early indications are promising.
In Southwest Appalachia, we completed 8 wells in the third quarter and plan to connect 9 wells to sales by -- prior to the end of the year. While we did not turn on any wells to sales in the third quarter, we continue to see strong well performance from our Ridgetop Land Ventures Pad in Wetzel County, which came online in the fourth quarter of 2015. As a result, we've increased our lean gas type curves for the second time this year to approximately 25 Bcfe based on 7,500 foot laterals. The wells that we have drilled and completed there continue to outperform the offset wells drilled by the previous operator by as much as 40%. As we look forward, this asset provides substantial optionality where capital could be allocated to the wet or dry gas targets depending on commodity prices.
Moving to Northeast Appalachia, we currently have 2 rigs running, which were the first 2 rigs to be mobilized. As Bill mentioned, the preparation for the reinitiation of activity resulted in some exceptional accomplishments. For the quarter, we have achieved a record total drill depth time of less than 8 days from reentry to reentry, which is 5% faster than the fourth quarter of 2015. Included in these results was 1 well drilled over 4,700 foot of lateral in just 24 hours, a company record in the area.
On the completion size -- side, we have tested reduced cluster spacing to increase well performance. This, when coupled with the optimized flow techniques we're using, expect to materially improve the flow rates. For example, the Racine pad we brought on in Susquehanna County this quarter came online at greater than 50 million cubic feet a day from just 3 wells. We plan to continue testing these techniques in the fourth quarter, and we'll discuss further as we get more information.
Moving to Fayetteville. We hit a very big milestone there during the third quarter where we surpassed 5 trillion cubic feet of production since our inception in 2004. Even with the recent reduction in rig count, this play still produces approximately 2% of the nation's gas supply and contributed over $60 million to the company in cash flow in the third quarter.
We continue our testing efforts in Fayetteville during the quarter on the Moorefield Shale, which lies just below the Fayetteville Shale. We brought online one Moorefield well at the end of June that had an initial production rate of 6.2 million cubic feet of gas per day, a lateral length of approximately 7,300 feet and an estimated EUR of over 4 Bcf.
This continues the encouraging results we've seen since the beginning of 2015. The 7 Moorefield wells brought online since the beginning of the year in '15 averaged an additional -- initial production rate of 7.2 million cubic feet a day, a lateral length of approximately 6,950 feet and an estimated EUR of over 5 Bcfe. We will continue watching the long-term performance of these wells and determine the aerial extent of the acreage prospective for this interval. With the potential of the Moorefield and the impact of increased proppant loading in the Fayetteville that we discussed earlier, we are encouraged that these, along with other initiatives being tested in the play, could significantly lower the breakeven price for the play and help it compete with opportunities available in the Appalachia portion of the portfolio.
This concludes today's prepared comments. So we'll now turn it back to the operator, who will explain the procedure for asking questions.

componenttext: You all talk about the $700 million to maintain production in '16 to '17. Could you give us a sense of what rig count cadence is that? Is that currently the 5 rigs you're at? Or would that require additional activity? And the -- I guess, the follow-up question to that is based on the hedges you all have in place, which gives you, I guess, a fair decent certainty in terms of pricing next year, what is your view on adding to your current rig count? And when could that occur?

componenttextpreview: This is Jack. As far as rig counts for the $700 million of maintenance capital, that would be less rigs then we're running today. That would be right around 3 rigs, maybe 3.5 rigs for the year.
componenttext: This is Jack. As far as rig counts for the $700 million of maintenance capital, that would be less rigs then we're running today. That would be right around 3 rigs, maybe 3.5 rigs for the year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Capital efficiency has gone up as we drill more and more in the Northeast, and so we're able to do more and more with fewer rigs. And our, I think, well count becomes probably the key question. As you look at our hedges, and Randy can talk a little bit ab
componenttext: Capital efficiency has gone up as we drill more and more in the Northeast, and so we're able to do more and more with fewer rigs. And our, I think, well count becomes probably the key question. As you look at our hedges, and Randy can talk a little bit about it, but as you look at our hedge positions -- as we look at our capital program, we feel very assured on delivering the value that we need as our capital -- as we look at gas prices and we see -- if they increase further than they are, then we will make some adjustments to our plans at that time. And our objective is to invest it in cash flow. And as that cash flow changes or rises, it gives us options to move forward. The rigs are our rigs. We're very flexible in terms of what we can turn on and turn off. And so we can be very agile in that view as we get closer to February.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. No. And I appreciate that. I'm not trying to front-run your guidance. And maybe the better question I should ask more specific to that is at the current 5 rig count, what does that imply for annualized CapEx then?

componenttext: Well, again, we haven't set our 2017 plan. My only reason for bringing up the $700 million were 2 points: one, just to make sure people understood that point. And there's a good amount of upside. We're returning back to flat production using that -- just maintenance capital. And then we'll analyze and look at the markets as we approve our budget and, in the end, look for opportunities to either go faster or drill more as economics and cash flow afford.

componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Randy Curry. The differential outlook, we remain very positive on the structural improvement in differentials over the long term. In spite of the recent headwinds, some of the projects that were going to be coming online in '17 are facing. We do believe that it's a question of when, not if. And so, right now, our differentials for '17 are at the strip levels. And the strip is also indicating out in the future, '18 and '19, some structural improvement, and that's consistent with what we're modeling.

componenttext: Okay. I guess my follow-up is -- may not be to you to answer, I guess. I'm going to have a go anyway. componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at Marcellus, and I don't -- these numbers probably don't have all of the improvements in them yet. We're working on that. But Marcellus economic wells are $2.60, $2.63 kind of range on pricing, that's a 10% kind of return. West Virginia is probably -- dry is probably $2.50. I don't have a wet one with the newer kind of outlook on gas pricing. We can get that to you, but -- I mean, not gas pricing but ethane improvements. But the portfolio looks very positive for opportunities to invest and make the returns we need in that range. If you look at 1.3 PVI numbers, and they're probably in the $2.80s to $2.90s for each of those 2 areas.

componenttext: Doug, this is Craig. In Fayetteville, it kind of just follow up on Bill's note or Bill's comments. Fayetteville, certainly at current prices, with the high 17, certainly looks good. What we're seeing in these early results -- we talked about these IPs and certainly testing Moorefield continues to push that breakeven down. But as we've kind of seen kind of layout based on historical results in our IR deck, Fayetteville at $3 flat gives you about 500 well locations. So you can maybe push that a little bit lower. And certainly, with new results, can continue to push. And that really kind of goes with all locations. As we continue to drive cost out of the system and improve production rates or EURs, that helps, but the numbers Bill quoted on our Appalachian assets is fair.

componenttext: And I'll comment. We have just one more thing on that. In the Fayetteville, we're doing some Moorefield drilling right now. We don't have -- the results are kind of early days, but those wells are coming on quite strong. So they have -- their economics are very solid. We're not doing anything that doesn't meet our 1.3 PVI investment hurdle at strip pricing, and that's excluding any hedge benefits. So you can kind of see that in each of the 3 areas, there's some depth in -- and some good depth in terms of well locations available to pursue.

componenttext:
Yes. I'll -- let me talk a little bit about the pace of what we're doing, and then I'll do some exit rates stuff at the back end. The -- there's a combination of things at work here. We've restarted the activity. We want to be as efficient as we can. And so really most of the completions in the fourth quarter will come across fairly ratably.
We expect that we will do -- our objective is to complete all the DUCs or as many DUCs as we can out of Fayetteville and then, in each of the other 2 assets, retain a level of DUCs only for efficiency. We don't -- when we halted activities at the end of the year, first part of this year, we had a DUC inventory. We then restarted. That's all going fine, and we're just working them off. Since we don't anticipate a large amount of drilling in Fayetteville, we don't need a large amount of inventory in Fayetteville. So you get those to market and begin to get returns on those. In the other 2 areas, you're going to be focused on capturing those that you can get to market in an efficient and timely manner to capitalize on those rising prices while retaining enough that we can be efficient with our plan. So I think at the end of the day, you'll see it ratably across the year. And on volume, what was your question on volume?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the -- what implications that would have for exit rate on '16?
componenttext: Just the -- what implications that would have for exit rate on '16?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far as the fracture -- the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations
componenttext: We're looking at about 2.2 to 2.3 Bcf a day equivalent exit rate. And as far as the fracture -- the level of completions, we're currently running 5 completion frac crews. We may pick up a sixth, but it's -- we're very smooth and just continuous operations. The only thing that impacts it -- the reason we don't have a little faster pace is water availability in Pennsylvania. And it comes and goes. They've been getting a lot of rain up there right now, so we don't foresee a problem.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my follow question -- and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your '17, so I guess, you're free to deflect a part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, it looks lik
componenttext: Got it. And then my follow question -- and Bill, I apologize if this is pushing too far to your '17, so I guess, you're free to deflect a part of the question. But as you look ahead to '17, I know you're going to work down your DUC inventory, it looks like by 16 in Q4, and then you say you'll be back to the -- your target of that 60% inventory that you need for efficiency in '17. So that implies you're going to work down your DUC inventory by another roughly 25 over the course of the year. What -- compared to the 52 completions you're going to have in Q4, what do you think your completion rate per quarter is going to look like in '17?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like. And we haven't done that yet. So we're doing scenario planning around that now. W
componenttext: Well, you're right. We will get those inventories to where they're efficient. The completion inventory in '17 will be directly related to what our capital budget looks like. And we haven't done that yet. So we're doing scenario planning around that now. We want to remain flexible between the 2 divisions up in the Northeast. And so as -- our DUC inventory, our rate of burnoff of DUCs, our timing of wells and completions, the underlying theme will be it will be as efficient as we can to drive higher margin through lower cost and improved well performance. And it'll be -- the makeup of that will be part of our capital plan.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Holly Stewart with Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Holly Stewart with Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit. How -- and, I guess, could you just talk through how you're viewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus, I guess, the slide deck is a littl
componenttext: Just quickly maybe following up on Charles' question a little bit. How -- and, I guess, could you just talk through how you're viewing the ramp process so far versus your expectations? It looks like DUC count now versus, I guess, the slide deck is a little higher, and the wells' turn to sales projection for the year is a little bit -- I guess, year-to-date is not right on par with the forecast. So just trying to get a good sense for how you think it's going and maybe if -- to see expectations here as you work through the fourth quarter?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. The headline is it's going terrific. Remember, there's 2 components to this. First component on the fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can, and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget. The seco
componenttext: Sure. Yes. The headline is it's going terrific. Remember, there's 2 components to this. First component on the fracture stimulation side is we want to be as efficient as we can, and we want to get the count to where it optimally suits our budget. The second thing that we talked about -- and this is critical, is the frac intensity or the testing that's going on, on these -- on some of these wells. We're ramping sand loading in a couple cases from 1,000 to 2,000 pounds a foot from 2,000 to 5,000 pounds a foot. And so those -- that testing impacts some of these wells. And to put that much more sand in that many more stages into a well takes longer to do. And so the only issue that we have right now -- and it's not really an issue. I miscalled it. It's an opportunity -- is we're doing some testing related to higher sand loading, which will have positive effects, we expect, on our wells. We've already seen that in West Virginia where we've gone up above 2,000 to almost 3,000 pounds in wells that are already online. And that, combined with how we're landing them and how we're flowing them and all of that is improving their individual performance. Well, we expect that to be the case elsewhere. And a nuance to all that statement is we're, right now, focused on technical limit. So we've already proved up to ourselves that we can get a whole lot more sand in and make a whole lot better wells, which makes them more economic. We want to know how much can you do. And so we focused the folks on that. We'll do those wells and get them online and see and then we'll bring them. And if we go to the place where much higher sand content and stage phasing, et cetera, becomes more of the norm after we test it, then we'll readjust our schedule, let you know what that looks like and go from there. That's the real big piece of that whole calendar issue.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And then maybe just following up on the sand comment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000 well -- or the 5,000 pound per furlough -- or foot test, and then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess, is that well online? Is
componenttext: Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And then maybe just following up on the sand comment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks the 5,000 well -- or the 5,000 pound per furlough -- or foot test, and then you just mentioned 3,000. I guess, is that well online? Is there anything to think through there? And then, was that a wet versus dry well? Just trying to think through, I guess, historically, you said you'd been at 2,000 pounds. So just trying to think through how that could potentially impact the results.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Holly, this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. They'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000 pound tests that we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the Re
componenttext: Holly, this is Jack. We have not brought any of our current tests online yet. They'll be coming on this quarter. But we do have some higher, greater than 3,000 pound tests that we did last year that are part of the better performance I mentioned on the Redland [ph] Land Ventures Pad. So we're building on that. Actually, stretching again, as Bill said, the technical limits to do that. We have brought on, in Northeast PA, some of our -- the Racine pad I mentioned was one that we went to tighter cluster spacing, more stages. And that contributes to the time, but it -- we're definitely seeing the performance there. And it's -- they're with high sand already at the 2,000 pounds that we adopted last year.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you walk through these, you've got a couple things going on. You've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have, and they're all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000 p
componenttext: So as you walk through these, you've got a couple things going on. You've got 3 different areas of production in the 3 divisions we have, and they're all in various stages of ramping up. And so you take Fayetteville going from 500 or 800 pounds to 2,000 pounds. That doesn't mean we're stopping there. That's a big leap for them. In the Northeast assets, we've already have proof that, that, in certain areas, that you can go up past 3,000 pounds and get materially better wells. Now we want to figure out, okay, how do we step that up and in what increment. I've got engineers that would like to do a whole lot more than even the numbers we've been talking about, but we want to be prudent about it as well. And then, we'll figure out where that economic threshold crosses that technical limit and optimize at that point and go forward. So we'll -- we've got a lot of moving parts here. And the early indications, both from late last year and early now with some of the Racine work in Northeast Pennsylvania and some of these, is very encouraging and we'll continue to pursue that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I was wondering if you could comment on the potential delays on Atlantic Sunrise. I think you do have some modest volumes on that project and what that means to SWN as we think about 2017/2018 and your -- how you're thinking about capital allocation
componenttext: Bill, I was wondering if you could comment on the potential delays on Atlantic Sunrise. I think you do have some modest volumes on that project and what that means to SWN as we think about 2017/2018 and your -- how you're thinking about capital allocation?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly, on a relative basis to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the
componenttext: Yes. Just in general, our exposure to Atlantic Sunrise and the Constitution Pipeline, quite frankly, on a relative basis to our portfolio is -- are small. We are watching both of those. We are very, very aware and trying to be more aware every day of the different twists and turns that are going on with those projects. We think that both are robust projects and should happen. But we've known for some time that we needed to manage our overall portfolio in that area by adding additional capacity. Last year, we added some additional capacity around what we already had, anticipating that you could have some scheduling challenges. I think, further, probably the greatest near-term impact becomes the seasonal differential challenge, especially as production and pricing resumes. And if you get production coming back online, you get the differential challenge. We're trying to manage that through basis hedging. Our overall transportation portfolio pricing is very low in that area. And so managing that to the markets we serve, managing the -- any kind of a basis challenge with further hedging we certainly are doing, and we'll watch it closely. Randy may have some other comments for you, but we feel pretty good about where we sit relative to that right now.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I agree with everything Bill said, obviously. The only thing in color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year, yesterday, and then there's a 90-day period after that. So the
componenttext: Yes. I agree with everything Bill said, obviously. The only thing in color I'd add is everybody, I think, is aware the FERC did issue a new deadline for the EIS, which is the end of the year, yesterday, and then there's a 90-day period after that. So the project has been certainly pushed back a little bit. But as Bill said, we feel really good about our overall portfolio out of Northeast PA and Southwest Virginia. And what we had was a 44k -- 44,000 a day volume on Atlantic Sunrise.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up on that. Can you give us an update on Rover as well where you do have more a significant -- from transportation exposure?
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up on that. Can you give us an update on Rover as well where you do have more a significant -- from transportation exposure?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Rover has received their final EIS. And there's actually an expectation, I believe, by the industry and the market that they'll receive some notification here very soon at the expiration of the 90-day period. So to-date, I think all the feedback that
componenttext: Yes. Rover has received their final EIS. And there's actually an expectation, I believe, by the industry and the market that they'll receive some notification here very soon at the expiration of the 90-day period. So to-date, I think all the feedback that we're getting from the pipeline is they remain confident on that and will be able to start construction fairly soon.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just my second question would be just on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic on NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your Southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachia ac
componenttext: Okay. And just my second question would be just on the NGLs. Bill, you highlighted how you're quite optimistic on NGLs and ethane. And how could you -- as you think about '17, could we see more activity in your Southern Marcellus or Southern Appalachia acreage to take advantage of that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the way we're doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to the
componenttext: Yes. I think the way we're doing this, as I said earlier, we've got economic projects in all 3 of our operating areas. And what we do in putting together the portfolio of projects is that we force rank them all. And we look at the PVI contribution to the company from each of the areas, and we rank them. And as we're working through that planning process and we see further and further signs of some clear strengthening of NGLs, you get some of the wells move around in that positioning. And so yes, it's entirely likely that as you look at where that mix falls out in that, by the time we issue guidance that you see it move around. We are -- I'm a firm believer in leveraging every strength you have. And because we have our -- we're vertically integrated, have our own rigs, we have our flexibility to move around, we have capacity in each of the areas, we need to take advantage of that and be able to be agile in working through that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marshall Carver from Heikkinen Energy Advisers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marshall Carver from Heikkinen Energy Advisers.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What are your wells cost own [ph] by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with the larger completions?
componenttext: Yes. What are your wells cost own [ph] by area now for a typical well? And how much more expensive are the wells with the larger completions?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- typically, in Northeast PA, we're looking at about -- still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because of the service prices right now are very favorable. We now,
componenttext: Well, the -- typically, in Northeast PA, we're looking at about -- still around $5 million, $5.5 million. We have not seen an increase in costs overall with our testing of the completions because of the service prices right now are very favorable. We now, in the very large jobs, we're pumping in West Virginia and Southwest Appalachia, we are adding $1 million to $2 million generally to our well cost. They're up to $8 million on the well cost, $8 million to $8.5 million, but we're getting a great return. I believe the work we did at the end of '15, we think, on that $2 million we invested extra on those, we got 2 PVI on that $2 million. So it's -- the return is very healthy on the incremental sand and the cluster spacing. Fayetteville is still right around $3 million on our wells. We have our own sand mine, and so sand is very cheap there.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In West Virginia, $7 million on a -- or 7,800 foot lateral in rich gas and about $6.5 million on a 6,000 foot lateral in this lean gas.
componenttext: In West Virginia, $7 million on a -- or 7,800 foot lateral in rich gas and about $6.5 million on a 6,000 foot lateral in this lean gas.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, $3.25 versus $3.50 gas price environment for 2017?
componenttext: Can you talk about capital allocation to the Fayetteville beyond completing the DUCs? How aggressive should we expect you to ramp up activity if we're in a, say, $3.25 versus $3.50 gas price environment for 2017?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly, as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology -- our completion practices,
componenttext: Yes. I kind of mentioned this a bit earlier. Certainly, as we look at the Moorefield testing that's going on, we want to understand the aerial extent of that. We want to understand how the changes to our completion technology -- our completion practices, flowback practices and drilling practices, what impact that has on the Fayetteville. I remain in the same place that I spoke about earlier, though, is that you have some targeted testing, and if that opens up new frontiers, then we put that into the mix. You have some land capture in the 2 other divisions, not Fayetteville. Absent those and maybe 1 or 2 other things, then you start looking at relative economics to the Northeast. And a big piece of our capital productivity improvement, a big piece of, really, our overall performance improvement is allocating capital to the highest best use of that capital. And today, with current technology and current commercial terms and all the other things that go into that, our 2 Northeast assets, by and large, are -- have that advantage. And so in the first pileup of projects, the majority of it obviously goes to the Northeast. But as you're seeing right now, we have a rig in Fayetteville. It's focusing on Moorefield. It's focusing on some other testing. And we've got some other things we're working on. And then, the rest of the activity is in the other 2 places. And we challenge the teams all the time, and they take this challenge on very well. And as you can see from our results, it shows through. Each group, while they're working for the whole of the company, they're driving in their own backyard, driving margin improvements, driving productivity and well improvements. You make major inroads into the water management of any of these divisions and you move the needle. So there's a lot of very exciting testing going on around water management and around different techniques. It can move the dial. So as we work through the remainder of this year and continue this -- the planning for '17, all of that will be taken into account. But the headline for you is really it's all about economic value and driving economic value out of what we have. And so the bias, the current view at this 10 seconds obviously goes to capturing that value in the Northeast.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the Moorefield point that you mentioned a couple times. Obviously, that's baseload because you're doing that now with the 1 rig you've added. Is it also the next -- is it also on the margin? In other words, if you do want to add more
componenttext: Just to follow up on the Moorefield point that you mentioned a couple times. Obviously, that's baseload because you're doing that now with the 1 rig you've added. Is it also the next -- is it also on the margin? In other words, if you do want to add more activity to the Fayetteville, would you actually do more Moorefield tests first with another rig over a wider area extent? Or would you actually go to doing more development drilling for the Fayetteville zone? I know you mentioned that, that would have to come only if the returns are better than Appalachia, but let's just say they are.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If they are, then certainly they would compete in the investment stack and you'd go from there. I'm going to do capital allocation based off of proof. And so the guys -- the teams are working those out, and certainly, we will go from there. I don't know w
componenttext: If they are, then certainly they would compete in the investment stack and you'd go from there. I'm going to do capital allocation based off of proof. And so the guys -- the teams are working those out, and certainly, we will go from there. I don't know whether at this 10 seconds whether we'll do more Moorefield testing next year or we'll gain enough to be able to sort of lay that all out and put it again in the priority stack.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. This is Craig. I may just add, as Bill indicated, Moorefield is certainly something that we like. We like what we've seen. But all of Fayetteville continues -- as the teams continue to work in the 6 months, doing a lot of work on paper and a l
componenttext: Yes, Brian. This is Craig. I may just add, as Bill indicated, Moorefield is certainly something that we like. We like what we've seen. But all of Fayetteville continues -- as the teams continue to work in the 6 months, doing a lot of work on paper and a lot of challenge across divisions and in divisions. It is kind of stepped up, and we like the early results we've seen. So it continues to compete, and it continues to claw back. If you'd asked us that question 9 months ago, I think, in a $3 flat environment, our bias would have been most of the economics would have been in the north. I think that's -- we're seeing some positive things that may be changing that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We challenge the team with thousands of well locations that are sitting there on the price curve, and they rise to that occasion. So we look forward to talking more about that as we learn more.
componenttext: We challenge the team with thousands of well locations that are sitting there on the price curve, and they rise to that occasion. So we look forward to talking more about that as we learn more.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kashy Harrison with Simmons.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kashy Harrison with Simmons.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Racine pad with the really impressive initial results, could you give us an idea of what your expectations are for year one cumulative production on an individual well? And then, could you also give us some idea as to what extent this optimized
componenttext: So on the Racine pad with the really impressive initial results, could you give us an idea of what your expectations are for year one cumulative production on an individual well? And then, could you also give us some idea as to what extent this optimized flowback technique would be incorporated into future wells being brought online?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the headline for you -- Jack may have some comments to go with it. The headline for you is it's just too early to tell. When we -- as a matter of practice just now and going forward and even in the past, when we have some very high rate perfo
componenttext: Yes. I think the headline for you -- Jack may have some comments to go with it. The headline for you is it's just too early to tell. When we -- as a matter of practice just now and going forward and even in the past, when we have some very high rate performance out of some wells, given advancing sand loading or given advancing anything, we're going to study them, understand them, are we accelerating EURs, are we opening up new recovery percentages, all that. And so these have not been on all that long. And so I would guard against adding to EUR at this time. What is clear is when they -- as they come on and they flow at this rate, you're accelerating value. And that is -- that's our driver is trying to figure out how do we maximize value. As soon as we get a bit more of those under our belt -- we're in a kind of a fun but awkward time right now. We've been offline in the drilling and completions area for 6 months. We've come back with a just an aggressively strong performance and -- but it's too early, and I don't want to lead you down a path that we can't confirm.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dan McSpirit from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan McSpirit from BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: Circling back on a previous answer regarding capital spending in 2017, what would 5 rigs running in $900 million in capital spending mean for production growth in 2017?

componenttext: Yes. I don't have that yet. It depends on where you allocate those, that capital and where you allocate those rigs and how many -- how the completions go. And the divisions are all very different. So I'll ask you to stay tuned on that.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And then, as a follow-up, relatively heavy use of swaps in 2017 as part of the hedging program. Just curious as to why swaps versus greater use of collars?
componenttext: Very good. And then, as a follow-up, relatively heavy use of swaps in 2017 as part of the hedging program. Just curious as to why swaps versus greater use of collars?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our program is one where we just -- we try to find the right balance. And we want to have a portfolio of both swaps and collars to give us both some floor certainty and then also some opportunity for the upside. So it's really just a balanced approach.
componenttext: Our program is one where we just -- we try to find the right balance. And we want to have a portfolio of both swaps and collars to give us both some floor certainty and then also some opportunity for the upside. So it's really just a balanced approach.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple questions. One, I think Bill, it was you that referenced ethane. Can you just talk about what type of leverage you have to that and what that could mean as far as margin and pricing? I know I have here -- obviously have [indiscernible] on the lin
componenttext: A couple questions. One, I think Bill, it was you that referenced ethane. Can you just talk about what type of leverage you have to that and what that could mean as far as margin and pricing? I know I have here -- obviously have [indiscernible] on the line, but can you expand on that a little more?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Randy?
componenttext: Sure. Randy?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Randy. Yes. The -- we have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our ATEX capacity, and so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do sta
componenttext: Yes. This is Randy. Yes. The -- we have a nice exposure to Mont Belvieu pricing via our ATEX capacity, and so that is really one of the primary drivers. Also ethane represents a little over 60% of our NGL barrels. So those 2 factors combined really do start impacting kind of the wet versus dry economics when we start seeing some significant shift in ethane. And the longer-term outlook, given the crackers that are under construction as we speak, for demand in the Mont Belvieu area is fairly significant. We're looking at over 600,000 to 700,000 barrels a day of demand on top of a base that is 1.2 million. You couple that with some export capacity, and that's why you see a rather strong outlook for ethane, which we have some -- certainly have some good exposure to.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.
componenttext: And export capacity is nearly 300,000 barrels a day. So you've got some material demand happening.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, as it relates to -- remind me, how should we think about '17/'18 as far as framework? What are you putting up [indiscernible] I guess I'll call them governors as far as debt to EBITDA levels, within cash flow, you're off-sp
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, as it relates to -- remind me, how should we think about '17/'18 as far as framework? What are you putting up [indiscernible] I guess I'll call them governors as far as debt to EBITDA levels, within cash flow, you're off-spin [ph] cash flow? But how should we -- we can play around in pricing, but how should we be thinking about that?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. At this point, I think that what you have to think about is you look at the forward curve, and depending on what that -- your view of that is, you look at our cash flow that our assets can generate, and then you look at the capital that investing wit
componenttext: Yes. At this point, I think that what you have to think about is you look at the forward curve, and depending on what that -- your view of that is, you look at our cash flow that our assets can generate, and then you look at the capital that investing within cash flow would add up to. And that's how we intend to be thinking about setting these budgets and plans. You look at assurance of that. We have a 3-year rolling hedging program that the front year's hedged about where you see we're at for '17. Then you look at the 2 following years. And we want to have a rigor and discipline around rolling those in, taking into account market forces and economics of the program and the investments. But I think right now, it would be prudent for you to look at that from the standpoint of hedging within -- or not hedging, but investing within cash flow as that's what we think is prudent.

componenttext: I was just curious, I know on the -- there was the illustrative $700 million in CapEx plan to hold whole things flat. I know a lot of things are dynamic. headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. The Moorefield Shale, can you give us -- I wasn't sure if I heard it or not. But what do those wells cost right now relative to the Fayetteville wells?

componenttextpreview: They run about $3.5 million to $4 million.
componenttext: They run about $3.5 million to $4 million.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you opened up your remarks, Bill, by talking about how you've basically been 95% within the zone or your target of where you want to land these laterals. You also talked about improvements with proppant loading. Are you seeing the biggest
componenttext: Okay. And then, you opened up your remarks, Bill, by talking about how you've basically been 95% within the zone or your target of where you want to land these laterals. You also talked about improvements with proppant loading. Are you seeing the biggest step-change from that lateral landing from rotary steerables? Or is the performance that you see this year more of a function of sand-loading? And where would have said that you were in terms of percentage of hitting zone in 2015?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jack. We're -- the rotary steerables have helped us in getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting them in zone before. They were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance of the wells is that -
componenttext: This is Jack. We're -- the rotary steerables have helped us in getting the laterals in place and speed. Those are where they are. We were getting them in zone before. They were taking longer. We were drilling slower. The performance of the wells is that -- it's a combination of landing in the proper zone and the completion techniques. The Moore sand is definitely making better wells, but if you don't get them in zone, it doesn't matter how much sand you put in.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing we're looking at, and we do this all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look at your -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so yo
componenttext: And the other thing we're looking at, and we do this all the time, as wells get better, you need to go back and look at your -- at the surface facilities and the gathering systems, and are they sized appropriately for improving well performance, and so you upsize meter runs or upsize production facilities. And I'm not talking about massive upsizing. Go from 2 to 3 inch, and you get a huge benefit. Looking at tubing design. In history, we've done some modified tubing design. We've done some tubing in these wells in different parts of the company, and we're applying all of those learnings back towards these assets as well. So you'll continue to see the components improve the overall performance. And as we can triangulate around, well, they think sand is contributing this much and better. As different flowback regimes or different surface facilities contribute to that much, we can share that with you, but we're getting solid performance out of each component.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Drew Venker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to circle back on the earlier question about your expectation for differentials next year. Just wanted to clarify, are you thinking pricing is better on an absolute basis in Appalachia? Or you're thinking differentials are actually narrower than for 2016?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Actually, differentials for this quarter compared to '15 in Northeast Appalachia were actually slightly better. And our forecast and our outlook and planning is kind of what the current strip is right now for calendar '17.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
