componenttext: And I'm sorry, just to clarify that. You're saying in line with strip. So is that better than -- narrower than this year? Or is it actually a little bit wider?

componenttext: It's greatly influenced by the seasonal effects. I would say there's probably right now about the same as this past year -- that I'm talking about.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this quarter, Northeast PA production was down, I think, more than the prior quarter. Just curious if you had shut in any volumes and just wondering on your typical operational plan. As you said in your remarks earlier, 3Q is typically your weak
componenttext: Okay. And this quarter, Northeast PA production was down, I think, more than the prior quarter. Just curious if you had shut in any volumes and just wondering on your typical operational plan. As you said in your remarks earlier, 3Q is typically your weakest pricing quarter of the year. Do you typically try to constrain volumes when prices are low? Or is it mitigated by some other basis swaps or other measures?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't normally constrain volumes unless prices get very low, which in the quarter they were actually not that -- at that point. There was a lot of maintenance went on, on different pipelines during the quarter that did hurt our production in the Northe
componenttext: We don't normally constrain volumes unless prices get very low, which in the quarter they were actually not that -- at that point. There was a lot of maintenance went on, on different pipelines during the quarter that did hurt our production in the Northeast a little. And we've brought on -- [indiscernible] the wells came on later in the quarter, the new wells that we didn't bring on. So it was normal decline generally.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we -- the investments that we did make early in the year, the benefit of that showed up in Q2. And so then you'll go [ph] 6 months without much of activity that'll do Q3. But as I said earlier, when you get to -- when you include the activity that we
componenttext: When we -- the investments that we did make early in the year, the benefit of that showed up in Q2. And so then you'll go [ph] 6 months without much of activity that'll do Q3. But as I said earlier, when you get to -- when you include the activity that we've got going on now and the improvement of the overall business, setting aside the activity we have going on now with just the overall improvement, we arrest decline by the end of Q4, and you're actually building back volume. So it was probably mostly related to just sequencing and timing.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing that was just pointed out to me that when we started -- restarted our drilling, you usually have simultaneous operations. You have some shut-in on the pads that you do actually curtail production, but it's really from a HS&E standpoint
componenttext: And the other thing that was just pointed out to me that when we started -- restarted our drilling, you usually have simultaneous operations. You have some shut-in on the pads that you do actually curtail production, but it's really from a HS&E standpoint that we do it. And so that goes in the second quarter. We had no operations going on. Third quarter, we did have some that contributed somewhat.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have minimal volume in the dailies. Most of our volume is under contract. So you have some just minimal volume. And if we don't cover cash costs, we don't -- we won't reduce it [ph]. But it doesn't show up on the radar. It's not material.
componenttext: And we have minimal volume in the dailies. Most of our volume is under contract. So you have some just minimal volume. And if we don't cover cash costs, we don't -- we won't reduce it [ph]. But it doesn't show up on the radar. It's not material.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ray Deacon from Coker & Palmer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ray Deacon from Coker & Palmer.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I was wondering if you could talk about your attempts to lock in additional firm transportation if you were to make the decision to ramp in the Southwest at this point, looking out to 2017, and keep the current rig count in place.
componenttext: Yes. I was wondering if you could talk about your attempts to lock in additional firm transportation if you were to make the decision to ramp in the Southwest at this point, looking out to 2017, and keep the current rig count in place.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to $1, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquired as
componenttext: Yes. Kind of a high-level view, and then I would like Randy to give you whatever color we can on that. When we went into Southwest Appalachia, we saw the very high price, very -- close to $1, long 20-year agreements. We got in there early. We acquired as much transportation as we needed to do 2 things, one, get an early ramp on the business. And assuming the pipes come in when they're supposed to come in, we can ramp that thing at 35% a year for the next 3 years comfortably. We then wanted to look at where the pipes get built, so committing to the right pipes at the right place to access our acreage was really important. And then, we stepped back. 16 Bcf a day of pipeline capacity, excluding expansion capacity being built all in one area is a lot of capacity. And taking on long-term commitments, which end up having to drill into or whatever, didn't make any sense to us at all. And so we said we'll wait because we do believe and, I think the industry shares this with us, that there will come an inflection point in the -- all this expansion where the cost of those and especially if you get into any expansion-type capacity, the cost of that comes down. and we will leg into that at a later date as that cost does come down and the terms get more rationalized. We also have the opportunity to enter and we have into firm sales capacity where we are making sales into other consuming-side, demand-side debt capacity. And so we'll continue to work that. And Randy may have some additional color he wants to put on that, but at a high level, that's kind of our philosophy.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The
componenttext: Yes, Bill. The only thing I would add to that, and Bill touched on it, is we're going to have a portfolio of options out of really all the basins we operate. So there'll be a mix of FT and mix of firm sales and mix of daily exposure to local indices. The outlook, again, is one that we think structurally, over time, improves, and we'll continue that. What we have today in FT we're very comfortable with, with commitments that we have made on some pipes that will be coming online. And so we're -- we'll continue to watch that but feel very confident about our position as it stands today.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess, just one more follow-up on that is it seems as though some have noticed that you have less exposure to the Midwest relative to others. And is that something you see as critical to price realizations going forward?
componenttext: Great. I guess, just one more follow-up on that is it seems as though some have noticed that you have less exposure to the Midwest relative to others. And is that something you see as critical to price realizations going forward?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We want to have exposure -- a balanced portfolio and a broad portfolio. There will be some Midwest exposure in -- with some of the capacity that we have that's to be built, but we also are very oriented towards the Gulf Coast as -- really as you look at k
componenttext: We want to have exposure -- a balanced portfolio and a broad portfolio. There will be some Midwest exposure in -- with some of the capacity that we have that's to be built, but we also are very oriented towards the Gulf Coast as -- really as you look at kind of Gulf Coast and Southeast, where the demand growth expectations are, that's certainly a value to us as well.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for one last question. Our last question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: We have time for one last question. Our last question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First thing I wanted to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so are you also increasing latera
componenttext: First thing I wanted to ask was, this call, we've had more discussion around completions rather than lateral length. And I think most E&Ps are pretty unified around lateral length, improving economics. I was just curious, so are you also increasing lateral length in your Fayetteville and Moorefield tests as well as in the 2 Appalachia areas?

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We're analyzing that the -- and we were up virtually 100% in zone and all the things
componenttext: Yes. Where we can, in some places, lateral length is limited to -- by unit size or how the -- how that is made up. We've done lateral length testing up past 12,500 feet. We're analyzing that the -- and we were up virtually 100% in zone and all the things that we've talked about. And what we're doing is analyzing that flowback. We have 4 of those wells, I believe, in 2 different areas are some of our longest that we have. And you want -- the trick is making sure that you're getting the contribution out of the full lateral length and that when you rerun economics, so it's not about flow rate or IP or any of that. It's about well economics. You make sure that these extended-reach laterals, you're getting the contribution out of the whole thing for the investment that you're making. And it's a risk-reward balance. But we do -- as we look to block up land, we are consistently -- so for example in the range, we started out in West Virginia a 7,500 foot target lateral. I think some of our latest averages are like 7,800. We'll continue to block up acreage in trade and exchange, so that you can get those out there while we're testing these longer-reach ones. The Moorefield laterals are longer. The Fayetteville well laterals are longer as well. So the trend is longer, but we will make sure that value per risked foot and all that makes sense.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little higher-level question on that Fayetteville to close, if -- looking at it longer term, is there an argument for high-grading and downsizing the assets through sales or acreage release, in other words, the more challenged locations? And I'm al
componenttext: Just a little higher-level question on that Fayetteville to close, if -- looking at it longer term, is there an argument for high-grading and downsizing the assets through sales or acreage release, in other words, the more challenged locations? And I'm also wondering how the Fayetteville's midstream might affect any thinking on that point.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions. We do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. We're seeing the applicat
componenttext: Yes, I think you look at the Fayetteville from a number of different dimensions. We do. First of all, it's just a massive cash flow generation machine. And the opportunity that, that affords the company is certainly a bright one. We're seeing the application of commercial and technical and operating expertise be applied in an even greater pace that is unlocking additional opportunities. Certainly, our midstream business is integral to that. The agility that we have, the ability to move back and forth, the ability to be flexible as a corporation, again, not drilling into somebody else's midstream contract or not drilling into the firm transportation that you've overcommitted to, any of those kinds of things. It's a balance. And I think we see that Fayetteville is a vast resource that continues to generate cash flow. Any of these assets are certainly assets that you look, say can I get greater value doing something different than I'm doing now. And we work that routinely. Where are they on their cost curve? Or you take a subset of it. We did a transaction in West Virginia on some acreage we weren't even going to get to until 2023. So it wasn't that it was not economic. It's just so long-dated that why -- if we're able to accelerate that value at a good value then it [indiscernible] do it. So I think we continue to look at it as the answer. We don't want to put ourselves in a place where we do a because we've done b. We want them to be economically synchronized, and we think that you add more value in the long run.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're out of time for questions. I would like to turn the call back over to management for closing comments.
componenttext: We're out of time for questions. I would like to turn the call back over to management for closing comments.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and thank you all for being here today and taking an interest in what we're doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout the call this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we
componenttext:
Well, thank you, and thank you all for being here today and taking an interest in what we're doing. You've heard a lot of impressive accomplishments throughout the call this morning. The good news is that we've positioned each of these assets well. And we think that they're each set up to where you can expect to have even more results and even better results as we go forward in time. With the stability that we've recaptured in the company this year, we've got a clearer path to capturing and delivering value-creating growth. And we're doing all of that in a rising gas price environment. And positioning yourself to capitalize on a rising gas price environment is a big piece of that objective. Our portfolio's primed to deliver impressive well results as we learn from all the things we've talked about today. And our firm transportation portfolio allows us the flexibility to maneuver and navigate and work through an ever-changing basis environment and ever-changing regulatory environment and an ever-changing pricing environment. So we'll continue to devise and implement innovative drilling and operating techniques and efficiencies. We will -- we are -- we have what we call around here an aggressive assault on improving margin. And so every individual in this company is driven by, incentivized by the quest to reduce cost, improve the operating results of every part of the business. So you have it on the revenue side. You have it on the cost side. And we're committed to continue to increase that margin. And finally, we will maintain the rigor, capital allocation, capital discipline, financial responsibility that we've demonstrated so far this year and is a hallmark of our company. 
So I want to thank each of you for joining us on the call today. Thanks for all the questions. We look forward to seeing you along the road and hope you all have a great weekend.

headline: Southwestern Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's teleconference. Thank you for your participation. You may disconnect your lines at this time. And have a wonderful day.
